Hot Pursuit is that rare breed of comedy that is so frivolous and haphazardly realized that it can only aspire to stupidity in its characters and in itself.
A sense of duty and a desire to create pretty pictures ... aren't exactly compelling reasons to mount a cinematic adaptation of a celebrated novel.
[I]f a musical can't even trust the music, what's the point?
About Elly is devastating because the lies here are simultaneously necessary, useless, and so dreadfully familiar.
The film works not because of any kind of historical specificity but because of its ability to simplify.
[The sequel] has drained most of the joy, fun, and life out of these characters.
The Water Diviner almost succeeds by way of its unfaltering sincerity, but the movie is too unfocused ... for it to have much of an effect.
The movie starts down an honest path near the conclusion, but Monteverde and Portillo can't follow through on it.
[Dan's] humiliation is the sole joke of The D Train, and it's more than a bit cruel...
It's a study in relationships, and will leave plenty for couples to chat about afterwards...let's hope your conversations feel as authentic as the ones in the film.
A worthy endeavor that is still good, however I bet that falls short of it's lofty goals.
We got the right guy in the White House: Gerard Butler makes this the action movie that junkies like me can't get enough of.
Thanks for retaliating against the mess that was "Rise of COBRA"...now this franchise knows where it can go. And knowing is half the battle.

The film has a load of hallmarks which nod to the 1981 original, but takes some evry different twists and turns. It lacks some of that movie's personality, and it's not as scary as one might expect, but still a bloody good time at the movies.
Another pointless exercise that only served to make me deeply examine why comedy was ever funny. Next time, I'd rather just laugh.
It's a great way for kids of younger generations to meet one of the great athletes...and human beings...of all-time.
It's a noble attempt to focus on a love story within a blockbuster sci-fi summer movie; it's too bad that love cost us the chance to have a fun ride into the future.

Some eye-popping action sequences at least make this a worthy summer endeavor for movie fans, but it felt like "Iron Man 3" got such a big lead in the first half, it was content to run out the clock late in the game.
Some of Bay's go-to tricks actually inject some juice into film, and I'll at least admit that no one polishes a turd like Michael Bay. But does it still have to smell so bad?
The Force is strong with this one.
It's not my kind of horror flick anyway, but even for fans of gross-out gore-a-paloozas and campy humor this is a swing and a miss.
It's got enough laughs and impressive visuals for adults, so you won't feel creepy walking into the theater by yourself
Much like an extravagant gala, it looks majestic and sounds awesome but I couldn't care less about these rich folks throwing the bash.

These films embrace their silliness, and director Justin Lin moves the film along at such an exciting pace that your cerebral cortex never has time to tell you everything that's impossibly stupid about the action you've witnessed.
Thank you Joe Nicholl for reminding me that I don't just love movies for wookies and capes and guys in iron suits. Still pumped for IM3 though.
For what the movie is, it's fine: a breezy flick that gives you some chuckles, a couple smiles and won't take up much of your brain's hard drive.
Memorable because of the historical events upon which it's based, "Emperor" succeeds in adding human faces to a time when the vague atrocities of war ruled.
Don't call me...don't even text. Just let me stay in the trunk of a car where this movie can't hurt me anymore.
If it wasn't for the talent on screen I may have been bored by this, but hey, you hired these guys for a reason, right?
It's a little film that isn't exactly memorable, but it's a match strike of fresh individuality in a 2013 movie year that desperately needed a spark.
Stick around, Mr. Soderbergh, you have a better walk-off film in you than this one.
John Moore seems to take all of our hopes for this out with an exciting-then-boring car chase that feels like it takes 40 minutes to complete.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's silly, it's too long, but it's not "Twilight"...and that's never a bad thing.
Did I really just grade this a half-point better than "Die Hard 5"? Excuse me while I puke.
In an effort to creep up to a climax, "Stoker" instead meanders to the point where you just to quit.
Girls Gone Wild would have turned the cameras off and called the cops; luckily Harmony Korine was at the helm here to keep the action going in churning out an original movie.
By focusing on the story and dramatic elements, "Snitch" sacrifices more action than necessary but after sitting through "Die Hard 5", any story that makes sense is a welcome change.
Bryan Singer does deliver the money shots; the beanstalks, giant attacks and a forest in the clouds make for a terrific adventure.
I can't recommend this to anyone other than hardcore extraterrestrial junkies.
This is like a nice acoustic set. It lacks the excitement and inspired bombast of the first, but it's nice to see these guys back having a good time.
If I see "Oz" on the poster then I expect something "great and powerful", and "acceptable" just won't cut it.
It doesn't help the effort to be serious when the villains are so cartoonish and simple they should've tried to plant their crime ring in Oz
Somehow, all that potential disappeared, and we're left feeling like Burt halfway though the movie: swindled and unloved.
Juan Diego Solanas directs a film that's like nothing I've ever seen before.
The fights are worth the price of admission (come on people, there's an axe fight!), but as a movie "Bullet to the Head" can't get up there with Sly's other recent endeavors.
The 3D is impressive considering it wasn't shot for that, and the sound delivers full throttle engine roars and the legendary soundtrack sounds as crisp as ever.
I think that this "Machete" may have killed any desire I had to see yet another B-movie homage.
it may not be the complete return to form of Shyamalan, but "After Earth" has all the goods necessary for an entertaining summer ride.
It may leave you feeling underwhelmed, but the journey to get there is well worth the ride.
The suspense and involving tone of "Riddick" make it a solid first entry for fall and a credit to the sci-fi genre in an impressive 2013 campaign.
As a film it's edge of your seat terrifying stuff, so have at it, childless adults!
Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 is all carbs with no protein to be found.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If "Don Jon" feels like a film that is spread too thin amongst multiple genres, it only goes to hint that Gordon-Levitt might be as talented behind the camera as he is in front.
A stellar cast lifts "Thanks for Sharing" into an enjoyable and emotional journey.
"Through the Never" is a jaw-dropping, eye-popping, ear splitting reminder that the aristocracy that is heavy metal has only one true king: Metallica.
If you like plausible story, forget about this.
Forgettable fun for a Saturday afternoon on cable, but don't bet on this to be a worthwhile experience at the theater.
Their defeat may be inevitable, but we're all winners for discovering this small film.
movie_title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete (2013)

movie_review_blurb: You can have an all-time great director and a cast of award-winners but without an interesting story or something to say, they're just people hanging around the craft services table.
The Dark World blends action and humor with a deft touch that gets us all a little more excited about the future of the Marvel universe.
It can make you laugh and welcome the holiday spirit into your soul, unfortunately that's not all the overly-ambitious "The Best Man Holiday" tries to do.
It's an action-packed sci-fi adventure with just the right dash of humor, and maybe this could be a franchise all audiences can celebrate.
The performances aren't to blame here, but unfortunately everything else is: bad story, worse script, and useless subplots make "Parker" an action ride for which you won't want a ticket.
Somewhere along the way, we the audience, lose track of the tremendous acting and directing potential when we start to wonder why we ever cared about these people in the first place?
"Captain Phillips" takes a fertile news story and elevates it from just another action movie into an emotional powerhouse of a thriller.
here's humor, intense action and even some family friendly young lust...and it all adds up to a 3D animated feast that can play with the big boys of May.
Don't you just love when movies are aware of themselves, their limitations and focus on what they do well?
It's an entertaining film throughout that shouldn't provoke too much thought.

I was literally in pain from laughing so hard. The guys are just furthering a story so that we can get more laughs before the lights come back and we realize we may have just witnessed the end of the Best Comedy of 2013 competition.
It's not a bad time at the movies as far as alien movies go; it just doesn't have the Superman magic.

The scariest thing in theaters this summer is definitely over priviledged high school kids; unfortunately their film is only as enthralling as a day in Paris Hilton's life. Glamorous, but there's just not much going on beneath the surface.
It's the perfect summer movie for kids; the monsters on campus won't scare anyone in real life...problem is they won't make you laugh much either.
It's an adventure that literally spans the globe at a breakneck pace before shifitng into a tense, suspense-filled final frame.
"White House Down" makes "Olympus Has Fallen" look like a documentary...and I'll have to check the latter out again to get the taste of the former out of my mouth.
Bullock and McCarthy make a great team and one that will keep you laughing throughout.
The mythology, while not exactly dense, is so broad that the film ends up biting off more than it can chew.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: I'm an adult with no plans for children in the near future; and as great as the minions are I would advise other kidless folk to save room for "Despicable Me 2" at the front of your Netflix queue.
When Guillermo del Toro gets the freedom to transfer so much from his increbidle imagination onto the IMAX screen, I would follow it anywhere.
It's not one of these one-note horror flicks hoping to make you jump; this KNOWS how scary it is and will get you by the end.
It's a heartbreaking story that is so emotionally powerful that, while I may not want to see again, if it's on I won't be able to help but see it's tragic conclusion again.

If I was the Mayor of Hollywood for a day (or the president of Elysium), I'd give Blompkamp the "Star Wars" universe and say "take your pick, Champ...you've earned it." And then hope he picks a Boba Fett tale.
Sudekis clearly has leading man charisma on the big screen and is at his funniest when interacting with the other Millers.
It's an entertaining film that could have been as riveting as The Social Network but ends up being fun-on-cable during a lazy weekend afternoon.
It's funny, action-packed and self-effacing at the right moments: "Kick-Ass 2" just may have taken a boot to every other hero hoping to be the top dog on the big screen this year.
Cursed with useless dialogue, non-existent chemistry and (the worst sin of all) a boring story, "The Lone Ranger" proves that not even the Independence Day spirit horse always backs the right man.
There's certainly some surprises that earn genuine laughs, but as a whole the film has the feel of a bunch of SNL sketches in an off year that air after Weekend Update.
The biggest problem with the movie is that it has all these crazy dictator jokes, which are funny but when it tries to be a movie, it fails miserably. You don't buy any of it.
As much as I applaud the effort and ambition that went into adapting this movie from it's source material, I can't rate movies based on trying hard and "John" dies long before the movie ends.

John Carter lives on the other side of that line; Kick-Ass would be happy selling his pot business and doing something else...but that becomes impossible when you get mixed up with people like Benicio Del Toro and Salma Hayek. Bad news and I had a blast.

It's the largest in scale of any of Nolan's Batman movies. The tone felt more like a comic book than any of the rest, and I wanted the darker, reality feel. But it's a good ride, and it closes out the trilogy well.

Falling in and out of love, one goes out with someone new and the other gets jealous. who will end up with whom? That is the roller coaster ride that is this film and if you buy into the premise, it will enhance your enjoyment of the film immensely.

It made me laugh and even though it got untangled towards the end I had fun watching it. I'm gonna give this movie the same score as my mom, who accompanied us to the screening, 3.1 Schmoes. Decimals run in the family.
There are clear nods to the previous film but it doesn't hit you over the head with them; thus this one feels like it's own movie. I thoroughly enjoyed myself if this film. Wiseman's best.

It was like watching a basketball game trying to focus on the point guard match-ups and the centers....but the story just wasn't something I bought all the way through; I was never convinced that Tommy Lee Jones' character could complete this journey.

I was hooked and then it left me a bit flat at the end. Maybe I'm just spoiled because of The Avengers where I always want to see someone team up or go against each other. If that happens with this franchise it seems like it would fit.

The other thing you learn is that she had an interesting childhood...both her parents are preachers, traveling ministers. "Do ya feel the power of the Lord upon you"?? 700 Club on steroids kinda stuff.
Is it silly and sometimes stupid? Yes, of course it is, but it's a comedy and it made me laugh enough to where I can get it to 3/5 Schmoes.

Usually I can get into this movies, I get invested, I want to root for the characters but it took to long to get anywhere in this movie. There wasn't that Disney magic sprinkle you'd think would be in a movie like this.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This will take you over when you're watching it, there's some cool tricks that suck you in, but after you start thinking about it, you realize that it's nowhere near as good as you thought it was while you were watching it.
It's simply one of the worst horror movies I've ever seen in my life; such a waste of time being in that theater. It's so wholly awful it's almost an acheivement how bad it is.
It's a great movie, so much fun, an acheivement that should be enjoyed by children of all ages and worth seeing it in 3D.

With a story like this, you need strong, compelling performances and wow did we get them. Richard Gere, along with Michael Douglas, is my favorite rich guy. They're 1 and 1A and in this Richard Gere is beyond watchable.

The key to this movie, as with any PT Anderson film, is that the story relies heavily on performances and my word do we get a lot of great ones here. Obviously the two leads, Hoffman and Phoenix, could be looking at earning a little golden guy.

Bane leading the charge, the movie had a Public Enemies vibe to it. You feel totally immersed in this time and the southern dialect, a tough one to not go overboard on, was pulled off very well by all parties in the film.
Some good one-liners and some you don't even understand. Stallone was harder to understand in this movie than Bane was.
The closest you get to character development is when he smiles, frowns, or utters the occasional one line. That was all the life this film had.

I really enjoyed the movie. Solid cast, great performance by Tanning and Soderbergh's style makes you feel at ease when you shouldn't. If you have a problem watching a movie about male strippers, pretend they're comedians, pretend they're magicians.

It's a hilarious film that gets a little slow towards the end simply because it has to tell a real story. It gets even funnier with a couple gut-punches at the end. It's hysterical and the funniest movie I've seen so far this year.

It is a little overly ambitious and now that you mention it, reminds me of Funny People, it starts off as one thing and goes into all these different tones and you (taps wrist) come on guys people have lives to live.

While it may not capture the imaginations of those still-uninitiated to the "Hunger Games" phenomenon, "Catching Fire" will at least entertain those looking for an emotional punch with their holiday action experience.

If you go to Wikipedia and type in 'summer blockbuster', this is the movie that should come up. It is everything that you need in a summer film. It kicks the season off perfectly and you will feel like a little kid again.
There's some laughs in this movie, there's some action, but halfway through this movie it just takes this weird turn, and you're like 'what happened to all the fun that I was having in this theater?'
This movie is not horrendous and judging from the trailers we've seen, I guess that's a win?

Nobody's waddling into this theater by accident. You need to walk into this theater expecting to see a bunch of babies, some pregnant chicks, a bunch of clueless dudes and when you do that, you kind of have fun because it's not a bad movie.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I don't blame the acting, I blame the directing. Obviously from watchig the trailers you know something has happened as a result of the nuclear incident and the explanation for what is just 'eh...blah...who cares?

Just like Spiderman, when this movie runs into a dead end, it gets itself out very quickly. I enjoyed being totally immersed in this world. If they want to take their time telling the story it's cool with me because I loved watching this movie.
I think you're invested in this movie from the moment it starts. It is a little inconsistent but overall I had fun with it. But no, Kristen Stewart is not fairer than Charlize Theron. FAN TA SY
It's just not good it's bland, it's dull. You would think you'd have an interesting story after all these years, think again. The aliens in this movie make Alf look like James Bond

Maybe we came from someone else, maybe we are just living in a giant petri dish, who knows? I had a great time in the theater, I was in this world, and I find myself afterwards asking questions, what more do you want out of a movie than that?

Let's talk about Sandler, because he's doing a character here. You wonder is it gonna be a Little Nicky thing, Jack and Jill, where it gets annoying? No, I laughed and never got sick of this character.

It falls into a lot of the same pitfalls that the music of this era did; it starts out fun, catchy, and has a great hook, but then it gets full of itself, bloated, difficult to work with, and by the time it realizes it made a mistake, the magic is gone.
This was not the story that I was expecting or hoping for. Without giving anything away, bears figure prominently into this, more so than I would have liked. And I'm a fan of bears.

This movie is even sillier than I thought it would be. You talk about shark-jumping, fridge-nuking. I have a new one for you, horse leaping! Once that happens, that's when it goes off the rails and begins it's descent into Movie Hell

It's grounded, it's real the entire time and that's a testament to the cast. Chris Pine has really impressed me. Let's forget about This Means War, because I'm pretty sure eveyone else in the general public has so he gets a pass.

Whether you have kids, will never have kids, have to take your nephews, your nieces, or some random kid, you're gonna be able to get though this movie. There is a lot of fun stuff in here for everyone.
The effects and make-up stand out, and some of the action sequences packed a punch, but the film was just too dull and predictable to help it rise above the January heap.
It felt stale, repetitive and I knew everything that was coming. Very disappointing because I love baseball!

I always root for these kids like this. You want them to fit in and have a good experience. It's what this movie does to you; it's so full of life and spirit but it can also get real dark in places. A lot like going on a date with Mark Ellis.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film seemed to want to put too much suspense and mystery into a story that just didn't have it; but I'll never complain for too long about being able to believe I'm actually watching Alfred Hitchcock at work.
From bottom of my heart thank you. And thank you to Bella, Edward and Jacob for letting us laugh, cry, debate, and pick sides while you three bastards stare at each other.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Killing Them Soflty" will hold you in it's desperate grip, and ensure that you leave happy about whatever line of work you chose to pursue (killers excluded).
It's an insult to an audience that is desperately trying to suspend disbelief.
Overall this film did make me laugh and briefly contemplate my future, I only wish it could have maintained it's focus on sweetness and humor the rest of the time.
This is a slow, niche film, but Murray delivers an award-caliber performance and for the right crowd, this is a worthy investment.
"Deadfall" ends up being little more a really good Lifetime Movie of the Week.
Modern technology can have a soul as it turns out; provided it is in the capable hands of a man telling a story in which we can somehow see a reflection of ourselves.
One of my favorites of the year, "Zero Dark Thirty" is a unique film experience that should not be missed.
Regardless of the frames, dimensions, or goggles used to conjure it, "The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey" is an incredible ride and a triumphant return to Middle Earth.
While it may be a landmark for musical lovers, proves that this genre of film may be the hardest to cross over to the rest of us.
It's not "Rocky" and it's not "Caddyshack", but "The Hammer" was a pleasant surprise and is a welcome addition to the all-too-small list of reliable sports comedies.
Robert Patrick has fun in a supporting role, but Emma Stone's talents are wasted on a nothing female-bargaining-chip character.
Leatherface is the smartest one in this picture: he's the only one with the good sense to cover up his face so no one will know he was involved in this putrid waste of time.
The fear is that this would be a farewell tour, but Arnold was so good in a film that knew exactly what it was, so I can get excited about more action films starring Arnold.

The performances are fine, the effects believably chilling, and the suspense creeps up in a perfectly paced scarefest that thankfully proves that the horror genre still works (as long as the chainsaws stay put).

The violence, the humor, the strong language all adds up to deliver on the considerable hype that goes when a celebrated director takes on an ambitious project. Here's to your thin red line, Mr. Tarantino...we're happy to step over!
We get emotionally attached to these guys and we're rooting for them to take down this cartel.. or at least survive until the end of watch. Eh? See what I did there?
It's not often that a movie can affect you and make you laugh out loud all at once, but "Silver Linings Playbook" coordinates the task with ease.
Some may have cried "the sky is falling" after witnessing "Quantum of Solace"; fear not, dear moviegoers: "Skyfall" places the Bond franchise squarely back at the top of the action film stratosphere!

This felt like watching the US blow the Ryder Cup. Everything that could go wrong did, anytime there was a chance to make a play it failed, and the participants looked like they really didn't give a shit.
Kids will love it but adults will get the nods, great combo.
As far as college comedies go, it ain't quite Animal House but I laughed more than I thought I would.
It combines found footage with traditional moviemaking. Producer Jason Blum and director Scott Derrickson, these dudes love making us pee ourselves watching bad stuff happen to people on screen.
Sometimes time travel is just used a cheap device in movies to make them seem different; this is not one of those films. It's genuinely unique and fresh.

You know when a get a burrito at Qdoba or Chiptole and they put too much deliciousness in there and you try to eat it and it just falls into a mess? Kinda like this movie. It's a burrito that should've been double wrapped.
There is plenty of action, not the fist-fighting kind, but it's such an engrossing story that you're on the edge of your seat the entire movie.

It's not the fast-paced war film some might have expected given the director's history, but "Lincoln" instead triumphs as the definitive portrayal of a man working towards what we would consider one of his finest hours in his too-short life.

This movie was that it felt like a comedian on stage who doesn't give a shit about the audience and if they're getting laughs when the audiences thinks they should. It's a refreshing attitude that I enjoyed but also at times left me a little cold.
It's the franchise where families get terrorized, webcams set-up and it's got one crazy demon that can't get enough of being on camera.
What's really a kick to the nether-region is that the story is so bad that you never really get a chance to admire or dislike any of the acting.

For true-true, we won't bother trying to explain the plot, but some of these stories are more musical, some religious, and others just about survival, but there's threads that weave their way into all of them. The peformances are good...I think.
Whenever a film surprises you by taking you on a different path that you were expecting AND manages to surpass those expectations, it is worthy of praise.
It was such a great time at the cinema; I was expecting to like it and I ended up falling in love.
I would rather go to Hell than sit through that movie again.
Chasing Mavericks has an engaging story that is capably acted on land, and only gets more thrilling once it decides to get wet chasing mavericks.

It's a predictable sports movie that for me would be a 2.5, but the performance of Kevin James is so good that I want to see him in more stuff now, so I can feel good about getting this to 3/5 Schmoes.

This holiday season it's Vince Vaughn who stretches his abilities to a new limit; and while the result may not be the funniest or most touching film to come along, it will at least bring in everyone in your family for a couple of hours.
The next step in the promising careers of Brit Marling and Zal Batmanglij: you'll enjoy the ride, think about it's themes...and then want to get a shower.

Dench and co-writer Steve Coogan share a fabulous chemistry on screen; they can ride waves of dialogue that take them from seemingly insignificant topics into questioning the existence of God and back again.
Much like Edgar Wright's recent flicks, we get to see both comedy and action in equal doses...it proves the worth of it's stars, and showcases a bright future for director Feig.
It won't convert any scary movie detractors, but should serve up enough creeps to satisfy it's fanbase.
Director Alfonso Gomez-Rejon has crafted a masterful film out of Jesse Andrews' novel/screenplay
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A great surprise and a documentary that should get consideration from movie fans and racinf enthusiasts alike...after all, this film proves that those sects aren't all that different.
movie_title: Winning: The Racing Life Of Paul Newman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This movie is ridiculous to begin with; the laughs hit you hard and often with lines that will offend andyone and everyone. It's last quarter slows it down for sure, but "Ted 2" is still one of the comedy highlights of the year.

The tie-ins with the MCU are abundant but we never feel like "Ant-Man" is leaning on it's big brothers too much; as a stand-alone movie this is the very reason I go to the theater at all: great action, big laughs and entertaining as hell.
Not for everyone, but "Irrational Man" might just surprise viewers not expecting to care.
It's a fun ride and fans of the show will want to keep coming back for more.

The film gets long in the tooth and it's ambition to be both dirty and touching spreads a solid story a little thin...but "Trainwreck" has so much in it to like, not the least of which is the future potential of more Amy Schumer/Judd Apatow collaborations.
Once again, Cruise accepts this mission with open arms and audiences everywhere should follow suit.
Too often this version feels like a bunch of sketches cobbled together and united by their love of dirty punchlines.

He might have a long way to go to win back the throngs of supporters that once lined his gallery but with "The Visit", he's at least back to showing us why we rooted for him in the first place. Nice birdie, M!

"Hotel Transylvania 2" isn't anything particularly new or ground-breaking...but it certainly can be a fun family experience during Halloween. Just remember to show the kids "Young Frankenstein" immediately after.
The film itself ends up feeling more like a soap opera than anything else, but that shouldn't take away from the performances.
Insightful, funny and powerful...and the actual test-footage featuring Cage as the man of steel is remarkable
movie_title: The Death of Superman Lives: What Happened? (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a conventional film and is anything but a biopic...but once you buckle in for this ride, it will be one you won't forget anytime soon.

Director Antoine Fuqua throws every boxing/sports film trope he has at us, and after a while it does feel used...but the emotion is thick enough and the boxing scenes so well executed that much of the story's ease can be forgiven.
It's one of the most daunting and original ideas that Pixar has ever tackled, and they simply crushed it. Nothing but joy for "Inside Out".
The Avengers, Mad Max and Tom Cruise suddenly have some jurassic-sized competition for the most fun ride at the movies this summer...thanks Dr. Hammond!
"Pitch Perfect 2" is entertaining for sure, it's just not as good as it's freshman year.
It's an inspirational story for sure, but the film never quite shifts into third gear even as we care about Zamperini the entire time.
Musicals are made to enchant and help us sing the blues away...and for that, I'd recommend the original "Annie". You're only a day away...
If this fanchise plans on being the "Saw" of Valentine's Day, I hope the next installment doesn't torture the audience so much.

Occasionally director Matthew Vaughn likes to show us just how crazy-violent his imagination can get, and not every frame of those scenes is necessary but it's a small price to pay for such pure escapist entertainment as this.
Never boring but not all that engaging, "Focus" proves that Will Smith still has all the charisma he ever did. Unfortunately, that's not enough to distract us from a mediocre flick.
It will make you want to sign up for a 5K immediately after...hopefully you have the endurance to finish. Or Bull Durham as your coach...

This is a huge disappointment considering the ability that Blomkamp has; it's one bad film and I won't overreact...but fans of the "Alien" franchise that he has been taksed to revive might just want to stick with "District 9" and "Elysium".
Holy crap "Mad Max: Fury Road" rocks! Oh what a lovely day indeed!
"Unfinished Business" is a major let-down and proof that even someone of Vince Vaughn's ability and stature needs help behind the camera to make us love him again.
I love those tunes and could hear them all day; but too often "Danny Collins" commits the sin the star is trying to avoid: relying on someone else's music to get it's point across.
You won't feel like you wasted your money, but you'll probably think of something better you could have spent it on. Like a "Hunger Games" book.
By the time we get to the laughable climax the film has lost any pulse it had, and "The Gunman" ends up being a major let-down.
"Avengers: Age of Ultron" lives up to the hype...it gets darker than the first, and still manages to be just as funny and action-packed.
Harrison Ford himself shows up and doesn't disappoint; although the third act of the film lost it's way a tad.

Even as a heterosexual man, I couldn't stand watching these two for much more than an hour: I excused myself to the bathroom and never looked back. In the immortal words of Dean Wormer, "Mr. Blutarsky...zero...point...zero".
First-time director Henry Hobson crafts a small film with a slow but sure pace that managaes to surprise and satisfy at the same time.
Succeeds as a riveting historical drama that features winning performances and first-rate direction.
"Into the Woods" gets long in the tooth suddenly, and some audience members will find themselves getting restless as the run time allows for too many unnecessary subplots

I loved this movie not just as a American or as a military brat; it's a stunningly well-made portrayal of the horrors of war and a study of the bravery it takes to finish the job. I bet Transformers 5 still is atrocious.

movie_review_blurb: Holds up as an action-packed western thrill ride that serves up a phenomenal climactic showdown.
I went for the great dialogue and the interesting story, [but] the performances I got out of this were a cut above even what I thought I could get.
Saoirse Ronan is a threat to win a statue everytime she's on screen and her performance in [Lady Bird] is just another step.
Another home run for possibly the greatest director of all time.
For Gary Oldman to embody that, when we already know the audio of the real man's voice, I thought it was just a magnificant performance.

Every little side or subplot that this movie takes, whether it involves Miguel or someone else in his family or just some seemingly ancillary characters, it pays off so richly, so beautiful, from start to finish.

I didn't know that [Henson] had this ability in her and that was one of the highlights of the movie that overall I didn't think was was great or even necessarily very good but I enjoyed watching her in the movie so much.
Watching the gang and actually the genius of the gang implementing their various plans was one of the appeals to the movie to me.
It didn't live up to what I thought it could hold, but the performances certainly [did]. I think Margot Robbie is looking at an Oscar nomination.

I love the way the animation looks, I think it meshed well with the live action.
Even if they were the best actors in the world, the movie leading up to [the act] is just this thing. It just happens.
It's something different that I haven't seen a lot of.
[Jesse] Plemons steals his scenes, if not the movie.
Ninja Turtles, you made me happy, you just didn't make a good movie.

... we get action sequence after action sequence...

Both a heartwarming and heartwrenching tale of love, loss and discovery that could be my favorite film of the year. Timothee Chalamet, Armie Hammer and Michael Stuhlbarg give award-caliber performances in a film that is an important as it is beautiful.

David Yates directs a movie that is entertaining but never garners all that much excitement, and it's an emotional flatline for the bulk of the film.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's an absolute triumph.

Patriots Day is not only one of the most important films of the year...it's one of the best of 2016.
One of the great rivalries in racing history is depicted in explosive detail with The 24 Hour War.

The perfectly paced new entry to our galaxy far, far away features so many new Star Wars moments to love...a journey full of classic hallmarks and new additions that maintains a balance of lighthearted fun, intense action and deep emotion.
It's an uplifting cinematic experience that virtually anyone can enjoy, all while learning a story that deserved to be told.
As much as we all want to trust Tom Hanks calmly holding a coffee mug, The Circle suggests otherwise. Audiences should be equally wary of the movie itself.
Showcasing the flaws and merits of the this lovable vehicle that has become a community unto itself, The Bug succeeds in being a vehicle documentary that can engage even the non-car enthusiast.
Overall Guardians Vol. 2 is a worthy entry in this franchise and in Marvel's cinematic orbit.
The best DC film since The Dark Knight.
It Comes At Night is a well-crafted examination of the human condition.
Justice League is a thoroughly enjoyable unification of superheroes that moves at a thrilling pace.
One of the best movies of the year sees a finely crafted work of imagination from a true master in Guillermo del Toro... it's a triumph of human spirit that isn't necessarily limited to human beings.
It's classic Shyamalan... and given his former heights, that's an impressive achievement.
I wept for for Teddy Roosevelt, Mr. Robin Williams. In one of his last screen appearances, there's moments when it feels as though he's saying goodbye to us.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It never gets fun. It's a dull ride for me. It actually felt like I was a commuter on a train.

movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Russell has created another film that is a joy to watch from beginning to end; he uses his considerable talent stockpile in front of the camera to weave a story that is funny, dramatic, and laughs at itself all at once.

movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Deadpool is like Die Hard with Bruce Willis' character David Addison from his TV series Moonlighting, if he wore a mask & cursed more... It's silly, swaggering, & obscene, but I mean all of those words in the best possible way.

Whimsical yet mature, fantastically magical yet full of realistic emotions and a simple, earthly plea for redemption, it goes beyond childish notions of resolution and "victory" toward a far more moving and poetic destination.
Hell or High Water is one of the great modern westerns... the sort of substantive food for the soul we all need to experience.
[F]ails to get to deeper ideas and truths that are ripe for exploration in precisely a film of this nature, and it winds up almost a caricature of the very sort of film it tries to emulate.
Pete's Dragon is an excellent entry in Disney's catalog of live-action remakes... [A]s American folktales go, it's the best I've heard in a long, long time.

With so much going for it, including being adapted from a best-selling children's book, it was a real surprise to me that the film overall was unsatisfying. The whole wound up being less than the sum of its parts...

[It] moves from one big action set piece to another, propelled by old-fashioned action-adventure sequences that are the stuff of solid summer popcorn fun... a rousing good story with thrills & laughs.

[T]akes the superhero genre in a new direction, letting the bad guys be bad guys even while they're forced into service for supposed "good." It's crowd-pleasing genre entertainment with delightful performances, [and] eye-popping visuals...
Shane Black's best work yet... a smart, funny, sexy action movie... You can tell Black would be happy making films like this for the rest of his life -- and we should be so luck.
[A] film with much promise that it cannot quite live up to... [B]etter than Origins, better than The Last Stand, & actually almost (but not quite) on par with the first X-Men outing...
[Y]ou're going to laugh, and laugh a lot. Keanu has heart in the form of Peele and Key, and in form of a cute kitten worth all the trouble the two men endure to rescue him.
Emotional impact winds up victim to brisk pace and a desire to hurry and show us some other weird behavior by Elvis to get a laugh.
[T]he best Marvel yet, with the greatest superhero action on film. It's immense, marvelous action-packed fun... [T]he single greatest pure superhero movie ever made.
The Conjuring 2 fail[s] to live up to its excellent predecessor... a horror movie should never, ever cause me to laugh when it's trying to scare me or attempting a serious emotional moment.
[A] remarkable film achievement. It's visually breathtaking, emotionally thrilling... [T]he best Disney live action adaptation...
70 percent portrait of a disease/30 percent family drama, recommended as preparation/demystification for Alzheimer's-affected families, and for fans of both Moore and Stewart.
Margot Robbie's the only reason to see this film. She's an Australian Emma Stone, with a wide comedic/dramatic range, and charisma for days. She's going to be around a while.
'Tomorrowland's' an 'addiction of geography' utopia movie, allowing us fantasies of exploiting resources on other planets since we've already hoovered up everything down here.
Sarah Connor's taught Schwarzenegger's T-800 to smile. Maybe it looked good on paper. Never warm up a terminator. If it's not deadly, it's in danger of becoming a goofball.
Glaciers didn't go through this area, so there's no drift (silt, clay, sand, gravel, and boulders). So the area is therefore driftless. That's very interesting. To geologists.
'The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel' is indeed second-best. The element of surprise is long gone, the love's gone a bit stale, and Sonny talks too much. But he dances well!
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's an R-rated comedy due to the Germany factor. Germany has endless co-ed nudist possibilities. These are the R-rated parts. So where are the comedy parts? We're not sure.
Think 'Nurse Jackie' reincarnated as a lawyer. The blatant Oscar-bid timing reduces the effectiveness of Aniston's performance rather a lot. It manufactures high expectations.
It should have been a Jason Bourne flick. Instead, it's sort of a poor man's version, so try not to think too hard about that, or the whole thing will turn mildly ridiculous.
Some casting decisions should never happen-Shaq as Tinkerbell-hmm... actually that might be fantastic, scratch that. But Mark Wahlberg as a professor of literature? Just no.
Scott Eastwood's less mysterious than dad. Clint's got more warrior, Scott's got more lover. Nevertheless! Scott's very Clinty! 'Ride's' the anti-'Fifty Shades of Grey.'
Re-title it 'The Bong Identity;' an over the top, silly grind-house-level violent spy-spoof, played very earnestly by Eisenberg and Stewart to surprisingly good comic effect.
You may discover hearing songs that normally provoke in you a knee-jerk flailing at whatever source is playing them ('Turn it off!!!') will here make you feel strangely happy.
The only foreseeable problem with this movie is that parents are going to have to be dealing with wee ones mimicking minion-ese for as long as this franchise shall flourish.
'We Are Your Friends' is a big-screen soap opera-all beautiful people, all the time, who wear very small bathing suits, and jump up and down near swimming pools to 128 bpm.
Stomach-turning 3-D puts you right over the black, bottomless crevasses on a shaky metal ladder. You may wish (like some of the climbers) that you hadn't come on this trip.
Women can't teach boys to become men, so the reformed assassin has become the potential (movie) ticket to seeing a satisfactorily performed forging of a boy into a real man.
One forgets tweens have choir practice and like to unabashedly break out into song. They think this is normal. It's very cute. Bad for dads; I give 'Jem' three tween stars.
A movie of note in this political jousting time of The Donald versus everybody else. Campaigns are showbiz; hair and makeup. Orange hair can give you an edge in the polls.
Mexican-born filmmaker Patricia Riggen makes the telling of this complicated true story of the 2010 Chilean San José Mine shaft collapse look easy. And, well ... fun!
I personally object to kitschy, green, Mickey-D type plastic toys in a Sam Peckinpah type western setting, but the bottom line is, it's quite a good small-child film.
'Tumbledown' is not-quite-a-humdinger about a dead folk singer, featuring funnyman Jason Sudeikis as a surprisingly effective romantic lead, and as such-it's right nice.
John Hillcoat makes manly movies. 'Triple 9' is a masculine motion-picture for men, at the multi-plex-more so in the man-cave. Don't spend the moolah; wait for it on Netflix.
Angelina Jolie has already proven she's a serious director. 'Unbroken' shows possibilities of her blossoming into a filmmaker of real significance.
Hawke's good in the role, but a more interesting casting choice would have been Josh Brolin, who's got more of Baker's tiny nose and power jaw, as well as more mimicry talent.
'Stray Dog' is a stark, insightful portrayal of U.S. biker culture that overlaps with trailer-park culture, veteran, gun, NASCAR, hunting, mountain, tattoo, and beard culture.
Either Franco thinks his every creative whim doesn't stink, and we should be delighted to sample all his artistic endeavors, or he's a selfless, mentoring, caring teacher.
In a spy flick, we want to see action. We want to see Jason Bourne jumping off a roof. We want tension, not realism-not smoking and meetings and yakking.
This movie can babysit your kids! And as the reviewer often recommends in regards to movies such as this, a good adult nap in a cineplex is an awesome thing.
'The Book Thief' mixes British actors using German accents, a few German actors, and the occasional German word, creating a playfully successful illusion of German-ness.
Olive Oyl once sang a love song about Bluto. The refrain was, 'He's... laaaarge.' And there you have Godzilla in a nutshell. He's large, and the movie's largely a crashing bore.
Yes, it's a Marvel cartoon, but don't underestimate this very entertaining summer blockbuster's ability to shift our collective consciousness. It can tinker with your dogma.
Neil Patrick Harris owns the movie's funniest scene, involving not one, but two bowler hats and no relief in sight.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Round and round we go, waiting for Tom Cruise to sprint through enough time-loop cycles to figure out how to kiss Emily Blunt amid the tarantula aliens. Very exciting!
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like 'Saturday Night Fever,' 'Jersey Boys' is also about four Italian-American youths from the outer boroughs. Both films have hits that are still in America's jukeboxes.
The elements of a Transformer movie: cool machinery, a long-legged jail-bait female of stunning visage, cornfields/sunsets; witty dialog: 'Dude, she's an evil jock-concubine.'
'Boyhood' is to coming-of-age movies what 'Act of Valor' is to war movies. 'Valor' used active-duty Navy SEALs, and 'Boyhood' films the same boy over a period of 12 years.
Surf frolic! Group hug! Bonding! Brosnan was a low-on-the-totem-pole James Bond, but we'll take that Bond over this bonding. Brosnan meanders insincerely through the material.
As of yet, we have no science on reincarnation, but the science fiction is definitely getting warmer.
It's slightly wince-worthy that lesser talents are funnier than Rob Reiner these days. He needs to get the eye of the tiger back or hang up the gloves and throw in the towel.
Shouldn't a film about religious tolerance be showing us a man living by example? Instead, we get an image of a bloody, gun-holding hand wrapped in rosary beads. Nice!
In the Roaring Twenties, séances and swindling mediums were rampant, and their debunking, by magician Harry Houdini, was an event of interest. This is a fun movie about that.
Prof. Norman (Freeman) says we use 10 percent of our brains. Dolphins, at 20 percent, evolved bio-sonar so sophisticated science can't match it. Watch Lucy evolve 100 percent.
Ultimately the movie's message is that community is sacred, all God's children should be cared for, and the destitute need a human net to save them from descent into madness.
Originally, theater consisted of mystery dramas and church services. Now we have horror, slasher films, and pornography. These do not uplift humanity. But 'Son of God' tries.
Anna Kendrick as a floundering, career-clueless, alcoholic, irresponsible moocher? Just no. She manages to make it work, sort of. Kendrick's magnetic, whatever she attempts.
Michael Bay, using Megan Fox as bait, hit pay dirt with "Transformers." Now they've made a nice amusement park thrill-ride with 2014's 'Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles' re-tread.
How wrong can you go shooting in the south of France? Or shooting Helen Mirren? Not with a gun. She can turn 103 and she'll still be alluring, even when she's being haughty.
It's the rare, current kid movie made with real actors. Unfortunately, it's not remotely adult-funny. That's OK. Parents suffer. It's what they do. Go and suffer for the kids.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Can we fly a spaceship through a galactic wormhole to Saturn? We haven't even put a man on Mars yet! It's another 342,077,666.43 miles from Mars to Saturn! Fuggeddaboudit!
A fair portion of Tommy Lee's life has been dedicated to telling stories about schlepping variously incapacitated or dead people long distances through the Wild West.
Jason Ritter's the best thing about the film, genuinely funny as a vapid but well-meaning fool-actor. His hysterically crying, post-sex monologues are hilarious.
Considering the 'Hunger Games'' teen demographic, a somber, dark, political drama/grimy-bunker flick would seem guaranteed to adversely affect the holy Hollywood bottom line.
It's 'Pulp Fiction' lite with blaxploitation aspects. Regardless, a movie about beating addictions, getting more out of life, and being a better person, is a good thing.
Costner holds it all together. While he's always been supremely watchable, as his looks succumb to middle-age spread-his acting chops have escalated.
Maybe... 'neo-grindhouse' has become a 'genre' because Tarantino's Midas touch turned grindhouse into ... art? Grindhouse sort of sounds like 'art house.' On the other hand-nah.
Blackbeard shouts, 'You shall be rewarded with confectionary!' Kids love confectionary more than life. That doesn't mean it's good for them. 'Pan' is cinematic confectionary.
Every time you want to hoot and dismiss this movie, the next moment it grabs you. Guilty pleasure. Good storytelling. Lurve. Gugu Mbatha-Raw. A star is born.
The gift of seeing 'Amy' is to witness such a blindingly bright talent, and to realize you don't ever want to be that famous.
How is dating in India different from dating in America? Indian culture is roughly 11,000 years old; ours-239 years. Dating is hilariously, eye-openingly different in India.
While 'Short' leaves dir. McKay a short step from true cinematic gravitas, it's possible he's just getting warmed up, and his wife will someday say, 'Adam, I never knew thee!'
Real-life ER doctors crafted this superb documentary as a cry for help. Our U.S. healthcare system is about to break down. 'Code Black' stands for an overflowing waiting room.
As prodigious a talent as Prince was, he only altered the funk. The megalithic, trail-blazing talent of James Brown birthed it. And Chadwick Boseman nails the telling of it.
We don't know what 'Are You Here' means, but we do know Owen Wilson is Steve Dallas, a weatherman. Or maybe a weatherman-ish boy. Or weatherboy-ish man. He needs to grow up.
Die-hard fans insist no new 'Jurassic' movie could ever touch the original. Oh yeah? Come again? 'Jurassic World' just completely blew the doors off 'Jurassic Park.'
'Sicario' is 'Traffic' on steroids; lots of bad cartel hombres. The FBI's naïve, the CIA's hydrochloric acid-cynical, Delta Force is brutal. Dude film with a killer cast-fun!
'U.S. Navy SEALS in combat are far more than anything Hollywood could ever write,' said co-director Mike McCoy. The real SEALS in 'Act of Valor' demonstrate this to be true.
Kyle killed two men, as a civilian, with his massive Colt .44 Magnum. That's a 'Dirty Harry' gun. Who directed 'American Sniper'? Dirty Harry did. That's terribly ironic.
Drinkable water will turn toxic in the near future, globally. Genius inventor of the Segway builds a water purifier like nothing you've seen before. 'Slingshot' brings hope.
The 24 Bond films sugarcoat a profession that really boils down to a whole lot of breaking-and-entering, snooping, and cold-blooded murder. This one's still decent though.
With new solar panels, a woman sees her energy bill go from $80 to $5. 'I'm not havin' to pay nothin'!' High time we had an exciting documentary about climate change!
This movie is comedic gold; brilliant acting by all-Amy Schumer, Bill Hader, and Lebron James shine. A sure (R-rated) crowd pleaser. Keep kids under 14 at home.
The little red-haired girl explains, that in the trying, she recognized Charlie Brown did kind, compassionate, truthful, and tolerant things. This is pure gold for children.
A cynical cherry-picked mish-mash of China's spiritual treasures for Hollywood's bottom line, rather than the sincere children's bedtime story it should be? It's still good.
What is the Force, and Jedi-ism? In Star Wars, it refers to the ability of a high-level martial-artist-knight to use supernormal abilities. Science has proven 6 of them.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Shock-value use of the 'N-word' was how QT made his bones in Hollywood. 'Hateful' is the culmination of a body of work engineered to liberate the N-word from PC-lockdown.
The Revenant demonstrates, definitively, why seeking enlightenment and never having to reincarnate on earth again-is a fabulous idea! It's also one of the year's best films.
The real, actual apocalypse may be happening right now! 'Apocalypse' the movie ... not so much.
'Creed's' the kind of gritty, cozy, workaday tale we love in America, with more than a little in common with the hugely popular, also Philly-based MMA fight-film, 'Warrior.'
'Why am I crying at the awesomeness of this fight?' Because it's art. Martial arts produce the same response as that 'Marriage of Figaro' aria in 'The Shawshank Redemption.'
Will film professors laud it as an example of exquisite filmmaking? No. Will there be scuffed DVD's of it in Navy SEAL, Delta Force, and Marine lockers? Youbetchabygolly yes.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A fast, funny, freak-flag-flying, four-letter-word-filled flick, making fun of the formulaic franchise and featuring Spider-Man's punk cousin, Deadpool (not his real cousin).
You know ... it's not great, this one. Aesthetically, it's complacent. It'd be nice to see a film honoring the original illustration by W. W. Denslow of the first 'Oz' books.
Pacquiao's the only boxer in history to win championships across eight weight classes. His story follows the classic Hero's Journey stages precisely, blow-by-blow, as it were.
See this film. Pay homage to the healing truth. A landmark film; would that it could reduce the lag time between genocides and our real-time grasp of their horrifying reality.
Part of what makes 'Eddie' work is director Fletcher putting perspective on these shock-and-awe-inspiring ramps, showing us just how Achtung! Verboten! dangerous the sport is.
While 'Burnt' is totally predictable, and the terms 'slick' and 'feel-good' definitely apply, it'll still hold your attention.
Sacha Baron Cohen at Harvard, as character Ali G: 'Some of you has probably never even seen a black man before, like that great civil rights leader, Martin Luther Vandross...'
'Supremacy' might function as a 'Clockwork Orange' type therapy for death-row white supremacists.
Now that the old-school Bond archetype is back, we find we've missed it. No one does debonair gentleman spies better than the Brits.
Always fun to see how high school gets techno-updated. The phone-and-social-media insanity portrayed here makes the beepers of 1995's 'Clueless' look like trilobite fossils.
Generation Y pays tribute to some kind of romanticized, analog echt-ness while being profoundly, scarily (often hypocritically) in virtuoso command of all things digital.
Dom's various vehicles are vehemently put through the wringer in the engine-block-destroying 'Furious 7.' It's like banging your head between two trash can lids, except fun!
The Civil War was about the South not wanting to give up its slaves. Now it won't give up its drugs. 'Rednecks and drugs: one of the worst hookups of the '60s.'
John Long, a brilliant climbing-literature author of Anker's generation, explains the addiction of extreme alpinism as going to a place where you know you're already dead.
One feels instantaneously cracked across the head, as if by dojo stick-warning from all this cinematic artistry, the degree of which is rarely seen in film these days.
If 'Lethal Weapon' and 'Midnight Run' were billiard balls, Kormákur's directing is the cue ball hitting those two and smacking '2 Guns' straight in the corner pocket. Classic.
The screening audience was apparently just as dumb as this reviewer, because when 'Non-Stop' stopped at its ridiculous CGI deus ex machina finale-everyone cheered and clapped.
'Survivor' has a 'you are there' feeling; sound-barrier-breaking rounds, RPG explosions, and Navy SEAL-scripting of real firefight lingo: 'Left is not good! Right is good!'
'Labor Day' is an example of why, when the world self-destructs, all that will be left is cockroaches, and romance novels. And Keith Richards. Okay, never mind that last one.
The film makes a good point-often those zealously caring about dead deer enough to dynamite a dam are hyper-focused to the point of oddly lacking compassion for fellow humans.
Modern hiking is a secular cousin of the pilgrimage; it heals through hardship, loneliness, silence, and beauty. The very fine 'Wild' depicts one woman's inner transformation.
Girls memorize the lines! But it's not a 'Rocky Horror' type cultural event; it's a lukewarm soft-core-porn soap opera-basically 'Pretty Woman' with spanking.
There's 'funny-haha,' and 'funny-strange,' but the howler that is 'The Boy Next Door' lands solidly in the category of 'funny-please-just-shoot-me-now.'
'Jupiter Ascending' is a thematic cornucopia of 'Star Wars/Trek/Gate,' 'The Matrix,' 'Predator,' 'Wolf,' even 'Turbo' (the snail cartoon), and at least seven more.
You've simply never seen such flat-out bad acting from Jeff Bridges. It almost feels like a dare: 'Let me just see how bad I can be, without anyone calling me on it.'
You've got walking in grass, riding a horse through grass, and sitting amid the grass. A few grisly kills. But mostly there's grass. And it grows. Green. Sometimes yellow.
It would be a drastic understatement to say that one never manages to care about any of these characters.
Ferris Bueller said it best: 'Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it.' 'Paper Towns' reminds us not to miss our life.

As mentioned, Cruise has always been an underrated actor due to pretty-boy looks, but his ever-so-slightly supernormal energy and intensity make him perfect for what has now become his signature movie role.
It all ends up sounding a bit like The Matrix's Agent Smith doing Roger Moore doing James Bond.
Movies like 'Truth' tend to be highly politically charged and have complicated backgrounds. Regarding 'Rather-gate,' it's likely that multiple cases of strategery abound.
Cartoon epistemology 101. Kids learn sadness is valid, and joy becomes sad too (bitter-sweetness). It's all good. 'Inside Out' is endearing, inventive, sensitive, and funny.
As a former trainer, the reviewer feels the spider-bod should be rockclimber-ish. All that pulling and hauling should result in some truly epic lats, and Popeye forearms.
Gangs packed military-grade weaponry, the heaviosity of gangsta rap inexorably began transmogrifying the USA into a hip-hop nation, and 'Compton' puts you right there.
Best-ever depictions of artificial intelligence in the movies: the cyborgs and androids of 'Blade Runner.' Transcend 'Transcendence' by watching 'Blade Runner' on Blu-ray.
Cancer's guaranteed to shake your life up. What if you discovered you had a 50/50 chance to live? If your life's stuck in a rut getting cancer can actually be a good thing, and this movie shows why.
'Moneyball' is right on the money, and hilarious. It's humor consists of uniformly understated, impeccably timed deadpan throwaways that come in under the radar and leave the audience roaring.
Emilio Estevez and father Martin Sheen may have made this heartwarming pilgrimage movie with troubled brother/son Charlie in mind-in hopes that he'd see the need for a thorough soul-cleansing.
A well-told tale of filthy politics and betrayal; a virtuoso hat trick (writing, directing, and starring) by George Clooney. It almost makes you wish he'd stop acting and run for office.
Drug movies are a fairly formulaic genre. 'The Infiltrator' has it all, but it can't beat the corpse-and-lye-filled-bathtub-eating-through-the-ceiling corrosiveness of 'Breaking Bad.'

'Martha Marcy May Marlene' is the vehicle with which the youngest Olsen sister moves out of her famous older twin siblings' shadows, and establishes herself as the serious artist of the family. She's magnificent.
'Tower Heist' is a low-rent payback caper involving the staff of the titular high-rent tower. It's Donald Trump's Tower. Oddly, The Donald doesn't have a cameo.
J Edgar Hoover, at least as presented here, was not a particularly interesting or likeable individual. It gets boring quickly.
Director Alexander Payne is a master storyteller of the huge life transition. 'Sideways' is one stellar example, 'About Schmidt', another. 'Descendants' easily rivals 'Sideways.'
'Ghost Protocol' is a stripped-down, lo-fi 'Mission Impossible' that winds the nail biting up to a near-unbearable cliffhanger degree, thanks to Brad Bird's sense of drama and timing.

One of the movie's best teachings is the concept that if one commits to '20 seconds of insane, embarrassing courage,' to attain what one desires, good things always come of it. An instant kid classic.

The first black U.S. fighter pilots rained down bullets on Hitler's Luftwaffe like borax upon cockroaches. A movie finally bringing that fact to light, all these years later, is by definition a good movie.
Director Joe Carnahan says, 'If you're afraid of wild animals or plane travel, this movie will put you off for a good, long time.' Really? One wants to know -- why is that a good thing?
A found-footage film, like 'Blair Witch,' combined with 'Bowling for Columbine.' Instead of witches and guns, it's a teen outcast with supernormal abilities; like 'Carrie' with shaky-cam and cool CG.

The true heart of the film is jovial, red-haired coach Bill. Not having had a father, he passionately gives every fiber of his soul to helping these African American boys, who are also missing fathers.
Fortunately, there were lots of kids at the screening. You gotta watch 'em. They were giggling, singing along, bouncing, and happily kicking the reviewer's seat. Bingo.
Hallström's made a wonderful film about the power of faith. Flyfishing in a manufactured trout stream in the middle of the desert is a faith-based activity, declares the sheik who built it.
You might find it to be thoroughly clichéd and utterly predictable. But it's not boring. That's largely thanks to Guy Pearce.
In what appears to be a possible first career dud, 'Bernie,' billed as a dark comedy starring Jack Black, falls far short of Linklater's normal standard.
The movie is visually sumptuous, the colors vibrant, the indigenous faces arresting, the local customs intriguing, and the soundtrack catchy.
If ever a movie had 'Paid for by the U.S. Navy' written all over it... 'Battleship' is tailored kitsch -- tailored to recruit male teens. Taylor Kitsch does a surprisingly good job of this.
'Moonrise Kingdom' magically recreates a child's-eye view of the early 1960s, bringing back memories of tents, tree houses, campfires, cub scouts, innocence, and first kisses.
What could possibly go wrong with this formula? Threequel-itis, that's what. MIB 1 was great, MIB 2 not so much, MIB 3-just not cuttin' the mustard.
It's a warm-hearted little movie. It may have a ton of Native American cinematic clichés-dream sequences with staccato wooden flutes, soaring eagles, and so on-but it works.
'The Dark Knight Rises' tries to be very dark and serious. The problem is, that rubber-headed costume just looks sort of, well, comical, when things get too realistic.
'Warrior' is secondarily a movie about the world's fastest growing sport, MMA. If you like the fight game, this movie will have you yelling and jumping out of your seat.
Leaner and meaner with a touch of Bruce Lee, the spider suit's finally right: the eyes dangerous, webbing weaponized. Garfield looks more like the illustrated Peter Parker.
Paltrow's bits are among the films creepiest, since, award-winning actress that she is, she's horrifyingly convincing in the throes of advanced symptoms, as well as looking extremely dead.
Momoa doesn't have Arnold's 7-time-Mr.-Olympia-winning muscles, but they're still impressive. Plus he can sort of act. Arnold could sort of act too, but Jason can sort of act better.
Highly recommended for those struggling with belief in spiritual realities.
Former Olympic skier turned high-stakes poker madam tell-all; about the underbelly of Hollywood illegal gambling -- totally riveting.
An insightful, dramatic neo-Western concerning the combinations and permutations of 1800s Caucasian/Native-American racism, and why it's still good to ruminate on it, in 2018.
A foreign director's Lynch-esque/Coen-wannabe POV on a small-town American tragedy, leavened by levity. Vivid and hilarious, it'll encourage you not to take life for granted.
Of all the critics on here, I'm the only one who's actually done/facilitated the work on display in the stunning documentary, "The Work." The movie is phenomenal. The real deal is mind-blowing.

Only The Brave is the forest-fire equivalent of its intensely gripping urban cousin, 1991's Backdraft. It's also educational; full of "So that's how they do that"! moments. Tragic story, satisfying storytelling.
Like liquor-running evolved into NASCAR, Cruise and a jovial script spins Iran-Contra darkness into the wink-wink, boys-will-be-boys rear-view glow we Americans enjoy shining on our culture.
Mitch Rapp books totally rock. American Assassin sucks compared to the books. But can you happily popcorn out to it on a Friday night? Yup. Would you enjoy the books more? Absolutely.
Remember 'In The Line of Fire?' CIA assassin vs. Secret Service agent? This is the haha version of that. Meh on plot and shenanigans, many belly laughs courtesy of Jackson and Reynolds.
Hard to categorize Dunkirk. Grand piece of art? Virtuoso nail-bite fest? It's both. While decidedly nerve-wracking, you'll be glad you went and suffered with the soldiers who saved us from Hitler.

Superb stunt-driving, a sweet romance, a mess of cliché's kaleidoscoped into hot-dang! storytelling, and the only thing missing is Prince's "Baby Knows," and Patrick Swayze's "Nobody puts baby in a corner!"
If "47" did nothing more than be less predictable, it still wouldn't match "The Shallows." And if "The Shallows" had been less predictable, it still wouldn't match "Jaws."

George Clooney once said "[flatulence is] one of the funniest things in the history of mankind," a sentiment shared by children, men, and dogs everywhere. 'Captain Underpants' cheerfully brings the potty humor.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Straight out of the gate, I predict CHIPS will become a perennial mega-hit with the frat-house/sorority set.
An Erin Brockovich-type feel-good biopic about 3 female African-American NASA math-wizard engineers who saved the 1960s Apollo rocket program and contributed to Civil Rights.
'Dr. Strange' is the first Marvel movie to tell the reality-based version of where superpowers come from. Science takes human supernormal abilities seriously now-exciting stuff.
It'll likely become an instantaneous cult-classic for teenage girls -- it's Hailee Steinfeld's 'Clueless.' However, late-millennial high school girls are anything but clueless.
Robbing of banks may be very 1800s, but robbing by banks is very 2010s/post-Occupy. Ergo, robbing robber banks makes for a post-Occupy Western. Pine, Foster, and Bridges kill it.

Never judge a movie by its title. 'Bad Moms' is laugh-till-you-cry hilarious; funniest movie you'll see all summer. Who can raise kids properly nowadays? It's impossible! It's real title? 'Cool Moms.'
To revitalize the franchise, they should knock Bourne upside the head and disappear his memory again. The true fun of 'Bourne' is seeing it all coming back to him, while doing cool stuff.
Tom Hanks's company Playtone appears to be dedicated to making movies where a Beach-Boys-y soundtrack and 1950s Boy Scout values still inform everything. Not necessarily a bad thing -- just cloying.
