movie_review_blurb: A dazzling stylistic exercise, Francis Ford Coppola's Tetro pays tribute to great bygone European filmmakers.

The latest generation of animated flicks is a sort of latter-day vaudeville revue. Kiddies who take Bolt to heart may conclude not only that dogs really do have superpowers, but also that everybody's in showbiz.
A British movie of a well-reviewed German novel about issues both moral and bookish.
Despite occasional attempts at plot and character, this is basically a roast with scenery.
Doesn't make fighting look graceful, easy or fun, and that's a mark of its courage.
24 City includes evocative footage of Factory 420's dismantling, but emphasizes people over place.
Israeli writer-director Ari Folman's powerful, innovative film is composed largely of nightmares, all but the final one rendered in graphic-novel style.
Stylish and effectively creepy, if mostly secondhand.
The high level of craft can't sustain the movie as its script (written by Inarritu with Armando Bo and Nicolas Giacobone) becomes increasingly hectoring.
Director Zack Snyder and his production crew clearly had great fun envisioning this swords-and-corsets fantasy. Few others are likely to approach their level of enjoyment.
There are great filmmakers - Chris Marker and Nanni Moretti come to mind - whose cinematic essays render their first-person musings utterly compelling. Shadyac is not in their league.
Miral plays like an art project that took a wrong turn somewhere between Soho and Ramallah. It seems the Middle East is unstable ground not just for diplomats, but for aesthetes as well.
The broad comedy clashes with the movie's final message.
The filmmakers doesn't sweat the fact that Eddie is a chemically enhanced fraud. What scares them is any possibility of alienating the movie's target audience with a downer ending.
Director Kim Jee-woon is a born filmmaker, even if this script (written by Park Hoon Jung and adapted by Kim) is unworthy of his efforts.
The movie evokes its time and place so potently that it almost doesn't matter that Hamilton's script proves unequal to her vision.
H.G. Wells did it better. This movie spends so much yawn-inducing time on variations of the same combat scenario that its final showdown feels rushed.
Sort of likable, despite Araki's utter lack of interest in charming anyone who isn't already a member of his small following.
Unapologetically episodic, the movie is designed to awe and shock... and to plunge viewers into a world whose fury is half exotic and half typical of any group of unruly adolescents.
Aside from its conclusion, "When We Leave'' is credible and well-observed.
Forget 127 Hours: "Sanctum" makes sawing off your own arm look like a minor penalty for the crime of spelunking while clueless.
Betrayal, sympathy and regret are central to the story, but there's hardly any room for such feelings amid the clockwork carnage.
More skillfully directed than written, "Kalamity'' is competent yet never startling, either artistically or viscerally.
Even at its most lurid, though, the movie is a little dull. And it only gets less compelling as the backstory fills in.
Alas, the Russian filmmaker can only do so much with his American debut's stale premise and lazy plot.
Little Children is intentionally very literary, with narration that sometimes substitutes for dialogue and a symmetrical structure.
The performances are utterly natural, seemingly as offhand as Andrij Parekh's hand-held cinematography.
A routine Hollywood high school morality play.
Slight and unsurprising.

The movie effectively simulates the game's whirl, and should grab all but the most finicky hockey fans. But for moviegoers who think if you've seen one sports flick, you've seen 'em all -- well, you've definitely seen this one.
Desperation is the project's principal quality.
For its first half, Secret Things is a tolerably silly lark ... Yet as Christophe's role expands -- and the soundtrack's classical flourishes become more strident -- the film's plausibility plummets.

It's hard to care whether it's Tad or Pete who wins Rosalee's heart, and Luketic's direction is merely functional. Yet the film is not a chore, mostly because its leading lady makes the not-quite-plausible Rosalee consistently appealing company.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Carries too heavy a burden to succeed as the trifle it really is.
This impeccably structured documentary is a fine introduction to Kahn's work and a consistently entertaining real-life mystery.
For true Kaurismakian austerity, the film to see is the singular Juha, which dispenses with dialogue altogether.
In addition to achieving a paradoxical balance of mirth and melancholy, Drifting Clouds is a dark, mostly interior movie with a color scheme as big as all outdoors.
One of those motley movies that borrows from just about everywhere.
Kiss of the Dragon does have a sense of its own absurdity, but that doesn't prevent it from cloaking the inherently comic kung-fu genre in a seriousness so solemn that it could be French.
An instant antique.
A dull, crudely animated Pokemon byproduct.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Gently charming.
Beneath the family saga and easy digs at the tackiness of Western consumer culture, Becker presents a serious critique of authoritarianism and propaganda.
Should give just about everyone who sees it a few laughs. But it will appeal most strongly to viewers who think Tom Hanks, who plays a thief and a potential murderer, can do no wrong.
Hardly conventional entertainment, but seeing what happens next provides much of the fun in this far-from-academic exercise.
For a film rooted in the director's own experience, The Lost City is surprisingly unilluminating.
Viewers who stick around will be rewarded with a complex, moving domestic drama -- and a couple of duels.
The sort of clumsy undertaking that trips up everyone and everything in it.
Poetic yet efficient, The Return constructs a powerful mood without indulging in brooding, overlong scenes.
Spring, Summer fans should only have their appreciation of that film expanded by seeing this rougher take on similar themes.
An entertaining but somewhat creepy look at the world of competitive Scrabble.
A charming and astute first-person documentary.
Kari may eventually go far, but for now he's one of the less interesting inhabitants of international art cinema's disaffected-youth ghetto.
On their way to confront ancient evil, Strother and Losey keep tripping over timeworn cliches.
Well-made, if rather predictable, new-age melodrama.
Will go anywhere for a gag.
This austere non-narrative should fascinate fashion buffs and fans of rigorous cinematic formalism, but leave everyone else fidgeting restlessly in their mass-market jeans and T-shirts.
movie_title: Yves St. Laurent: His Life and Times (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Provides some wry chuckles, but much of it is as dark as a Glasgow winter.
Nothing in this film makes any sense, and Stuart Blumberg, David T. Wagner and Brent Goldberg's script merely gets more preposterous as it elaborates on its implausible premise.
Rather than the That's Entertainment of jumps, falls and back flips, actor-director Robin Shou's tribute to his former profession is half-baked and a little self-serving.
movie_title: Red Trousers: The Life of the Hong Kong Stuntmen (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The contrast between Schock's discreet approach and the family's stormy differences could have been powerful. But without much of the latter captured on film, Circo feels all too diffident.
A veteran film editor making her first feature, Israel emphasizes the area's low-key beauty.
Although its camera moves are fluid and its art direction elegant, Hanna doesn't travel anyplace unusual. The point of all its battling is just to battle.
A better history lesson than it is a drama.
While Barnes and Sheehan are persuasive as the squabbling siblings, the music-biz mockery is blunt and obvious.
The Rum Diary is too muted to convey the intensity that propelled Thompson past most of the other magazine feature writers of his boozy era.
A contemporary fable set in a place constructed from blocks of French cinematic history, Le Havre is one of Aki Kaurismaki's warmest, most engaging films.
Rather than idealize life in a state of nature, Oka! depicts Bayaka culture as messy and not always admirable, but exuberantly vital.

Luchini, who played the condescending patriarch in Potiche, is very experienced at this sort of thing. He conveys not just the foolish vanity of the middle-aged male, but also moments of genuine empathy, gallantry and hurt.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Enlightening, compelling and, finally, heartbreaking.
movie_title: You Don't Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantanamo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As in his "The Fall," director Tarsem Singh's visual instincts overwhelm his storytelling finesse.
This isn't one of those epics that uses length as a bludgeon. Rather than sweep, the movie spirals, twisting its viewpoint to reveal tales within tales.
Computer-generated imagery is often used to simulate the future in motion pictures, but the ravishing The Mill and the Cross uses it to replicate the past.

Director Alexei Fedorchenko doesn't use sheer duration to immerse viewers in the spiritual journey. Not counting the credits, this beautifully photographed and quietly evocative movie is barely 70 minutes long.
Unlikely to appeal to filmgoers who don't already have a taste for the spectacle and sentimentality of Chinese cinema.
The writer-director tells the story with verve and small-budget ingenuity.
Silly and slapsticky, "Love in Space" is too busy devising absurd set pieces to develop the characters or make their mutual attractions plausible.
Shaolin features a half-dozen impressive action set pieces, including an elaborate carriage chase and a battle inside the cages where Cao imprisons his workers.
Limelight offers a few moderately enlightening interviews and a lot of candy-colored lights.
The Black Power Mixtape includes plenty of interest, but it would be stronger if the filmmakers had dug a little deeper into the footage from 1967 to 1972 and skipped the final years altogether.
If it sometimes seems undercooked, that's an understandable flaw for a movie whose making was utterly illegal.
The Twilight Saga hasn't matured along with its heroine. In fact, the latest movie regresses a bit, delivering more filler, less feeling and crummier CGI than last year's Eclipse.
The African American fliers' great achievement merits a great movie. "Red Tails" isn't it.
In some ways, The Pruitt-Igoe Myth is more elegy than analysis.
movie_title: The Pruitt-igoe Myth: An Urban History (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As the loosely aligned band of survivors turns into a pack of sociopathic loners, the only reasonable conclusion is that they were all pretty rotten to begin with.

You can see where this is going, and the filmmakers can see that you can see. So they rush to the hideous yet hilarious climax in little more than an hour and then pad the running time with the slowest-moving credits ever.
The truth is knotty in Norwegian Wood, deftly adapted by Franco-Vietnamese writer-director Tran Anh Hung from Haruki Murakami's most popular novel.
The stories are horrific, if laced with Tarantino-style humor.
Pulling Garbo's story from Roch's film requires considerable effort. The director takes a cinema verite approach to historical material, which never works, and forgoes narration.
In the Land of Blood and Honey is far from the best movie on this subject made since the war ended -- or even this year.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a modest improvement on bad-boy director Guy Ritchie's first tweaking of Arthur Conan Doyle's iconic detective.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's engrossing, even if it does lack the element of surprise.
A stirring if occasionally over-obvious clash of capital and labor.
It was frantic sex that earned Shame an NC-17 rating, but this arty drama is mostly slow and methodical. And thoroughly unsexy.
A Dangerous Method didn't have to be another Naked Lunch, but Freud plus Jung plus Cronenburg should have equaled something a little more dissonant and troubling.
Williams's Monroe is more vital than anything else. The actress captures Monroe's range of emotions and personae, her shifts from vulnerability to brashness.
The Swedish version was sloppier and trashier, which suited the material. If that movie was more lurid, it also packed more genuine emotion.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The movie keeps its balance better than its leering title might suggest.
It's a campy rampage that runs a few minutes shy of four hours, dooming what otherwise would likely be a bright future as a midnight movie.
Luc Besson has decided to make one for the girls.
Cranky old Godard can be tiresome, but his reactionary radicalism is still illuminated by flashes of brilliance.
Occasionally muddled and always melodramatic, yet it's pictorially compelling, thanks to dramatic locations and exacting art direction.
It's a modest journey, but a satisfying one.
The most dramatic and even lurid of writer-director Jia Zhangke's movies.
The movie's enjoyment derives heavily from surprise, which the script uses both to advance the plot and just for fun.
Darling's fragility was no secret, which gives even the movie's comical moments an underlying poignancy.
While its story is inherently bittersweet, the movie has many charming moments. After all, it's about one smart elephant.
One secret to the Topps' widespread acceptance is in plain sight: their remarkably old-fashioned act.
Since the crux of the tale is a teenager's decision about an unwanted pregnancy, "Lebanon, Pa." can't possibly please everyone. But Hickernell doesn't strain to be provocative.
13 Assassins is reliably entertaining, but ultimately it's too traditional to be a classic.
"The Princess of Montpensier'' features sumptuous costumes, grand vistas and swooning emotions, but it's much too clear-eyed to be a romance.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Using not one but two world wars as backdrops, Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen is an exhilarating kung fu romp.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Fortunately, for both Ozon and the viewer, the title character is played by Catherine Deneuve, who can very nearly carry a film by herself.
Sometimes, it errs on the side of inclusiveness, with banal commentary from gay reality-TV shows. Taking the broad view mostly works, however.
"My Perestroika" is specific to Russia, of course, but the juvenile certainty and conformity it chronicles seem universal.

The Empire State's eminent domain laws are unusually loose, but most of the rest of this story is pertinent far beyond New York. Change a few names and add the next credit bubble, and a Brooklyn-style Battle could be headed to a neighborhood near you.
Neither amusing nor exciting enough to ensure a long-running franchise.
Viewers who require more context may be frustrated, but the movie is always lively, and its loose approach to history suits its impressionistic style.
Circumstance is in many ways an impressive achievement. But its mix of documentary detail and melodramatic plotting ultimately tips toward the latter.
It's a playfully sexy farce that plays like a Gallic "Annie Hall" - if Annie had been as blithe about nudity as Baya is.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The low-budget movie, set during Russia's 2008 invasion of Georgia, is neither innovative nor profound, but it is kinetic, visceral and sometimes moving.
The Hedgehog is not exactly a naturalistic drama, and its winsome charm and annoying contrivance are thoroughly intertwined.

At a mere 83 minutes, 30 Minutes or Less might seem able to deliver on the promise of its zippy title. Instead, this slackers-go-gangsta comedy demonstrates that less than 90 minutes can be a very long time.

The movie fails to make the cross-country jaunt function as a metaphor for the country's mid-century passage. Minus that, the Pranksters' everything-changing adventure looks a lot like just another road trip.
It's telling that the movie, after reaching a tidy payoff, takes one last spin into an epilogue that questions the actuality of almost everything that's come before.
If the movie's mix of nihilistic violence and snarky attitude suggests In Bruges, it's a family resemblance.
Seen now, the movie seems as timely as it is outdated, its themes contemporary even if its clothing and hairdos are anything but.
The glib story and hectoring structure undermine the filmmakers' best intentions.
Quietly astonishing.
Tabloid spins a heck of a yarn, while implicitly warning viewers not to be so entertained that they believe every gamy detail.
Rapaport, a longtime Quest fan, clearly admires Tip. He's just too forthright a storyteller to bury the tale of the quartet's acrimonious unraveling.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While Aurora is a formal triumph, it's less resonant than either 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days or The Death of Mr. Lazarescu.

What does Optimus Prime see in the whiny Sam Witwicky? Why do both the Autobots and Decepticons keep departing Earth, only to reappear a few scenes later? And what is the evolutionary advantage of pretending to be a car, anyway?
The first in a proposed trilogy, "Atlas Shrugged: Part 1" is nearly as stilted, didactic and simplistic as Rand's free-market fable.
This is not a film for purists or quibblers.
The movie depicts the military's culture of intimidation and assault as global, not as an aberration that might be explained by the pressures of combat or the tedium of life on secluded posts.
Kang's Na Young and Tee's Jason have a winning rapport when the script isn't pushing them into contrived shtick.
A candid yet unrevealing documentary ...
Capably recounts the main facts of the case, but doesn't illuminate its darker corners.
Most of the time ... the movie is too busy being saucy or sappy to even look at its target.
movie_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Patriotism and self-interest clash powerfully in "The Age of Shadows," a stylish and morally complex thriller set largely in Japanese-occupied 1920s Seoul.
What gives Command and Control its urgency are both its wealth of information and the implications of its story.

Murphy is fine as the title character, although his performance consists mostly of suppressing all of his usual shtick. He certainly doesn't endow Mr. Church with any unexpected depths. But then neither does the script.
Fila and Klein are equally good in roles that, while more predictable in outcome, benefit from small unexpected moments.
"Blair Witch" runs only eight minutes past the original, yet it feels about a half-hour longer.
For a study of a critic, The Seasons in Quincy is frustratingly uncritical.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mia Madre is most poignant when it finds a tone much like Moretti's 2001 La Stanza del Figlio (The Son's Room). Both movies are gently bewildered meanders through denial, regret, and the beginnings of acceptance.

War Dogs would probably have been more compelling if the filmmakers hadn't strayed so far from the true story. But they manage to slip a fair amount of interesting commentary between the blunders, bong hits and wartime near-misses ...
Florence Foster Jenkins is ultimately a tale of vulnerability, and a tin ear is the least of it.
The actual Operation Chromite was a surprise. In the movie version, you can hear everything coming from miles away.
Sachs' latest is ... warm, subtle, and observant, but feels a little undercooked.
It's comedy, as much as the eerie atmosphere and Tiran's very physical performance, that distinguishes Demon from routine ghost stories.
A rare look at the era through women's eyes.
Creating worlds with images is a form of magic. Miss Hokusai demonstrates that simply, with its extraordinary simulation of sunlight streaming through O'Ei's spread fingers.
The film might have taken a more original route to perdition. You can never guess what wild-eyed prank Schrader will pull next, but his characters are more predictable.
The corn is fertilized by a ponderous score and a handful of bland folkie-rock tunes.
Although The Salesman's plot is unbelievable, most of the movie occurs in a recognizably genuine world: dirty and battered, but bedeviled by compromise and self-interest, not pure evil.

The animators don't overplay the loveliness, preferring subdued colors punctuated by the occasional vivid blue. Red rarely appears, and the many dream sequences are as gray as the night from which they emerge.
In a mostly severe mode, Brandt carries the film well. But there's only so much she can do with the open-ended, underwritten script.
Much of the action is grimly predictable and clearly derivative. It replays bits of Pulp Fiction in a Miller's Crossing setting.
The movie is a charmer, as sweet as it is slow. But even some sympathetic viewers may find it nothing more than an almanac of neat stuff, less dramatized than merely cataloged.

It might seem that Dan Brown takes his art-history/conspiracy thrillers very seriously. Yet there's one clue, hidden in plain sight, that he doesn't: He keeps letting director Ron Howard turn them into silly movies.
The director's most punishing film since Raging Bull.
The emphasis is on deep-focus 3-D spectacle, not psychology.
For all its ugly self-interest, Old Stone is also beautiful, and not just in its use of red lights in black night.
Mifune: The Last Samurai is a relatively short film that would have benefited from additional voices, as well as more Kurosawa-like sweep and Mifune-style verve.
Boasts some gripping scenes and a few stabs at satire, but ultimately offers little beyond its assured sense of style.
Although it's intended as a satire, director Feng Xiaogang's movie has a literary tone, a leisurely pace and relatively few laugh-out-loud moments.
The Monster offers solid performances and a real-world subtext. But those virtues aren't enough to keep the movie from getting stalled in some big bad woods, miles short of profundity.
A satire whose whimsies and sight gags frequently click, but whose philosophical impact is negligible.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While the stagiest sequences are visually impressive, much of the movie is not.
Doremus and screenwriter Nathan Parker ... borrow from "Romeo and Juliet," "1984" and every sci-fi flick ever made about a society that suppresses feelings. The movie's futurism is nothing new.
A playful yet also serious about the workings of power.

As a shaper of stories, Bercot is not yet as assured as those directors. But she knows how to elicit authentic performances, whether from veterans like Deneuve or a first-timer like Paradot. His Malony may not be likable, but he's altogether believable.
Wandering through the Louvre's colonial plunder, Sokurov ponders the lost worlds of Egypt and Assyria, but ultimately finds his way home.
This may be the first big-budget Asian action flick ever set in Chongqing, but otherwise it's on familiar turf.

Several previous movies, including 2012's The Last Ride, have attempted to make sense of Williams's life. I Saw the Light should have taken its cue from its unearthly star and pursued a more cosmic mission.
It's impossible to say how autobiographical My Golden Days is, but there's no question that it's profoundly personal.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is both provocative and fairly gripping, if not altogether convincing.
Clever but ultimately disappointing ...
Malick has made what is essentially the same movie three times in a row: Tree of Life, To the Wonder, and now Knight of Cups. It's time to ask if he knows what he's doing.
It is bewitchingly strange, and as enveloping as the Amazon jungle.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although the film's three sections are stylistically disparate, they're linked by several motifs, including a lachrymose Cantopop ballad, a man who carries a traditional sword, and Tao's dog.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Admirable but arduous. Its vision of sin and repentance is sexually graphic and sometimes perverse, more Jean Genet than St. Francis of Assisi.
Like many films set in contemporary Bucharest, this is a story of self-styled potentates, small-time graft, and inevitable disappointment.
The carelessly plotted story consists mostly of setups for fight scenes, nicely staged in such distinctive locations as an elevator, an umbrella store and the hull of a partly built ship.
What distinguishes In the Shadow of Women are its naturalistic performances - especially Courau's - and its elegantly composed shots and offhand rhythm.
Cops prowl darkened mazes, looking for perps they probably couldn't see even if they found them.
It's distinguished by its craft and verve.
The imagery is gauzy and ephemeral, with lots of layered reflections and nighttime shots. The narrative spins backwards and then jumps forward, as if reconstructed from shards of painful memory.
All this foreboding produces no suspense: It's evident from the bloody prologue where "The Invitation" is headed.
Both grimmer and meatier than the director's previous efforts.

Amusing and even edifying, although it is also unlikely to make converts out of those who just don't get Zappa's pastiche of juvenile parody and sophisticated songwriting, derived from rock, jazz and 20th-century experimental music.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director To fills in the messy back story neatly as he introduces the supporting players, who provide comedy or menace (and sometimes both).
In fact, there are many differences, some of them merely playful but others profound.
Rather than gain speed and power in its final act, as Joseph's design comes into play, the movie stalls.
movie_title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Wailing is a Hell of a ride, but Na should have given more thought to its destination.
With its European locations, electro-thump score, and near-ceaseless violence, the movie plays like something tooled in French producer-scripter Luc Besson's factory for international action mashups.
During the impressive action sequences - which Xu choreographed himself - the director plays it straight. Otherwise, he introduces playful kinks into most of the genre's other conventions.
The documentary's strength is that it doesn't insist on a diagnosis. "Why have you let me film this?" asks Kriegman at the end, and his former boss has no answer.
The movie doesn't linger on any single topic, happy or sad. With so many lives to look back on, Fegan moves briskly from theme to theme.
Plays it straight with a topic that in reality is far more twisted.

"Phantom" glories in its own artifice. The movie is carried by sweeping widescreen images, dynamic camera movements, impressive special effects and a color scheme that contrasts icy blues against fiery reds.
A visually powerful, impeccably acted mood piece.
Think of Elvis & Nixon's sometimes clumsy prologue as its opening act, building anticipation for the showdown between its title characters, and Spacey and Shannon.
Writer-director Hany Abu-Assad doesn't tell simple stories, even when he does.
Once again, Chinese and American filmmakers pool their resources, only to find that having more money doesn't make it talk any more persuasively.
Ducournau's movie is as tiresome as it is scandalous. Rather than tell a story, Raw merely administers a series of shocks.
"Donald Cried" succeeds on its own modest terms, but watching its title character can be painful. This is not a movie for people who'd just as soon forget their own teenage mortifications.
"BPM" is often exhilarating and ultimately moving, but it makes few concessions to audiences without a strong preexisting interest in its subject.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Trier is a ingenious filmmaker, and he makes Thelma visually compelling even when the story lazily turns to the usual scare-flick tropes.
It's a tightly woven series of closeups of a diverse, divided populace.
"Blade" goes for the carotid while offering a classic look and a comic-book story. It's part Kurosawa, part "X-Men," part "Ichi the Killer."
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The argument in favor of The Square is not that it's great fun to watch, but that it's very entertaining to ponder after viewing. It lingers, both amusingly and disturbingly.
Despite a modicum of visual style and competent performances, it is unable to keep us guessing - or, more important, to make us care - long enough to work up true suspense.
The movie's biggest fantasy is a world where there are no fundamental conflicts, only misunderstandings.
A solid if conventional bio.
Sweet and rather silly, the movie is entertaining. It's rarely persuasive, however, and generally seems like a missed opportunity.
Writer-director S. Craig Zahler takes his handiwork so seriously that viewers may do the same.

J. Mills Goodloe and Chris Weitz's script ... dispenses backstory as if through an I.V. drip, designed to just barely sustain the audience's interest. Most of the time, character development is buried under fresh powder.

Despite all the revelations about Felt's career and family, he is no more complex a character at the end than at the beginning. Neeson's performance is all steel-spined bearing and resonant intonation.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As both a movie and a battle plan for ending the child-sex trade, "Stopping Traffic" is disorganized and incomplete.
movie_title: Stopping Traffic: The Movement to End Sex Trafficking (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's thesis is that the 1960s' political clashes and cultural revelations were essentially linked, and equally liberating.
Wonderstruck offers much to occupy the eyes and minds of movie buffs and Haynes fans. Yet there's little room left for insight and emotion in this overstuffed cabinet of curiosities.
Ex Libris's graceful exit suggests that Wiseman always knew exactly where he was headed.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining if mostly routine con-game thriller.

Sam Munson's 2010 novel The November Criminals is the kind of book that attracts smart filmmakers and serious actors - that then, all too often, gets diluted into a bland disappointment like November Criminals.
An entertaining if inevitably unreliable current events romp.
The movie's central story, a tortured-love triangle, is slight. But the context is fascinating and the visual style bewitching.

It does rely on certain Gallic attitudes toward women that don't travel well. Louis' psychiatric method could reasonably be described as sexual assault, and the notion that Chloe might be "hysterical" is at best archaic.
Much of "The Monkey King 3" is devoted to philosophical musing and romantic mooning, the latter cued to a drippy ballad.
Peter Rabbit is sometimes crass, but more often simply dull.
Although a tighter cut of the 130-minute Before We Vanish would likely be an improvement, it might lose this version's intriguing asides.
The filmmaker's universe is both deeply ordinary and just a little uncanny.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While A Ciambra is not a happy story, its vigor and authenticity deliver a sort of joy.
Despite its neo-new-wave style, Lover for a Day is neither offhand nor autobiographical.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: If watching it is frustrating, so is the larger process of seeking understanding, or at least a nonviolent mutual tolerance.

In the Fade boasts an assured sense of style and a meticulously constructed script. Moments that initially appear to be asides turn out to be essential, and the final scenes of the first two chapters are vivid and startling.
Jared Moshe, the writer and director of The Ballad of Lefty Brown, is a fan of classic Westerns and he's made a movie that should please fellow aficionados.

Feng [snakes] his camera exuberantly though scenes that highlight colorful costumes, dynamic choreography and beautiful chorines.
Gradually documentarian Greg Barker's look at Barack Obama's foreign policy team comes into focus, thanks in large part to the counterpoint played by the Trump campaign.
[An] engaging documentary ...
For viewers unfamiliar with the topic, "Twenty Two" provides the basic facts about the estimated 200,000 women enslaved in Japanese-occupied China.
If her career as director somehow doesn't pan out, Meyers-Shyer would make an excellent fairy godmother.
Sweeping and dynamic, if mostly unsurprising.

While making a hash of a national legend, Ritchie is at least enough of a patriot to have filmed King Arthur entirely in the U.K.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Music redeems an at-risk teen in "Urban Hymn," a social-problem melodrama whose other major characters don't fare so well.
Last Men balances the visceral and the melancholy.
This movie is rarely more than merely competent, but it should stir lovers of justice as well as dog fanciers.
From the sizzling griddle that opens the story to a hallucinogenic trip triggered by blowfish toxin, this engagingly goofy romantic comedy speaks the international language of food.
movie_title: This Is Not What I Expected (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Attempting to make an atrocity palatable to a mainstream audience, "The Promise" delivers the history, but undercuts its impact.

Cedar is well attuned to the Manhattan-Jerusalem-Tel Aviv nexus. He gets excellent performances from Gere - playing partway against type as a charmer who's unnervingly hot rather than reassuringly cool - and the rest of the cast.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The longer the movie runs, the more its novelty fades. The tone wavers, and plot holes that appeared small at the halfway point start looking like chasms.
Working with cinematographer Jean-Marie Dreujou, Thompson contrasts the widescreen format with a restless handheld camera and many closeups, so the movie feels both sweeping and intimate.
Harrelson is as engaging as the man's personality allows. But Wilson struggles with tone, shifting from monotonously bleak to predictably satirical to improbably sanguine.

Most of its plot elements are overly familiar, but they're invigorated by Elliott's easygoing performance and the way Haley deploys them in explicit homage to his muse.

The Journey ponders nothing less than the intractability of political violence. Which means it's pertinent far beyond Belfast.
With seven main roles and several flimsy subplots, I Do... lacks focus and drive.
Jung shreds a simple story and then weaves the pieces into an intricate tapestry of flashbacks and pure-action scenes, with the individual strands often sewn together by pictorial rhymes.
Although it's a scrappy indie, the movie has something in common with many platinum-plated CGI blockbusters: The visuals are as strong as the script is feeble.

[A] perceptive drama ...

movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Valerian is exuberant, extravagant, and generally likable. Yet many parts of the movie just don't work. Sticklers for things like acting and dialogue are likely to be dissatisfied.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Viewers ... will find the setup more rewarding than the payoff.
For viewers who aren't hostile to mysticism, vegetarianism and endless chanting, it's a stirring story.
movie_title: Hare Krishna! The Mantra, The Movement And The Swami Who Started It All (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As usual in Hui's films, the personal and the political are stitched tightly together.

"Moka" is a stark, moody mystery that doesn't actually contain much mystery. Instead, it excels as a character study and a dynamic face-off between two formidable actresses: Emmanuelle Devos and Nathalie Baye.
[An] affecting low-key drama ...
Breakneck chases, high-altitude jeopardy and split-second rescues upstage everything save for a flowery moral: No technological breakthrough is more disruptive than a mother's love.
This charmer is determinedly mundane and low-key, until an unexpected finale transforms it.
The movie lurches from event to event, and tone to tone, without articulating a reason to exist.

The fresh-faced actors, realistic dialogue and naturalistic performances suggest a casual approach, but as the story progresses, the filmmaker's control is increasingly evident.
It's time for Derrickson, who also directed The Exorcism of Emily Rose, to master a new ritual.

movie_review_blurb: The film's payoff is about as novel as a scoop of lemon sorbet.
Both laughable and sweet.
Engagingly lively, if not always graceful, and often surprisingly comic.

Unlike most movies that rely on TV-news reports to drive the story, Dormant Beauty is complex and humane, and never shrinks to mere spectacle.

Sometimes too faithful to teenage aimlessness, We Are the Best! can be shapeless and uneventful. But the movie often jolts to life, whether with outbursts of hostility or moments of gleeful female bonding.
With characters like the impish Quicksilver, the movie recaptures something of the spirit of the comic's early days.

The movie is one of those stories of rock war veterans that's great fun to hear, even if you don't buy a word of it.
[Brings its] raunchy scenario to a payoff that upholds the very middle-class values the movie gleefully profanes.

There's a fundamental problem here. The movie relies on the instinctual human fear of death, but its message is that dying is a promotion.

movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

If the movie hits ominous notes, they've all been heard many times before ...
This movie is meant for the ... audience that's already jazzed about exploring the bottom of the seas.
If the movie's universal themes don't impress, its specific details do.
Basically a promo reel for small-town France and Gallo-Indian food fusion. Anyone who requires a more substantial meal should eat before heading to the theater.

As the filmmakers follow the story over seven years, the movie becomes richer and more empathetic. The events are absurd, but the emotions merely human.

Far from a searing drama yet seldom takes the glib way out.

A pensive, intelligent vampire-angst movie.
[Rob] Zombie's most chilling movie so far, if not his most horrific.

movie_review_blurb: This is not muddy storytelling, just bipolar and unconvincing, as Grant force-feeds us comedy to soften us up for the emotional kill.
Jonah Hex is not a good movie, but it's a great cautionary tale about what happens when a film loses its way.
Hersonski has done Holocaust scholarship a great favor. Just when we thought there were no new twists to the story of the Warsaw Ghetto comes this documentary: focused, sorrowful and revelatory.
Rockwell charms us into giving the film the benefit of our many doubts.
Schwentke keeps things light: light on big laughs, light on unique action set pieces and light on any sense that these game but retired spies are too old for this crap.
Bitton operates at a cool, investigatory remove that's not as objective as it looks ... nevertheless, it's a well structured, sometimes riveting piece of information gathering.
Works fine as civics instruction but it won't move the needle against this decidedly anti-democratic process.
Feels the burden of history so heavily that it's effectively smothered by it.
Ray is a ratty little bugger with a corner pub smile that hides secrets you're safer not knowing but can't wait to discover.
(Prioritizes) statistics and on-field accomplishments over larger questions of religion, culture and community.
movie_title: Jews And Baseball: An American Love Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A wild biographical ride that adds an unexpected psychological layer to the classic art versus commerce conundrum.
movie_title: Dirty Hands: The Art & Crimes of David Choe (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Burzynski may have credibility in the eyes of some, but the movie about him has no credibility, so no one will be receptive to its message.
Filled with odd behavior and curious quirks. What it's not filled with are recognizable humans.
It's all quite renegade, in that self-aggrandizing, subcultural way.
Densely constructed and pretty damn brilliant.
Predictable, leaden, unfunny and unnecessary.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Soft sells its cliches so effectively and without guile they seem fresh in the telling. Then again, maybe you can never overuse the concept of people learning how to be happy.
Forgettable all around.
An unpersuasive, amateurishly told story of an abused wife escaping her old (straight) life and embarking on a new (lesbian) life.
A chamber piece, a psychological horror film, about "young mothers, bad choices."
Haim Tabakman's feature directing debut fascinates for the powerful, multi-layered themes that percolate beneath its visually spare and delicately told story.
Packed to the rafters with star talent and greeting card sentiments, this is best appreciated by women who cry at TV commercials.
In an era of impersonal filmmaking, Carmel is as personal as a movie can be without naked body parts.
Even by the low standards of today's romantic comedy, this is a black mark on everyone's resume.
While this may be straightforward, politically neutral, documentary filmmaking, its makers have chosen an incendiary subject who pisses most people off the moment he opens his mouth.
movie_title: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Appearances by Toni Collette and Whale Rider's Keisha Castle-Hughes should draw a few curious parents to what is, most of the time, a quirky and quite enjoyable coming of age saga.
If someone needs to be convinced they're dead, Neeson should make the argument.
A lovely experience.

Pipkin liberally applies the dispiriting statistics, but he's not laying a guilt trip. His tone is positive and hopeful, elevating One Peace at a Time from other docs that try to motivate using alarmist rhetoric, smug sarcasm or scare tactics.

Heikin has gathered rare video shot in-country and riveting escapee stories to create a commendable upgrade to our limited fount of North Korean knowledge, which almost completely mitigates the doc's numerous problems.
Why even include a modern day human vs. undead smackdown, when all you can afford are about ten extras jumping around an empty warehouse?

Utilizing pervasive social media and numerous promo screenings, the movie looks to open well. It's just too bad Pink and company declared open season on an embarrassing decade then armed themselves with a urine-filled squirt gun.

Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children has all the making of a super franchise -- the call of destiny, the making of heroes and the embrace of kinship. Plus, of course, coming to terms with your inner freak.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The animation and sound effects are so superbly rendered -- the fantasy sequences have an entirely different and nifty flavor -- that a drop of drool or a puff of baby powder seems to have real texture and feeling.
There's a deep hollowness under the funny suit.

There may have been enough aerosol spray to burn off the rest of our ozone layer, but Wednesday's ambitious live version of the musical Hairspray on NBC was worth the environmental damage. It was light and fun and soon had you stuck.

Lion is really two beautifully shot films -- the tenacious story of young Saroo Brierley, lost far from home, and the less dramatic, slightly forced, story of him all grown up and looking for his past.

[Adams] delivers a heart-wrenchingly beautiful performance using her ability to communicate a half-dozen emotions just standing still... But director Denis Villeneuve sometimes gets lost in repetition and blind alleys.
A lazy, meandering mess that gives off no heat.
Streep, of course, fills her character with emotion, humanity and need, but director Stephen Frears and writer Nicholas Martin haven't decided whether their movie is slapstick or tragedy.

This small and lazy film -- featuring two actors, one evil voice and a crumbling stone wall -- attempts to be deep and even existential but it can't hide its deep flaws in the constant swirling desert sands.
You'll end up feeling about the film like Bobby about Los Angeles -- "half-bored, half-fascinated." And that's a pretty poor average, even for two poorly stitched-together films.
Robbery crews are strongly advised to avoid 1837 Buena Vista, but moviegoers hoping for a thrill might like to visit. But don't linger.
A nasty spat between two couples over the course of an evening may not sound like a fun flick, but like any act of carnage, it's hard to turn away.
With this hectic, ambitious and hormonal Grease, Fox proved it could up the ante in the new mini-industry of musicals on TV.
An exuberant, inventive The Wiz Live! on Thursday night breathed new life into the notion of full-scale musicals on live TV with a happy serving of 70s soul and R&B, updated with a 2015 vibe.
The character of Peter Pan will clearly survive this live event, but it remains to be seen if NBC's lacklustre Peter Pan Live! killed off the network's brave experiment in live theatre.
How do you solve a problem like Maria, indeed.
This sequel gets progressively messy while The Blair Witch Project grew progressively taut.
Cranston is simply remarkable in the role, a tricky one since his character has precious little dialogue with anyone else. Yet the actor shows everything here -- arrogance, sorrow, anger, love, fear.
Still, for all its problems, this is a film with world-class animation, revealing everything from astonishingly rich crowd scenes to rusty details on an old pail.
It's not always a well-marbled ride. There's an inconsistent tone, with horrific moments spliced with satire and detours into vaudeville and a few moments when it's kidnapped into a heist movie.
After this fifth episode, you'll wish Disney would just declare the franchise dead and tell no more tales.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are gorgeous exteriors of Vienna, Budapest, London and lush hotel interiors. The soundtrack is Tchaikovsky and Mozart. It's like an extended ad for Chanel, except for all the gore.
Nostalgia is not a perfect film but it is moving and sensitive. You leave with your head in the clouds and a new view of your precious stuff.
That old Hollywood standby, the venerable buddy cop movie, may have met its anguished demise this holiday season. Will Smith just killed it.
Despite a stunning performance by Winslet and some beautiful cinematography by Vittorio Storaro, Wonder Wheel loses its charms quickly and you'll soon be begging to get off this particular ride.

Washington gives us another astounding performance of a deeply idiosyncratic man, but the film around him often isn't as skillful, meandering in places and gradually becoming more like a lot of other films.

This fusion of commercial with contrition doesn't always work but it's surprising how much brutal honesty we get between shots of Lovato working out in a light-streamed gym or suggestively lounging in her frighteningly white kitchen.
This film makes such firefighters into cartoons, which ill serves their legacy.

Somewhere in "The Cloverfield Paradox" is an excellent sci-fi thriller but one that's in desperate need of sharpening. It's no disaster, like Netflix's recent "Bright," but it tries too hard to give something to everyone and ends of unsatisfying...

The Earth might be the film's titular star but the documentary is really about the sun and how that star's waxing and waning energy over 24 hours shapes life down here, from the warmth of morning to the shadows of night.
In Victoria & Abdul, the Empress of India comes off honest, loving and decent. That seems deaf as well as stupid.
The best moments are actually when it pays homage to the first film. The worst are when it takes itself too seriously, the trap of the very spy films it was designed to mock.
Unlocked has got all the cliches you need and want.
But this thriller-inclined version of "Death Note" doesn't dwell enough on such questions and instead becomes increasingly strained by its own insanity and clogged by clunky dialogue.

The film is both a tribute to parenting and a confessional of its absence. Like the book, it looks back without pity or sentiment. Unlike the book, it's got Woody Harrelson and Brie Larson, acting spectacularly.
... somewhat unsteadily balances a cute, getting-to-know-you budding respect between two tentative lovers and the raw ravages of survival, which includes cougars, thin ice and deep snow...

Slate proves again to be a special talent, able to go from goofy-silly to volcanically desirous in the time it takes to gulp a Zima. Falco makes every minute of her small screen time sizzle and Quinn has great skill as a preternaturally mature teen.
Gripping sports reportage with chocolate-box dramatisations of his childhood years, making this very much a game of two halves.
What we're left with is a peculiar example of the regional specificity of humour; a reminder that there's nothing so particular as that which makes a nation laugh.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Part musical bonanza, part laugh-out-loud farce, part satirical social document.
Following the Roger Corman exploitation rule book to the letter, The Anomaly wrings maximum bangs for bucks from its tight budget while unashamedly showcasing the director's buff assets.
A sporadically enjoyable folie à deux; flippantly erudite, forgettably frothy.

McCarthy remains a winning screen presence, and the fact that so many A-listers have jumped aboard to share screen time with her speaks volumes about her standing within the brutal world of big-screen comedy.
The denouement flirts uneasily with melodrama, but the overall tone is rewardingly gentle and surprisingly positive.
The genius of Boyhood is that while watching it, you simply forget about the head-scrambling logistics of the project.
I found it moving, funny and really rather charming, provoking more than enough laughter and tears to dispel my underlying anxieties about the "live" performances.
An essentially televisual affair, but there are chilly thrills to be had as director Steve Reeves and co-writer Mike Oughton make good on the promise of the award-winning short Taking Life.
Grinningly naff but nonetheless goodhearted ...
At once urgent, defiant, and heartbreaking.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An unsettling description of a brutal episode that, despite some awkwardness in approach, does its job with admirable sincerity.
Chef slips a few tasty side dishes around its meat-and-potatoes main course.

It's an uneven affair, embraced as unguardedly "intimate" by some fans of the band, but in reality less moving than Anvil! The Story of Anvil, and lacking the objective insight of Terry Zwigoff's oddly comparable Crumb.
As for the performances, they're ripe and rich, even though the three core characters sometimes appear to be starring in entirely different movies.
Something very special: a Kevin Costner vehicle that makes both The Postman and Waterworld seem fearsomely substantial.
A powerhouse performance by Juliette Binoche provides the beating, tortured heart of this finely wrought and very affecting film about the later life of sculptor Camille Claudel.
Sweet.
If the more melodramatic strains of the script (co-written with Charlotte Colbert) are occasionally at odds with the cast's naturalistic input, the overall picture remains convincing and engaging.
A melancholic cross between Venus and Goodbye, Mr Chips, which could have been more enticingly entitled Venus and Chips.
The audience are made to suffer through scenes that range from the uncomfortable to the unwatchable.
Screenwriters Scott Neustadter and Michael H Weber are on hand to lend an alt-indie edge that cuts through the mawkish manipulation ...
A somewhat plodding but still sporadically entertaining affair ...
You may find yourself tickled, providing your toes don't curl up so far that they actually stab you in the heart.
It's typical Greenaway - overly long, peacockingly erudite, eye-catchingly grotesque, perpetually mischievous, and gleefully up itself.
While the story itself may lack originality, the miserablist milieu is affectingly real.
What redeems it all is the sense that the film-makers take their subject matter seriously and imagine their audience to be as sentient as their simian screen counterparts.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gibney unearths a wealth of archive footage that reaffirms Kuti's superstar status, and watches as Jones wrestles with the contradictions that made the musician such a troublesome icon - confronting some, sidestepping others.
Enjoyably preposterous ...
Robespierre's admirably forthright romcom remains good-natured as it flies the flag for a woman's right to choose ...
Has a few scares up its sleeve ...
At best, this aspires to the whimsical charm of Local Hero; at worst, it simply steals from it.
Craig Gillespie's by-numbers schmaltzathon never transcends its tourist's-eye views of India or patronisingly cliched views of its people.
It sounds mawkish as hell, but director RJ Cutler reads his target teen audience well, crediting them with more intelligence and resilience than one might expect.
Thrilling, chilling, electrifying.
movie_title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (Das Cabinet des Dr. Caligari) (1920)

movie_review_blurb: Short prison sentences for all involved would seem fair.
Reichardt and regular co-writer Jon Raymond display a keen ear for the fragile rhetoric of the self-righteous.
Knappenberger argues that the case against Swartz was overzealously pursued in order to make an example of him and on the evidence presented here it's hard to disagree.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Sen (who also shoots, scores and edits) goes walkabout through the minefield of contemporary Australian culture, offering an evocative snapshot of an unravelling crime scene - social, racial and economic.
Generally as raw as the steaks that Cage manfully cuts from the carcass of an impaled deer, the high whiff of which seeps through every frame of the film.
The narrative nods its head towards Toy Story and ParaNorman, although there's nothing here to match the magic of either of those strange gems.
movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While the end result is palpably stupid, it's not as terrible as one might expect.
A nasty little B-picture, unashamed of its exploitation roots.
Worth seeing for those who haven't seen it all before.
An arresting cocktail of sex, violence and surrealism, shot in monochrome hues which accentuate the perversity of the entire twisted venture.

The tone veers from quirky observation to bleak contemplation, with a streak of dry cruelty - particularly when viewed through the reflective eyes of the horses upon which Erlingsson repeatedly focuses.
He's splendidly charismatic company, as his A-list roster attests en masse.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's surprisingly moving stuff - dressed up with just enough archival outrage to remind you how scandalous Divine once seemed.
Rahim and Seydoux keep things grounded in the familiar isotopes of human emotion, their passion less explosive than merely uncontained, progressing inexorably toward meltdown.
Moments are electrifying - the spaces between them challenging.
A fascinating story which continues to raise more questions than it answers.
If you paid to see this, you would feel duty-bound to demand your money back; I saw it for free and still wanted a refund.
Powerful stuff.
Takes us into the home - and by extension, the mind - of its amnesiac subject, who appears to have found happiness living in the moment after brain damage robbed him of his short-term memory.
The air of impending disaster (we open with the notorious mobile phone footage) culminates in a harrowing final act that is both chilling and heartbreaking.
This unpretentiously efficient affair handles its dual-narrative past/present intercuts with aplomb and keeps a couple of nicely nasty tricks up its sleeve.
Lacks the discipline necessary to make it anything more than a war of improv attrition.

This terrifically engaging work raises important questions about universal experience and cultural context - in this case, the search for independent female identity in a society all but suffocated by the threat of violence.
Rubbish, then, but laughable rubbish - often more "with it" than "at it".
Although the ideas and performances are strong, the drama itself feels oddly disjointed ...
This sympathetic and engaging drama is deceptively gentle in its insight - compassionate yet unsentimental.
It's solidly unsurprising (and often quite boring) generic fare, spiced up with steroidal pectorals and fetishy catfights.
While the motion-captured 3D CG has an uncanny photorealist quality, the wisdom of attempting to turn Tarzan into an Avatar-lite fantasy remains, at best, questionable.
Starts with a whimper and ends with several bangs, passing umpteen snores en route.
A stripped-down tale of revenge with bloodied hands and a blackened heart, this viscerally intelligent thriller takes a new stab at an old genre with refreshingly distressing results.

It would nice to be able to declare that this women-on-top revenge comedy presents a sparky gender-role inversion, but instead it just trots out the usual cliches in tired and increasingly tiresome fashion.
Exhibition reaffirms Hogg's status as a distinctive, singular and challenging voice of British cinema.
John Curran's scenic yet intimate recreation of Davidson's epic journey makes for an engrossing watch, albeit one that unfolds at a walking pace.
[An] affectionate and somewhat wistful account of her rise to prominence as a portrait photographer of legend and renown.
A vérité thriller rich with a sense of location and cultural authenticity.
movie_title: After the Night (Até ver a luz) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone with a fondness for broad canvas, ideas-heavy sci-fi should ignore the negative scuttle and give Transcendence the benefit of the doubt.
The strangest $125m ever spent by a major studio.
Saldanha and his team of crack animators paint the vibrant, verdant settings in eye-catching detail, providing ample visual distraction from the patchy plot ...
The film itself never quite comes into focus.
Drab production design (bombed-out buildings and Blake's 7 costumes) aims for gloomy portent, but the grit feels as fake as the fashionable tattoos.
A hugely impressive work by a uniquely talented storyteller.
movie_title: A Story Of Children And Film (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Ayoade fills the future-retro landscape with sounds and visions lifted from Terry Gilliam's Brazil and David Lynch's Eraserhead, with effective if derivative results.
Farhadi finds his characters trapped, not by the constraints of an overbearing authority but by the spectre of the past.

Excerpts of performances from shows such as Being Harold Pinter and Minsk 2011 hint at the visceral power of the group, which the Belarusian authorities apparently view as a threat to national security.
movie_title: Dangerous Acts Starring The Unstable Elements Of Belarus (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Much of the build-up may retread familiar The Last Exorcism territory, but the claustrophobic final act is properly alarming scary fare.

Relaxed, intuitive performances from the top-notch ensemble cast pay dividends, with Hahn commandingly stressy in the central role, and Michaela Watkins impressively abrasive as neighbourhood organiser-in-chief.
Frank manages to get beneath the mask and the skin of its eponymous antihero in a manner that bridges the gap between absurdist laughter and all-too-tender tears.
Slathered in portentous narration by Liam Neeson and a ludicrously over-cranked and incessant score, both of which conspire to undercut, rather than enhance, the overall impact.
Scenes of people kicking doors down and shooting each other in the head are efficiently handled - it's everything else that's a problem.
With its chilly visual sheen and sharp bourgeois satire, this handsomely mounted and consistently well-played yarn offers disposable pleasures and rewarding intrigue.
In the title role Kyle Catlett (looking like a cross between Johnny Rotten and Macaulay Culkin) blends adult intelligence and childish innocence with ease ...
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Haunting artistry aside, it's hard to see what Egoyan brings to the table that hasn't already been covered in print (Mara Leveritt's book provides source material), on screen and elsewhere in the media.
A finely wrought tale of a woman out of time, a film that plays eloquently upon the heartstrings as it interweaves familiar personal intrigue with stirring social history.
A more interesting proposition than it is a finished film.
You can take the result as either smart satire or sick schlock - frankly, it works on both scores.
While the on-off romance between the central duo is kinda cute, they never for one minute convince as a band - a fatal flaw.
movie_title: Jolene: The Indie Folk Star Movie (Benny & Jolene) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Wingard and Barrett's increasingly ludicrous schlocker has plenty of fun with genre convention, unafraid to laugh at itself as the bodies pile up and the knowing nods and winks become manic twitches.

The live performances are electrifying, all jagged elbows and brilliant pop tunes, with the band suitably assisted not by drugs and booze, but by a neatly organised display of treatments for colds, incontinence and light grazes.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As brash, rehashed gag-fests go, this easily passed the six laugh test - even before we got to the end credits.
This cack-handed snapshot of "Grace Kelly's greatest role" is destined to become another epithet-coining catastrophe, the benchmark by which badder-than-bad biopics will be judged in years to come.
[A] terrifically watchable and impressively empowering documentary ...
Despite the smattering of knowing nods to the parents (jokes about James M Cain and Lost in Space) this has little to entice the over-sixes and plenty to scare the under-fives ...

If you can get beyond the implausibility of Sharon Stone paying John Turturro to join her in a ménage à trois - and, frankly, I couldn't - then there are lightweight pleasures to be had amid the wry, angsty middle-aged male fantasy.
[A] vomit-inducing blend of mawkish sentimentality and dead-on-arrival humour, all bundled up in a putrid package of festering family-friendly fun.

Heli paints a harrowing and often unbearably grim picture of a lawless bandit country, the indignities of which are made all the more powerful by Escalante's evident compassion for the struggling characters at the sharp end of all this escalating chaos.
Innocuous then, but sadly lacking the wit and insight of Shelton's far superior Your Sister's Sister.
Notable largely for the anguished, nuanced performance of Jessica Lange ...
You're left with the impression that the charismatic Pantani was more sinned against than sinning.
movie_title: Pantani: The Accidental Death Of A Cyclist (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A handsomely mounted if somewhat slight affair, beautifully photographed by Marcel Zyskind, gorgeously dressed by Steven Noble, and well played by the central trio ...
Much of the narrative may not ring true, but Weigert's performance is warm and engaging, lending not just heart, but much needed credibility.
Teases together four disparate stories of people driven to violence by the purgatorial pain of their modern existence.

My advice would be to seek out the biggest, loudest Imax auditorium available and allow the movie to roar majestically right in your face, peeling away any niggling uncertainties with the icy fire of its thunderous breath.
A rich treat for the eye and soul alike.
Merely confirms Schrader as an all-but spent force (it's been largely downhill since the dismal Dominion) and nails Bret Easton Ellis as a one-trick pony.
Watching this was the first time I have ever punched the air because a football sailed into the back of a net. And very probably the last.
Although the doc doesn't dig very deep, it allows plenty of space for each of its divas to flaunt their unique style, which ranges from classic elegance to colourful adventure.
Puri is great fun as the indomitable head of the family, and Mirren convinces as the grand dame, despite dishing out her lines in an accent that staunchly refuses to set.
The air of paranoid mistrust rings true, evoked most eloquently by Hoffman's world-weary face, which speaks a universal language.
It's essentially a 10-minute sketch stretched out to an 80-minute movie, which feels even longer.

There's more than a hint of The Treasure of the Sierra Madre about this Dennis Kelly-scripted thriller, which does a grippingly efficient job of trapping its audience amid the pumping pistons and clanging pipes of its inhospitable setting.

The Grandmaster interweaves themes of ancient loyalty and modern betrayal around a narrative predicated upon the interplay between the differing schools, traditions and movements of myriad martial arts disciplines.
Stations of the Cross appears to acknowledge the miraculous, even as it descends into hell on Earth.
"Please look after this bear", says the tag around Paddington's neck. Rest assured, they have.
It's an overpowering experience, awe-inspiringly photographed by Geoffrey Unsworth, groundbreakingly enhanced by Douglas Trumbull.
Hockney's account of his life and philosophy is always worth listening to, even if much has been recounted before in a variety of media.
While the film-makers are clearly keen to pay tribute to the heroism of those involved, the film itself wisely avoids glib romanticism, opting instead for gruelling realism.
Through it all, the changing nature of violence (destructive, cleansing, inevitable) is unravelled in illuminating, harrowing form.
It's entertaining in parts, but wildly overlong and narratively ill-disciplined.
movie_title: Rurôni Kenshin: Kyôto Taika-hen (Rurouni Kenshin: Kyoto Inferno) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Blimey, this is miserable.
Winter Sleep is an engrossing work, a finely observed portrait of collapsing social contracts, public and private.
Former horror maestro Christopher Smith, who made his name with Severance, Triangle and Black Death, goes in search of his inner child with this moderately likable Christmas romp.
A spiky media satire about the making and marketing of a revolution that most definitely will be televised.
There's a few table-turning twists that lend a veneer of final-girl sister-power ... but little else to provide big-screen distraction.
While individual gags and cineliterate nods (from Nosferatu to Blade) may have comical bite, there's not enough meat to sink its feature-length fangs into.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's solidly predictable and somewhat grating, only partially redeemed by a reliably watchable cast.
Infuriatingly conflicted fare, buoyed up by brilliant performances, weighed down by old-school cliche, leavened by the bleak plains over which it casts its lonely, misanthropic eye.
OK, so the narrative may be a tad shaky, but what lends Azkaban its edge is the unabashedly creepy tone that Cuaron conjures.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I can't speak for the kids at whom it is aimed, but as an adult I'd rather stay in and watch a CBBC Chuckle Brothers marathon.
[A] multi-stranded slice of phoney-baloney, manipulative claptrap.
The result is intriguing and intelligent, but ultimately uninspired.
For all its ponderous tone and pedigree, this remains lightweight stuff, rehashing familiar neo-noir riffs while over-exercising its central "dog's life" metaphor.
Taking its title from Ebert's bestselling memoir, this lovely, insightful film is a splendidly watchable tribute to a truly cinematic life.
It is a celebration of Turing's extraordinary achievements, a populist yarn that makes an admirably firm fist of establishing its spiky subject as a heroic outsider.
It's stirring scattershot stuff, made with a fine eye for period detail and an evident passion for the music, which remains the driving force throughout.
Top marks go to young leads Ansel Elgort and Kaitlyn Dever, who manage to create their own believable world within the mawkish miasma of this flawed movie.
Like Benedict Cumberbatch's unique pronunciation of the word "penguin", the result remains oddly entertaining.
The Pyramid plods through its conventional generic tropes in increasingly aggravating fashion, any tension dissipating in the face of unscary cats and rubbery monsters.
Despite stylish direction by Rupert Wyatt, who pulls off a few arresting set pieces, The Gambler never manages to make sense of William Monahan's often laughably overripe screenplay.

The central arguments about the codified rules of high-school interaction lack focus and (most importantly) context, pinballing around with plenty of bell-ringing pizzazz but precious little analytical bite.

For all its overripe contrivance, you'll leave the cinema with a spring in your step and a thump in your chest, eager to bang the drum for what deserves to be one of the year's real word-of-mouth hits.
It sounds grisly, and at times the twee picture postcard Parisian milieu (street-lit cafes; padlocks on the Pont des Arts) drifts into snore-inducing cliche.
It's a powerful story, and one that deserves to be told and retold, albeit in rather more adventurous fashion.
While the external scenery is spectacular, it's the internal landscapes that capture and hold our attention.
Eastwood has stripped things back so that we observe the action through American eyes only, our focus as blinkered as that of its titular killer.
An account of an OCD American misfit whose desire to take up arms in a foreign land seems more driven by his self-proclaimed "crash course in manhood" than geopolitical conviction.
The tagline promises "It ends here" but the denouement keeps the door open for more. What next? Taken 4: Taken the Piss?
La Streep gives it some much-needed oomph, but just wishing upon her star power won't make your dreams come true.
Brings to life a tragedy from the past that continues to have relevance amid today's unfolding news headlines.
Each viewer will judge its truth for themselves, but the director's compassionately unsentimental acceptance is clear and profound.
It trots along at a fair old pace, the cast doing a sterling job of keeping straight faces while spouting quasi-scientific gobbledegook.
After the bloated uncertainties of Alice in Wonderland and Dark Shadows (his last two live-action features), it's encouraging to find Burton returning to a more intimate canvas.
Yes, there is spectacle, although the initially promising parting of the Red Sea is almost drowned by waves of climactic silliness.
Jolie's movie is only interested in the gruelling POW endurances that were arguably the least interesting part of this inspirational life story.

Wallis here retains all the unaffected charm that she showcased in Beasts, skipping nimbly between comedy, pathos and show-stopping song and dance, lending credible heart and soul to a production that so often fails to find its feet.

Somewhere amid the rictus grins of this cynical seasonal offering there lurks the spectre of the old-school variety show in which tradition demands that you applaud a string of famous people for simply turning up, rather than actually being any good.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Considering we all know the outcome, the levels of tension remain impressive, while an atmosphere of melancholy tempers even the most triumphant moments.
The Farrellys, who once had a genuinely anarchic edge, demonstrate a fatal lack of timing - missing the film's comic beat by around 20 years.
If only the viewing environment were more suited to casual contemplation, allowing the audience (like the passengers) to dip in and out of the car in 10-minute stretches.
It manages to infuse its simple narrative with a spicily subversive attitude toward traditional gender roles, while spooning its audience generous helpings of sweetly seductive costume romance.
movie_title: A Tale of Samurai Cooking: A True Love Story (Bushi no Kondate) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While the narrative may suffer from a few too-cute contrivances, the overall air is heady and engulfing, with Deyn cutting a defiant figure - strong, resilient, irrepressible.
It's a remarkable story, told with slick thriller flair, focusing increasingly on the interdependence of its subjects, who chose personal morality over political rhetoric, with isolating results.
Although once hailed as a potential successor to David Lean, Jackson's cinematic instincts are here singly overshadowed by a computer game aesthetic.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If it's spectacle you want, then Interstellar delivers, particularly when viewed in Nolan's preferred 70mm Imax format.
I honestly can't remember when I last saw a happier screen couple.
It all looks terribly old-fashioned and a little old-hat.
A boisterously rotund performance by co-writer/star Celyn Jones provides the heart of this slight but diverting tale ...

At 149 minutes, the film never drags nor does its mood settle, slipping from classy narcissistic humour to exploitation-inflected thrills in an instant; mercurial, mystifying - and tantalisingly missing.
Gradually mutates into a debate about the singularity of the soul, the spectre of reincarnation rearing its unexpected head under laboratory conditions.
It's an elegant Chinese puzzle of a movie, deftly constructed by director Virzì, and boosted by an array of strong performances.
There are plenty of close-to-the-bone belly laughs as the estranged McLeods hit the road for Scotland, after which an unexpectedly morbid twist takes us into altogether darker territory ...
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Janiak's directorial debut makes confident use of limited resources to conjure creepy thrills, peering through the cracks in the couple's imploding relationship, spying shadowy monsters lurking in the darkness.
It's utter balderdash that could lose at least 30 minutes from its bloated running time, but I'd be lying if I didn't admit that the DIY violence struck a neanderthal nerve.
For all its sombre subject matter, there is warmth here too; personal, musical, spiritual.
A tale of terminal Tinseltown wastrels with the twisted structure of a Greek tragedy and the rictus grin of a freshly poisoned sitcom.
The performances of the young cast are committedly brittle, especially Ben Schnetzer playing the antithesis of his Tory-baiting role in Pride.
Flits between handsome neo-noir pastiche and ripe psychological melodrama.
Incessantly shrieky ...
It just looks like a low-rent mishmash of Divergentand The Hunger Games, recycling riffs from Logan's Run with sets and costumes lifted from Bill and Ted's Bogus Journey.
Entertainingly preposterous ...
It sounds awful, but it's actually quite likable in an indulgent indie-spirited way, skipping breezily through laughter and tears in largely inoffensive fashion.
A sweet-natured contrivance; big on whimsy, low on memorability.
Impressively sober, thoughtful ...
The biggest surprise is the fact that, even after all this time, Neeson still can't do a decent American accent.
The results are challenging and alarming; the film-making brave and defiant.

While this may lack the emotional clout of The Muppets star/co-writer Jason Segel's original reboot (leading man Ricky Gervais doesn't really do feelings), it doesn't skimp on good old-fashioned variety entertainment.
While it's hard not to trace the icy bloodletting and gangster banter back to American cinema, the frostiness of Skarsgård's performance remains resolutely Scandinavian.
Anyone who can refrain from weeping as Dorothy cries "Aunty Em, I'm frightened!" deserves to be locked in a tower for all eternity.
The visuals are dazzling, the voices expressive, and the end-credits sequence offers a laugh-out-loud appraisal of the madness of the animators' labour-intensive craft.
One of the most irresistibly uplifting films of the year - for any audience.
The meagre charms of the first act are soon squandered as this descends into straight-to-video stodge, progressing inexorably to a depressing climax. The book was better.
Lang's razor-sharp dissection of crime and punishment never puts a foot wrong.
Plaza steals the show with one foot in the grave, her rotting heroine ricocheting between adolescent snarkiness and cadaverous rage, a lethal combination of which no one around her has the measure.
I counted three laughs in this wannabe bawdy comedy of errors, and one of them was a Breaking Bad gag so far past its tell-by date that even I got the joke.
Plays like Moneyball-lite ...
An ambitious and engagingly authentic adaptation of Bola Agbaje's Olivier award-winning play.
Suicide is no laughing matter, but there are some wry smiles in this changeably moody indie-pic about self-destructive siblings.
There are light and fluffy pleasures to be had from this disposable rom-com ...
It's visceral, rebellious fare.
Never before has "Ghhrrrrr" meant so much or conveyed such depth of character.

Director Owen Gower mixes plentiful archive footage with contemporary interviews to cut through the media rhetoric about rioting pickets and paint an altogether more alarming portrait of a carefully orchestrated state crackdown.
It's not entirely unlikable, but there's nothing here to match the charm of the movies this imitates, nor justify the mood swings that it signally fails to negotiate.
