Rock's crass reliance on misogynist hooker gags and hot-sauce-up-the-ass homophobia routines means that an Adam Sandler cameo hardly seems out of place.
Lively does a good line in aloof, and if Huisman never convinces as the object of her desire then the narrative's peripheral relations more than fill the emotional gap.

Director Jon Wright, who directed the rambunctious monster-movie Grabbers, makes the most of his limited resources, imbuing the action with an oddly endearing sense of string-and-glue DIY youthfulness.
You have to admire a movie which takes a gold-star cast (Julianne Moore, Jeff Bridges, Alicia Vikander) and creates such an unpolishable turd.

The live-action sequences, in which Antonio Banderas chews the pirate scenery, may not live up to the Looney Tunes madness of the cartoons, but for sheer head-scrambling craziness this is hard to beat.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A splendidly anarchic portrait of a world on the verge of a nervous breakdown.
Can they trust each other? Of course not. Do we care? Not really.
The ramshackle but likable results will go down well with a cup of tea at what will doubtless be packed matinee screenings.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Beauty and the Beast with bared teeth.
Not exactly a crowd-pleaser, perhaps, but a bold jab at popular film-making that catches the audience with its guard down.
[A] quietly beguiling tale of an ageing gay couple who have been together for decades ...

Considering how much of the film consists of a single group of people becoming increasingly unhinged in a suburban living room, it's impressive how effectively Byrkit manages to suggest multiple realities and ominous other worlds.
Paranoid sound design and woozy atmospherics accentuate the film's more experimental aspects.
This adaptation of EL James's BDSM potboiler struggles to make a spanking cinematic silk purse out of its notoriously tin-eared source.

As we watch (and listen), we are swept away on a tide of changing social attitudes to race, gender and sexuality, the singularity of love splintered into kaleidoscopic reflections of desire and devotion.
movie_title: Love Is All: 100 Years of Love & Courtship (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The laddish humour undercuts director Andres Dussan's stated attempt to "use mainstream comedy to raise awareness of this sad reality" of fatherless families.
Despite the whiff of reality TV, only the very hard-hearted could fail to be charmed.

In compact, economical form, DuVernay sets out her table: the juxtaposition of domestic intimacy and institutional violence; the tension between the personal and political; the vivid interplay between the historical and the contemporary.
I was unprepared for the transcendent final moments, which left me suddenly and unexpectedly in tears.
It's stark and chilly, with an oddly engaging death's-mask grin.
When it comes to bonkers, overcooked, overambitious sci-fi, writer/directors Andy and Lana Wachowski really are in a world of their own.
I laughed more than I expected, spurred on by the fact that in doing so I was exercising a basic democratic right.
With the animators' thumbprints everywhere in evidence, this is properly tactile fare; I could feel it scrubbing my soul clean like a cinematic pumice stone.
The films are rich and diverse, moving from the warm humour of Cate Blanchett reconnecting with her mother-in-law to a battered Rose Byrne having visions of Jesus.
I found myself going with it for about two thirds of the time, seduced by its sweetness, suspicious of its sexuality ... occasionally exasperated by its incessant shaggy-doggedness.
[The victims'] voices are powerful and appalling, and it is to Broomfield's credit that they are heard here.
An origins story ripe with innocence and loss, this anime-inflected treat harks back to Disney's big-hearted heritage even as it looks forward towards new worlds of innovation.

Rondón turns a deceptively simple coming-of-age tale into a vibrant treatise upon a raft of disparate issues ... with authenticity, integrity and, perhaps most impressively, a transcendent sense of levity.
For the most part it's brash, boisterous fare, cocking unsubtle snooks at its generic predecessors ...
Director Stephen Daldry rediscovers the upbeat oomph that powered his debut feature Billy Elliot, finding hope and humour amid the squalor and violence of the narrative's darker turns.
If this Nobel prize laureate is not a major world leader by the time she's 30, then there is something irreparably wrong with the world.
Solidly MOR fare that should be propping up Channel 5's Friday night schedule sometime very soon.
Offers a cornucopia of spectacularly trashy clips that will leave you laughing, screaming and squirming - sometimes all at once.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Encore!
Some may find it intolerable, but this latterday western has much more to offer than misery.
A melancholic psychodrama about identity, love, and the eye of the beholder.
It's a movie of ideas rather than spectacle (Philip K Dick's dreamy electric sheep are inevitably invoked) with some well realised visual effects (a la Ex Machina) giving it genre legs.

The whole thing plays like Thunderbirds Goes to Hell and will doubtless offend all those numskulls who complained about the BBC's transmission of Jerry Springer: The Opera. For that alone, it gets my vote.
A poignant gem, very different in tone to the director's most celebrated works, Grave of the Fireflies and Only Yesterday, but no less worthy of praise and admiration.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Heaven knows what Brian De Palma (originally slated to direct) would have made of it, but nuts-and-bolts man Simon West, with whom Statham remade The Mechanic, keeps things simple.
Steve Martin has fun as the pompous Captain Smek, but this remains little more than colourfully inoffensive.
The notions are lofty and the players sincere, but the film itself is fatally overcooked.

Dorval and Clément are both exceptional, their brilliantly controlled performances contrasting with the explosive energy of rising star Pilon, who looks set to burst out of the screen and into the auditorium.
Swerving between pink-hued small-town satire and visceral gore, The Voices aims for the ghoulish humour of Eating Raoul or Parents - and, for the most part, misses.

Schwentke cranks up the action enough to keep us distracted, with well-oiled scenes of renegades jumping freight trains, and simulated cliffhangers involving flying fiery buildings offering several edge-of-your-seat moments.
A novel by Jean-Patrick Manchette provides the source material, but the only real "auteur" here is Morel, for whom this is very much more of the same.
For the most part ... it's a film about Neeson punching and shooting people while looking a bit bedraggled and a touch hungover.
In Nazi-occupied France, the bucolic yet class-riven life of the small town of Bussy is turned upside down by the arrival of refugees from Paris and jackbooted soldiers from Berlin.
While the story is somewhat schematic (you can plot the vectors of the narrative from the angles of the opening moves), the performances are absolutely lovely ...
Egged on by a swirling piano score that cranks up the melodramatic tension, this is enjoyably twisty nonsense ...
Splendidly lusty fare, its feet deep in the mud of the English countryside, its head in the lens-flared glare of a dreamy tragi-romantic sky.
Cinematographer Lutz Konermann captures the backbreaking beauty of it all, while director Pacha finds her way into the very heart of this timeless ritual.
The subject matter may be tough, and the end-point inevitable, but the message we take away is defiant and ultimately uplifting.
This dreamy/nightmarish weirdie finds Araki reining in his anarchic excesses with rewarding results, as his satirical sensuality reaps the benefits of a heavily orchestrated deadpan formality.
Despite its navel-gazing tendencies, this retains a spicily frank comedic edge, laced with the kind of bitingly quotable epithets you'll wish you'd thought of yourself.
The film never quite escapes the grip of the genre cliches with which it wrestles.
It's sporadically gripping but ultimately rather frustrating fare, leaving us intrigued enough by the conspiracy-theory backstory to want hard documentary evidence rather than mere dramatic licence.
Too tonally conflicted to engage our sympathies.
Like its subject, this documentary is powerful, honest, and empowering. Bravo.
Jesus wept, Vince Vaughn has done it again - kicking the putrefying corpse of feel-bad scrotal comedy around our screens with the dead-eyed stare of the fiscally medicated.

The crash-bang-wallop set pieces are economically choreographed and efficiently edited, but their real weight comes from the sense of brooding menace established in interim sequences in which not very much appears to be happening.
It's a relief when the narrative abandons its verbose antiheroes and turns instead to Moss's silently expressive face, which speaks volumes.

While it's good to see Rare Exports director Jalmari Helander dropping a Hollywood A-lister into the European wilds ... this cheekily ridiculous Boy's Own adventure falls awkwardly between target audiences ...
While the 3D beasts are undeniably impressive, their human counterparts remain resolutely two-dimensional thanks to a script that mistakes tone-deaf jumps and starts for emotional arcs.

A sublimely modulated blend of laughter and tears, a film that cuts to the very heart of profound personal loss without ever losing sight of the fact that life, in all its chaotic comedy, carries on regardless.
Committed performances from the two leads provide ballast, although the inevitable Oprah coda feels a little too much like a sales pitch.
Roberts is already a singular screen presence, and here acquits himself confidently behind the camera, handling the film's shifting tones with nicely cracked off-kilter humour.
Plaudits to Pattinson for once again taking the tougher route, downplaying his own matinee-idol charms for something less attractive but more adventurous.
"Don't get emotional about real estate," warns Carver, but that's exactly what we do as Bahrani and his cast crank up the tension in gut-wrenching fashion.
In a highly nuanced central performance, Marshall is both engaging and evasive, perfectly matching the fluid tone of Tucker Green's enigmatic urban parable.
Poyart goes for sub-Fincher flash throughout, making the whole thing look like a slightly creepy commercial with pop-promo set dressing and risible VFX "visualisations".
There's much to admire about this Morwenna Banks-scripted tale of two soulmates facing life-changing events.

No matter how close he becomes to the family ("he's not my uncle," Bob is forced to explain at one point), McAllister somehow keeps our focus on the fact that this is all a microcosm of a more global crisis.
There may be an interesting idea lurking in here somewhere, but any subversiveness is lost amid cod-indie gurning and comic bum notes.
Best to let the film's mesmerising tableaux descend upon you in the dreamy darkness, then sift its haunting memories for precise meaning in the hours, days and weeks that follow.
Nicely balancing its historically literate gags with broad knockabout slapstick, Bill is a crowd-pleasing treat that should tickle audiences young and old alike.
Powerful sound design effectively accentuates the sense of stormy isolation, giving the mountain the last word.
There are a few chuckles along the way, but only the scenery has any real depth.

Hinging on the double-barrelled blast of Tom Hardy's bang-on central performance(s), Legend is a brash, cartoonish affair, happy to bask in the reflected glory of its subjects' bizarre cultural icon status.
Emera is indeed a winning presence, and it would take a hard heart not to be moved by her rendition of Michel Sardou's Je Vole ...
This is terribly pedestrian.
Bring back The Last Airbender!
Aidan Gillen works his sublimely suspicious swagger as the clearly untrustworthy Janson, while Patricia Clarkson goes once again for ice queen, even in the midst of a battlefield.
The heady cocktail of politics, religion, blowjobs and murder is catnip for Ferrara, although anyone not versed in the controversies of Salò may leave the film none the wiser.
Ricki's life may be chaotic but the film hits the high notes when it counts, in rambunctious, crowd-pleasing fashion.
The film's primary colour palette provides a satirical antidote to cinema's more familiar gangsta hues.
It's a troubling piece that confronts both depression (suicide is a recurrent theme) and creativity.
The nice-westerners-v-murderous-foreigners vibe ... blossoms into shrieking xenophobia.
Andrews walks a fine line between the literary and the cinematic, studiously sidestepping mawkishness without recourse to emotional detachment.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Martian delivers on both intergalactic spectacle and feet-in-the-soil character drama.
Nourizadeh seems too seduced by the action set pieces to keep his eyes on the characters.
I actually hid my eyes from the laser-projected 3D Imax image at one point, overwhelmed by the sheer visceral spectacle of it all.
The result is typically idiosyncratic; often intriguing, sometimes insightful, occasionally exasperating.
While Spectre may not be the equal of its immediate predecessor, it's still bang on target in delivering what an audience wants from this seemingly indestructible franchise ...
Built upon Brando's archive of self-analysing audio tapes, Stevan Riley's intimate documentary gets under the actor's skin to reveal a troubled, fragile, self-obsessed soul.

Brand emerges as exasperating company - variously intelligent, amusing and insufferable - but Noel Gallagher steals the show, declaring that he'll only buy into Brand's revolution if he can be the Duke of Manchester.
Eschewing familiar vistas, Fleck and Boden take us on a tour of boarded facades and crumbling casinos light-years away from the glamour of Vegas or Atlantic City.
Terry Norris steals the show as the irrepressible grandpa who has little intention of putting his rakish fighter-pilot past behind him.

A pulsing soul-power soundtrack, extensive and rare archive footage and fiercely honest contemporary interviews drive Stanley Nelson's blistering account of the rise and fall of the Black Panther party.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's hokey as hell, but The Crazies director Breck Eisner plays it like a video game and keeps the teen fan-boy market onside by ensuring that you can't throw a rune stone without hitting a member of the LOTR/Game of Thrones/Dark Knight cast.
Crimson Peak is one of the year's most handsomely mounted productions. More importantly, it is a film with a palpably beating heart ...
It all gets a bit lost in the woods, but there's enough finely honed madness in the corridors of the hotel to cover the price of a room.
Cutting between archive footage and new film of the interviewees listening silently to their testimony, Loushy reveals a soul-searching history of disillusionment, self-doubt and raw regret.
For the most part this is as flimsy as Tinkerbell's wings: big on gossamer sparkle, low on substance.
Engagingly sympathetic portrayals of stoical working women and harassed railway guards keep us on side as the action rattles through familiar generic junctions.

Proving once again that, with the exception of Punch-Drunk Love, Adam Sandler is at his most tolerable when you can't see him, this perfunctory animation sequel provides innocuous pre-Halloween/half-term distraction.

Seasoned pros Frears and screenwriter John Hodge handle the sharp corners of the story with aplomb, although there's little here that wasn't covered in Alex Gibney's superior 2013 documentary The Armstrong Lie.
Co-writer and star Brett Goldstein holds it all together very amiably, while Catherine Tate, Natalia Tena and Ruth Sheen provide solidly entertaining support.
Polsky's documentary is nominally about ice hockey, but culture and politics provide the driving force as the Russians go head to head with the Americans in a battle of ideology, economics and art.

While Sicario may be guilty of exoticising the "murder capital" reputation of Juárez and its environs, it does so in a way that is horribly efficient, exploiting our anxieties and expectations with cruel precision.
Fukunaga's self-shot widescreen cinematography and Dan Romer's swirling score lend an epic sweep to the harrowing, heartbreaking narrative.
Straddles the line between psychological suspense and supernatural horror.
This is an important story and Suffragette tells it without stylistic fuss or frills in solidly down-the-line fashion.
Naff jokes about rape, the Holocaust, and the wretchedness of Fresno leave laughter in short supply as the shrieky action pinballs self-consciously from barmitzvahs to pet cemeteries.
Watching this overegged hybrid docu-horror investigation of sleep paralysis, I found myself fighting the urge to snooze.
Offering a balanced but impassioned account of the case, Silver, director of 2013's Who Is Dayani Cristal?, puts the viewer in the position of the jury ...
Nothing to get upset about.
This is very much Shakespeare in the wild, its poetry visual rather than verbal.
Panthaki and Akhtar have droll double-act chemistry, McClure is indomitably entertaining (as ever) and the low-budget vibe produces a few good giggles.
What exactly is the point of a Transporter movie without Jason Statham?
Finlay picks apart this real-life Bubba Ho-Tep tale, offering a dizzying analysis of the madness of the Orion myth alongside a movingly sympathetic account of Ellis's unsung talent.
movie_title: Orion: The Man Who Would Be King (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Courtenay and Rampling are at the top of their game throughout, drawing us into their hopes and fears even as we watch them from a distance.
While the jumbled time-loops and neo-nuclear family gags make for some initial reboot fun, Genisys soon becomes little more than an overblown karaoke rehash of the sci-fi riffs of yesteryear.
At times it's too schematic for its own good, but there's a musical quality which harmonises the script's rockier edges, and the use of diegetic song is powerful and engaging.
Excerpts from unfinished films offer glimpses of what might have been, while Welles in discussion remains an unsurpassed raconteur.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A flickering story that blends intrigue, industrial espionage, and possibly even murder.

Confessional with punchlines - that's how Amy Winehouse described her songwriting, providing the key to Asif Kapadia's sober, unsensational and overwhelmingly sad film about her short and volatile life.
Brice keeps a forgiving eye on his characters' foibles, teasing rather eviscerating them to unexpectedly sympathetic ends.
Admirably lacking in installation-style pretentiousness.
Although the opening "minions through history" sequence proves a very tough act to follow, this slice of burbling slapstick animation did keep me grinning and giggling throughout.

Those with an adolescent nostalgia for video-nasty era degradation/retribution may be mildly titillated, but Lynch has neither the wit nor desire to raise this above the level of faux-retro fanboy fantasy.
There's a lot of in-joke love (and in-crowd cameos) in Peter Bogdanovich's throwback screwball romcom. Sadly the laughs are far fewer.
With its weirdly lyrical portrait of frontier life, this blackly comic oddity balances on the generic knife edge between the western and the musical.
Chilling, damning stuff.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: McKellen nurtures his character's changing nature with affection and grace.
Like all of Sparks's stories it's corny as hell, but there's an unabashed, old-fashioned charm that gradually warms the cockles and moistens the eye.
The dramatic final act is audacious, yet wholly in keeping with the film's bubbling themes of love and war.
Sheer brilliance.
Compared to this, Sex and the City 2 looks like an art film in which earnest radicals read from the works of Karl Marx and Andrea Dworkin.
Unsurprisingly, it's a mess.
Some crunchy action adds blood but not meat.
Horribly real, an urgent and alarming account of a crisis so hellishly labyrinthine it's hard to see how anyone can escape its widening web of violence, extortion and corruption.
Looks even starker and more jarringly isolated today than it did in 1961.
Will disappoint even the most undiscerning viewer.
Intriguing on personal and political levels.
London Road exists in the quarter tones between speech and song, the lilt of voices drifting almost imperceptibly into melody.
Browning's sympathies are clear; if there are "freaks" on display here, they are not the versatile performers to whom the title seems to allude.
Tatum's autobiographical experiences still feed into Reid Carolin's script, but the edge of the original has been lost, character playing second G-string to choreography and costume.

O'Reilly is terrific as the sneery discontent at the centre of the madcap maelstrom, while Rima Te Wiata walks a wonderfully fine line between pathos and aggravation as the long-suffering/insufferable mum whose forced smile is about to crack.
More formally traditional than its predecessor, but no less distressing.
The notes of this tune are tear-jerkingly familiar, and there's never any doubt about the final chorus, replete with a descant line of convenient illness and last-minute substitution.
The whole family are terrific company and Magali captures both the beauty and the bleakness of the environment in which they live and work.

It's Hawkins, Mitchell and Jackson (the latter playing his own father) who really light up the screen, bringing energy and vitality to the film even as it misses the wider picture (and stirs up old rivalries) ...
That none of it makes any sense is not a problem, but the failure to raise the temperature despite endless shootouts, punch-ups, car chases et al is a fatal flaw.
A return to intriguing form for Zac Efron after the patience-testing trials of That Awkward Moment and Bad Neighbours.
This increasingly ramshackle thriller somehow manages to bodge many of its key plot points, leaving the narrative as badly maintained as the rundown houses it occupies.
This shoestring-budget doc lends a non-judgmental ear to opinions that range from the eye-opening to the jaw-dropping.
It's hard to imagine even Hangover fans being satisfied by such middling vulgarity.
Arterton has flirty fun with the title role, and her scenes with Luchini boast a satirical crackle that's missing elsewhere.
"I don't want to watch any more," declares terrorised youth Dylan. We know exactly how he feels.
Horribly convincing performances add exploitative heft, while Johan Van Essche's production design makes the Boschian hell seem all too real.
This is the work of someone coming to terms with their past, transmuting the traumas of childhood into the building blocks of adult awareness.
Talking to Temple, Johnson seems like a man whose eyes have been opened for the first time, finally relishing the experience of life on Earth.
Named after Hindu deities, the six boys (their sister is barely glimpsed on camera) prove easy company - attractive, articulate, and engagingly enthusiastic.
Reynolds's failure to display the faintest trace (verbal, physical) of Kingsley's character negates any potential mind/ body tension. Self/less? Point/less!
This superb Irish animation from the director of 2009's The Secret of Kells is a treat; an enchanting and very moving "family film".

Salgado proves an adept and compassionate storyteller, his training as an economist providing sociopolitical insight into the suffering (manmade rather than natural) that threatens to engulf his work.
Ted 2 confirms that Seth MacFarlane really is nowhere near as funny as he thinks.
Although the tone is uneven, there are plenty of sharp one-liners ... and snappy cineliterate swipes at everyone from Tyler Perry to Robert Altman.
From the grisly punning title to the low-rent action sequences, this really is less fun than double maths.

What starts out as a Festen-lite exercise in public discomfort mutates into something more intriguingly deconstructive, although the layers of artifice ultimately prevent this from getting beneath the surface of its long-buried cruelties and rivalries.
After a while, the cameras start to flash "low battery" and "power save" warnings, but only the cacophony of booming rumbles and loud BANGS stopped me from drifting into "sleep mode".
Not so f-ant-astic, then, just a little ant-iclimatic.
The result is disappointingly televisual, the verdict wholly predictable.
The plot may be gossamer-thin but the characters are sturdily drawn and life on the farm engrossingly evoked.
Friedel has something of the steely vulnerability of a young Al Pacino, but remains shackled by the plodding material.
That so much of it rings true is a credit to the film-makers; that Wilson lived some (if not all) of it is a reminder of his matchless alchemical magic.
Although there is at times a feeling of contrivance and faux-naïf innocence, there is a lightness of touch -- poetry even -- in the way the film is put together.
I liked it on the whole; the film had suspense; it had drama.
A film so assured and professional that it makes one suspect the presence of a thriving industry that has for years gone unacknowledged in Europe.
El Cantante has to legitimize its subject before it can immortalize him; and in the effort, it makes the mistake of letting a star get in the way of the truth.
Cohen here is ever the model of grace and dignity around his peers, if not exactly entirely at peace with himself.
Ramin Bahrani's talent for orchestrating sequences of tightly wound tension is in full bloom here, as is his complementary knack for quieter grace notes.
You've got a romantic comedy that ain't much of either.
How refreshing for a film to stare death in the face and find compassion reflected in its gaze.
A film with meat and bones sorely lacking in heart.
This is a film about eroticism and passion that is neither erotic nor passionate.
It's most affecting when its characters are at their least guarded, but as Nour, Salma, and Laila are hurt by those closest to them, the film pulls back toward more formulaic expressions of conflict.
Director Pat Collins's approach to visual composition is more interesting in theory than practice.
Everyone's Hero is an after-school special stretched to feature-film length.
The film wraps mindless cartoon violence and a few fart jokes around life lessons about friendship and responsibility. Kids should like it; parents won't mind it.
A fascinating look back on the major social and political events of the second half of the 20th century and early years of the 21st ...
movie_title: The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument (2014)

movie_review_blurb: At almost three hours long the film drags a bit, but you'll have more fun at Om Shanti Om than most of the Hollywood movies released today. Watching it, you can't help but smile.
It's supremely silly and filled with crater-sized plot holes, but it's a profoundly moving film, too - about trauma, about loneliness, about aging and family.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What worked in Shields's quiet, contemplative novel about a family in crisis falls flat on screen.
Harrowing, heartbreaking and humane ...
At least the monsters, when compared with their co-stars, have some personality.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jonathan Levine's film displays an intelligence lacking in most teen slasher pics.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Tower is King's ultimate roller coaster - twisting and stomach-clenching and terrifying but, above all, fun. If only this version was as thrilling a ride.
It's a profoundly weird film but hypnotic nonetheless.
movie_title: Let the Corpses Tan (Laissez bronzer les cadavres!) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The lead actors are both marvellous... Yet the film's most impressive performance might come from director Dominic Cooke, who has delivered an assured, wistful debut.
It's somewhat amusing - especially Tom Sturridge, who turns Lord Byron into poetry's version of Jack Sparrow - but immediately forgettable.
Vegans and animal lovers might have a tough time stomaching parts of the film.

[Emma] Thompson who carries the film, both literally - she's rarely off-screen - and emotionally; the burden of this particular case weighs down almost every line of dialogue, registers in almost every expression on her face.

... for the most part the cast fails to support the weighty material. Still, the essence and importance of [Richard] Wagamese's book - both the brutality and the beauty - shines through, more vital than ever.
It's a by-the-numbers profile, complete with the requisite visit to his childhood home, but, partway through, it becomes a rather piercing portrait of a man constantly doubting himself.

Lacks Casino Royale's narrative drive, and is less than the sum of its parts, [but] those parts are often terrific. See it for them, and see it for Craig's fully-formed Bond: angry, icily unsentimental, and fleetingly borderline psychotic at the close.
Parker's script is as sharp as a wiseguy's suit, his attention to period and genre detail a constant joy, and he coaxes scarily poised performances from his young performers.
This film is a towering achievement, and the next installment can't come soon enough.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Even now, it's distinctly unnerving.

This fusion of sci-fi, action, romance and comedy could have been a dreadful mess, were it not for writer-director Robert Zemeckis and co-writer Bob Gale's refusal to let a loose line or idea escape their pens.

It places the traumatised but still astonishingly high-functioning company in national and historical context, peels away its glamorous mask, and lets the backstage dramas of its various damatis personae unfold.

Whether watching Kirk and Sulu skydive from space, a rural Mid-West dotted with vast interstellar towers, or Kirk do battle with a very ill-tempered beastie on a frozen moon, it's hard not to gape in wonder.
It's Remember the Titans on the basketball court. Count it right up there with the best of Disney's fine sports flicks.
The story plays out predictably with a happy ending -- think The Natural on Wimbledon's Centre Court -- and all in all, it's a decent romantic comedy.
Like me, you'll probably feel inclined to watch it again.
The film has its sappy, predictable moments, but the gorgeous cinematography, apt direction and fine acting more than compensate. Think of it like Chariots of Fire on the golf course.
Its main flaws are an overabundance of sports-movie clichés and hackneyed phrases, but at least the final game doesn't have a predictable ending; I'll give it that much.
You'll leave the theater somewhat emotionally spent -- feeling like you've been tackled by a 220-pound linebacker -- but it's worth the ride. One of the best sports movies ever.
This true story seems like it can only be explained as 'a God thing,' and indeed, how else could something so extraordinary take place without divine intervention?
The film shows that Intelligent Design should be on the table for discussion. But if you're looking for ammo to argue your Darwinist friends under the table, look elsewhere.
Like a Michael Moore documentary, Griggs plays fast and loose with statistics -- enough to raise my own B.S. Meter and lower my trust. I kept asking, "Is this the whole truth?"
The film ends with a beautiful scene that will tug at your heartstrings.

The performances are strong, the scenes and sets authentic, the camerawork excellent. Though parts of the film are difficult to watch, it is beautifully composed and filmed. Now if only I could say the same for the dialogue.

[Blomkamp is] back on track with Chappie, the latest in a long line of films about how artificial intelligence inevitably morphs into something far beyond what its Makers -- er, programmers -- intended, sometimes with a sinister turn, sometimes not.
Mirren is her usual stellar self, but the pleasant surprise here is Ryan Reynolds.
There are too many messages here, and too many of them mixed or conflicting.
Charming and fascinating.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Here's the thing: You can wrestle those Big Questions, if you want. Me? I mostly just wanted to see how awesome dinosaurs would look with today's CGI. And people running for their lives.
Ruffalo, one of our best actors, has proven that he can handle just about any role thrown his way.

As the Olympic trials draw near, it's fun to watch them really go for it, and you'll be rooting for them to make the team. And no matter what happens next, their childhoods remain sane and very intact.
Moverman and cinematographer Bobby Bukowski let their shots linger long, almost uncomfortably so. But that's the point. This film forces you, like George's character, to wait for something to happen.
It's about time somebody made a documentary about this remarkable woman.
You'll root for these underdogs, all right, but hopefully for deeper reasons than just winning races and leaving those jerk opponents in their dust.
John Sayles takes on a genre movie and makes something that ends up as distinctive as his trademark ensemble films.
it's original, sharply funny, and rather moving
movie_title: Ghost Dog - The Way of the Samurai (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The surprise element here is that the film takes Monica's career, and her love of the game, as seriously, probably more seriously, than it does Quincy's.
Hugely funny film that mixes knowing satire with winning stupidity, and has Martin and Murphy in form they have rarely managed in recent years.
Carrie Fisher, in her final Star Wars performance, is the heart and soul of the film, stealing scenes with ease and on more than one occasion bringing lumps to the throat.
A flat, tired rehash of teen movie story tropes, the film attempts to have it both ways by winkingly acknowledging its secondhand origins.
In some ways, the filmmakers have created something too authentic in spirit to the original film, as it also fairly quickly becomes a plodding chore to watch.
It boils down to this: Thai girl fighting. Is that enough of a movie for you?
The original handful of Friday films had a certain low-rent elegance about them, and this slickly done, dimly lighted, whiplash-edited update loses that too.
A movie where the only conception of life seems to come from other movies makes for no kind of movie at all.
Passable in its efficiency, Fired Up! is less offensive than it might have been while also managing to be staggeringly uninspired.
The attitude displayed by Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience back toward those fans comes across as a curious mixture of shameless pandering and discreet contempt.
Scott Walker: 30 Century Man chronicles the career of musician Scott Walker, an enigmatic figure whose influence far outreaches his relative obscurity.
A shockingly mundane disappointment taken on its own and a deeply misguided refraction of the original.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Myrick does an admirable job of spinning tension from a group of guys mostly standing around, but too often the film's portentous tone seems more silly than suspenseful.

By turns playful and melancholy, provocative and sentimental, all three of the shorts that make up Tokyo! seem like direct responses to the city itself as well as being jumping-off points for each director's personal quirks.
Haunting suffers for its need to be sold as a straight-up horror film, and the fact it has been seemingly retrofitted as such.

The story never fully blends the idea of Singer's rediscovery of his artistic voice -- and even something as simple as why he was a children's performer in the first place is never addressed -- with his personal renewal.
The filmmaker's overreliance on oddball characterizations and easy-bake kookiness often derails her seemingly loftier intentions.
A leaden murder mystery with a clunky structure that swings back and forth between 1958 and 2008, Stolen wastes the talents of a reasonably good cast.
Strange, disorienting and unexpectedly affectionate.
Represents much of what is wonderful and fresh about the recent wave of ultra-low-budget American independent filmmaking.
The heart of both the story and its telling do help in smoothing over other deficiencies, sweet and disarming in its belief that something like a baseball game can make a bigger difference.

Though its excessive cheerleading is a major flaw, Faythe Levine's quietly uplifting Handmade Nation functions as an inspirational snapshot of current craft culture, a series of scenes from a scene more than a definitive document.
Perhaps the best thing that can be said about My Name Is Bruce is that Bruce Campbell has in fact appeared in worse movies.
Luck by Chance is a sharp look at how stardom is both desired and created and the personal and professional toll it can take on those who pursue it.

IMDB lists the title of the film as "Ip Man Zero," an obvious nod to its coming before parts one and two, but unfortunately, it's also an inadvertent comment on what this particular film has to offer.
movie_title: The Legend Is Born: Ip Man (Yip Man chinchyun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The story of the unsolved abductions and the man who might have become the scapegoat for a community is troubling enough. No big-screen trickery is required.

Despite its director's disinterest in letting people in, there is nevertheless something exciting about a movie this uncompromised, in which the big change from the book to the screen actually toughens up the story instead of watering it down.
Zesty fun for its actors, Feast is at once a sly parody of the celebrity-chef culture spawned by all the cable cooking shows and competitions, and a creepy little chamber-piece.
It's likely the best anti-Christmas Christmas movie since Bad Santa.
A pleasant, charming knockabout with a playfully imaginative sense of wit and a pleasingly assured visual style.
With 1968: Tunnel Rats, Boll continues to show himself to be an unusually versatile filmmaker -- outrageously awful in any genre.
The film is bad -- not good-bad, tacky-bad or fun-bad, just plain awful and nearly unwatchable.

Dragon Hunters is sort of a lightweight, inoffensive programmer if what you want your children exposed to is mindless and pointless audio-visual entertainment rather than, you know, reading a book or stepping outside.
One would only hope that a film about death and dying wouldn't have to feel quite so lifeless.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkably compact and engaging overview of the history and ideology of this urban outlaw art form.
The story of a man (Aaron Eckhart) grappling with middle-age ennui at work and at home feels done to death, as does the distracting addition of a spunky rich-kid high schooler.
The images captured by Herzog and cinematographer Peter Zeitlinger are dazzling all on their own, finding the disorienting psychedelia that is nature at its weirdest.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Written with more bite, the premise might hold up, but as executed here by Tolan, it is a soft-hearted, haphazard mess.
For a film that seems to pride itself on its depiction of prison-reality, it feels extremely movie-phony.
When a single episode of your sister's TV show contains hotter action and more story structure than the movie you are in, it may be time to reboot. Murder.com is strictly CTRL+ALT+delete.

[Director] Jarrold seems too often to consciously be making an in-quotation-marks classy picture, much like last year's Atonement, in which the costumes and setting are just so, but the human drama gets lost amid the pictorial pleasantries.
Eight Miles High, based on the memoirs of Uschi Obermaier, wants to be both a tangy piece of Eurosleaze and an overview of one woman's transformations from the heady days of the 1960s onward.
Elegy seems to mourn for the wrong things, making its self-examining characters seem merely narcissistic and more than a little pathetic.
The film gets the scummy patina right, all phony-Leone dusty trails, but while everybody on screen looks to be enjoying themselves, it is no fun to watch.
An empty enterprise that provides a few moments of goofy fun, Mirrors reflects back nothing.
A preposterously inept, fabulously amateurish piece of vanity moviemaking.
If it were a parody of relationship-youth pictures, In Search of a Midnight Kiss would maybe be tolerable, but writer-director Alex Holdridge seems to be playing it with a straight face.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An elegant and deceptively straightforward dramatic thriller.

The problems that plague the movie land squarely with the writer, director and producer, Deborah Kampmeier, who has crafted a howler of a bad script, shows little affinity for working with actors and displays no visual sense behind the camera.
Despite its superficial lip-service to self-actualization/realization, there has to be more to life than what Beverly Hills Chihuahua is putting out there, which is fit for neither man nor beast.
...It wants so desperately to be a Hollywood-style story of the little guy triumphing over the big guy that it races past much of the subtlety of Kearns' story...
At times stirring, inspiring and thoughtful.
Occasionally sharp but never quite as smartly formed as it could be, this Sex Drive is only partly worth the trip.

The HSM series has always been playful and high-spirited, with a refreshing emphasis on collective action and the importance of group effort over the individual, and there's nothing in High School Musical 3: Senior Year to upset the formula.
This movie about wanting to make a movie doesn't make for much of a movie.
By turns exuberant and goofy and mushy and yearning.

Do these heartbreaking stories exist in the real world? Yes, yes, they do. Does dramatizing these stories with nothing to add except a certain cruel wallowing in the existence of unspeakable human depravity serve any real purpose? No, no, it does not.
A Good Day certainly shows Dortch as a talent to watch. Whether he does anything more with that talent will be up to him.
movie_title: A Good Day to Be Black & Sexy (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The story is a mishmash of adventure-fantasy tropes.
Cthulhu isn't awful, but it isn't particularly compelling either, as Glidark and Cogswell make their message so plain that it robs the story of its broader mysteries.
Good but perhaps not good enough, "Meskada" can be thought of as solid letter-grade-B work.
Cox might yet again pull something astonishing from his ethos of trashcan poetry, but it simply didn't happen with "Repo Chick."
Better than it might have been yet still a definite letdown, a literary B-side turned into something not awful, just forgettable.

Not agile enough to make the idea of a contemporary small-town western really work, Stagliano instead simply cranks out a rather bland programmer doomed for the anonymity of a video store shelf or VOD queue.
Pulsing with a rowdy energy, the film works as both a sci-fi horror flick and a teen adventure film.

"Where the Road Meets the Sun" is earnest but inorganic, trying hard but uninvolving, with little to actually say about the big, mixed-up intersection of crazy and unbelievable that is Los Angeles at its best.
movie_title: Where The Road Meets The Sun (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cold Fish is wild, head-turning, stomach-churning stuff, and it makes a bracing addition to the overstuffed canon of serial-killer cinema.
Too well-intentioned for its own good.
Gibney and Ellwood struggle to create context for or make much sense of the vibrant hodge-podge of material that they excavated from the archives of Kesey, who died in 2001.

As he tells the story of a pair of teenage brothers looking to qualify for the Olympic boxing team and an even younger fighter trying to overcome a troubled childhood, Frimmer in essence loses the forest for the trees.
"3D Sex and Zen: Extreme Ecstasy" finds it is love, not sex, that rules the human heart, a sweet and conventional idea regardless of the technology of the film's projection.
This fourth "Spy Kids" picture isn't so much bad as it is just boring, lacking the buzz and brio of even some of the earlier entries in the series.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A drama of depth, nuance and ambition.
Unable to decide whether to pitch their story as chastely sweet or ridiculously raunchy, filmmakers Alex Gregory and Peter Huyck end up with something that just lays there flacid.
The film takes a startlingly long time to rev up, and even at less than 90 minutes feels thin and at moments like it is playing for time.
With dependably creepy character actor Sid Haig to goose things along as leader of the locals, "Creature" is delightfully dopey.
Why an actor would create a starring part for himself this thin and underdeveloped is beyond explanation.
Though it doesn't exactly have pretensions toward the rhythms of real life, the film does nail the breezy movie feeling of a buffed-and-polished romantic comedy.
Goes from funny to not funny in about the length of time it takes for the lawyers to get involved.
Offers a fascinating glimpse behind the scenes at the Spanish restaurant hailed as the most influential eatery in the world.
"Beware the Gonzo" isn't bad, it's just that for a film aiming to celebrate media rebellion it feels timid and unadventurous.
Sheridan can't ever quite get hold of the tone and falls back on a default dreaminess (the little girls play a shaky rendition of Beethoven's "Für Elise" more than once) that never quite convinces.
A fascinating, deeply felt film of wild, untamed emotions and probing insights.

Six has in essence backed himself into a rhetorical corner, leaving as perhaps the only option for his next stunt something in which the filmmaker Tom Six winds up with his mouth surgically attached to his own anus.
With its hefty running time, the film builds an unexpected emotional resonance, though never exactly sympathy...
Far and away the sharpest, most wildly aware film in the series.
It seems telling just how many other musicians were willing to participate in the documentary to attest to the outfit's influence.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: More lyrical tone poem than straightforward documentary.
"The Hammer" never quite brings the pain, in the parlance of pro wrestling, leaving the film feeling heartfelt but flat.
Sigur Rós fans are intensely devoted -- lore describes people passing out at shows in some sort of overwhelmed, ecstatic state -- and "Inni" finally gives some sense of why and how that might happen.

The film serves both as a welcome document and reminder of the group in its prime, while also creating a portrait of lives still in motion, grown men trying to move on from yet respect the work of their younger selves.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though the performers gamely try to make the most of what little they have to work with, the film is murky to look at and unfocused in its storytelling. "Dead Awake" is a deadly snore.

With its eager-to-please congeniality, it almost works, but with a pacing that is at once comfortably assured and frustratingly slack, like holding exactly to the speed limit on a stretch of open road, Larry Crowne never quite comes to life.
The film is somehow a disappointing combo of too-full and oddly empty.
From its title, "Alien Girl" seems to promise some kind of playful intergalactic adventure. That, it is not.

That a production this ambitious has been financed and distributed outside the studio system throws a curveball to anyone who thinks "independent film" can mean only urban moderns sitting in an apartment bemoaning their ennui.
As a film, it's pure and singular, but it's not quite fully formed enough to be what one could call truly visionary.
Directed by the perennially hollow Dominic Sena from a script by Bragi Schut, "Season of the Witch" is all seams. It never balances out its competing desires...
There are intriguing issues swirling around the film, but [director] Kofman never brings it to a boil, never finds the deeper, truer meaning inside the ideas he is grappling with.
Fun for fans and a healthy primer for those previously unaware, the film's overall air of fawning worship makes it feel softer than befits such a gruff, roguish figure.

The film's fight choreography is again handled by the legendary Sammo Hung - he also now has a supporting role and incredibly shot his own fight scenes while recuperating from heart surgery - and that alone makes the film worth checking out.
movie_title: Ip Man 2: Legend of the Grandmaster (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Andy Lau and Gong Li are appealing leads, but this Chinese-language carbon copy doesn't find a distinctive voice.
Without tension or suspense, the film is too gloomy and chaste to be a naughty exploitation picture but also too brainless to work as anything more real.
Strictly as a piece of filmmaking, Never Say Never is a bit of a mess.
A film so drained of entertainment or simple humanity it is difficult to relate to as anything other than industrial artifact.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An unexpectedly rich exploration of family bonds, blood rituals and the oftentimes zombie-like desire to assume the roles proscribed to each of us, played out with a sharp undertow of political allegory and darkly comic sensibility.
It's actually refreshing that Lussier and Farmer don't belabor the film's internal mythology of satanic cults, hell and the devil's administrative assistants.
A sly and pleasant-enough young-adult programmer that is more likeable than not.
Even at its most chaotic, the film never loses sight of the human toll of the increasingly over-the-top events it portrays.
Things might not go quite as Brügger planned, but as is so often the case, that seems to have been for the best.
"Elektra Luxx" has a playful, breezy sexiness that gives the world of the film, porn biz and all, a refreshing innocence.
Shows a certain amount of promise but often falls prey to easy emotional beats and an overall sentimentality when it should push for moments less obvious, more rare, true and insightful.
Wuershan's heavy hand, never letting up for a moment to allow any air or life to enter the film, cuts off the film's energy even as it rattles relentlessly on.
movie_title: The Butcher, The Chef And The Swordsman (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's easy to feel sucked into some kind of time warp back to the heyday of late-'90s post-Tarantino crime thrillers, cut-rate knockoffs filled with casually cartoonish violence, quippy patter, overtly flash filmmaking and incongruous pop tunes.
"The Last Godfather" is more harmlessly amiable than outright awful, though it might still be best to just forget about it.
Asked to convey a wide spectrum of emotional tones like confusion, shock, sadness, anger and oh, look out for the mountain lion, Brody does all he can to hold the screen.
In some ways this film's biggest failing is that it can't decide whose story it is telling, his or hers.
Although "Legend of the Fist" is slick, stylish and assured, it is also bloated and hollow, and seemingly without much sense of what actually is working.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A fitfully engaging effort that is most successful as a performance piece for actors Kat Dennings and Reece Thompson.
A hodgepodge of styles, "True Legend" works best as a freewheeling showcase for Yuen's dazzling fight sequences above any sort of cogent storytelling.
Would the film be easier to take in a more condensed form? Of course it would, but then it wouldn't be the singularly overwhelming oddity that it is.
"Great Revival" is in many ways the very definition of propaganda - it even ends with an image of a waving flag - but "Revival" is too harmlessly flabby to be taken quite that seriously.
movie_title: The Beginning of a Great Revival (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The saga of small-town strip mall taekwondo instructor Fred Simmons, The Foot Fist Way is the sort of nimble oddball discovery that one wishes would come along more often.
The Favor is that rare film that at every turn exhibits good taste and a sense of restraint.
Postal is largely just a byproduct of Boll's self-promotion, rendering the film itself, in essence, beside the point.
Among the biggest surprises of the year.
It's a film filled with hope and yearning, love misdirected and truer feelings found.
The film is perhaps best thought of as part cultural curiosity, part obscurantist's delight.

Gores certainly seems to be enjoying himself, and diplomacy and plain old good taste prevent one from saying much of anything about his screen performance. Arnold doesn't merit such kindness, nor does producer and director Penelope Spheeris.
It probably looked like a good idea on paper.
The animation style of Hoodwinked is dated by at least a handful of years, marked by that glassy smoothness that dominated previous generations of CGI.
You'd think that having gone to the trouble of writing, directing, producing and starring in April's Shower, Trish Doolan would have something to say.
... director David Rosenthal and his writing partner, Joseph M. Smith, simply don't come up with enough material to keep the laughs coming at a reasonable pace and never quite get a groove rolling.
An entry into the cycle of avenging teen-girl pictures, in which the filmmakers try gamely to put a unique spin on familiar material, but eventually fall back on by-the-numbers tropes.
The story, dialogue and animation here really are for-kids-only.
Down the Rabbit Hole makes teen sex comedies, action-chick sci-fi and the other usual multiplex chum seem like high-minded discourse.
movie_title: What the Bleep!? Down the Rabbit Hole (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Watching Americano is like hearing a long story about someone else's holiday, and while it seems everyone had a nice time, it's too bad they didn't shoot a better film while they were there.
There's a lot of talk here about religion, as well as plenty of gospel singing, but no sense of what these characters truly believe.
The low road always wins out.
movie_title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Cupo's script never quite settles on a point of view, toggling wildly from the wise-guy mechanics of loan sharks and race forms to the personal concerns of an expectant wife and a steady job.
As director, Farnsworth lets tricky visuals run roughshod over dramatic unity, while as a performer, his lack of screen presence makes him seem sullen and uninterested instead of darkly charismatic.
[Mo'Nique's] sassy forte may be talking so straight-up she sounds crazy, but she seems a little advanced to be doing 'yo mama' jokes.
There's no salvaging this.

Standing Still wants to be an honest, earnest look at the difficulties of growing up and moving on, but it remains stuck in such a fantasy-laden milieu that the characters never feel particularly real, and their problems seem phony and arbitrary.
Watt seems to want to say something about the role of fate and happenstance in creating connections between people, but she never quite brings the strands of her ideas together.
... a haphazard jumble.

While Slattery-Moschkau is obviously coming from a very earnest place -- a card before the final credits compares the annual budget for the pharmaceutical industry to that of her own film -- it doesn't make the overall effort any less clumsy.
The film just keeps circling, never narrowing in on who its characters truly are or where it wants to take them.

Although the filmmakers have succeeded in portraying a raw slice of street culture, they have also made something that seems unnecessarily stiff, foisting a structural conceit onto something that by its very nature is free-form and uncontainable.
Murray becomes less and less sure of where things are heading or what it is she is trying to get at, such that the last few reels feel perfunctory and unengaged.
Ethan Green may not exactly be fabulous, but it is pleasantly diverting.
movie_title: The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Recut and reassembled at just a little over two hours, the new version of the film is a staggering and bracing object, stylistically bold and hypnotically captivating.
Facing up to such nasty, untidy realities of modern coupledom would have given Dirty Love some of the edge it aspires to, but seriously lacks.
This is the kind of smug, listless product that the world, indie or otherwise, would be better off without.
Corpse Bride is a rather unblessed union.
Written, flatly, by David Kendall and directed, barely, by There's Something About Mary co-writer Ed Decter.
The film works no matter which side of the racial divide you're on, because nothing unites an audience quite like making fun of everyone.
Fans of Plympton's shorts may marginally enjoy the film, but it is doubtful this listless feature will win him any new viewers.
Myers' puppy-dog tenacity to that cast-iron tenet of low comedy, disarming and even somewhat charming in the first film, now has an air of careerist desperation about it.
Anchored by two fine performances, this bittersweet comedy about second chances just might signal a new beginning for the director as well.
Pretension, in its own way, is a form of bravery. For this reason and this reason only -- the power of its own steadfast, hoity-toity convictions -- Chelsea Walls deserves a medal.
Without the character detail and internal motivations that presumably exist in the novel, the film feels too schematic, a reduction to types going through the paces of plot.
Chai's structure and pacing are disconcertingly slack.
There ought to be a directing license, so that Ed Burns can have his revoked.
Writer-director Roger Avary comes into his own with The Rules of Attraction.
Despite apparent motives to the contrary, it ends up being, like [Seinfeld's] revered TV show, about pretty much nothing.
However sincere it may be, The Rising Place never quite justifies its own existence.
If missteps hold the film back from achieving the full grandeur it aims for, there is no denying the way it conjures a magic-realist American suburbia, rarely before brought so convincingly to life.

Director Charles Stone III fails to find a coherent grammar with which to shoot the band performances, leaving them flat and at a remove from the exuberant, pull-out-the-stops crowd pleasers they are presumably intended to be.
Writer-director Juan Carlos Fresnadillo makes a feature debut that is fully formed and remarkably assured.
The characters are never more than sketches ... which leaves any true emotional connection or identification frustratingly out of reach.
A disappointing hodgepodge that fails to tie up its conflicting strands of family drama and suspense thriller.
Relies on easy caricature over true character such that the film fails to build emotional momentum or resonance.
Though its heart is in the right place, this would-be feel-good sensation never puts the other pieces together.

Rivaling only George Lucas as Hollywood's reigning tech-obsessed gadget wizard, Cameron (who is never introduced, he's just there) seems pretty fascinated by this stuff, but as a filmmaker he has a hard time letting anybody else in on the appeal.
The film is tough going for all the wrong reasons.
This self-styled throwback to the down-and-dirty horror films of the 1970s and '80s never delivers what it definitely promises.
Exactly the kind of unexpected delight one hopes for every time the lights go down.
When huge chunks of character development and narrative exposition are relegated to a track announcer's running commentary, it can never be a good sign.

Director Erik Van Looy has filmmaking chops to spare, and while he has created a sharply shot and crisply paced film, he isn't able to make it all cohere, as the moving parts spin in place without any connection or harmony.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Conrad Pla turns in a performance of such staggering ineptitude that it almost (key word: almost) reaches a so-bad-it's-good, Plan 9 From Outer Space brilliance.

Director Meiert Avis is a veteran helmer of music videos, so while it is not entirely surprising that he has no feel for character or structure, it is strange that he doesn't breathe much life into the frequent musical performances and montages either.
A film that never quite manages to justify its existence.
More than just another Iraq-doc, Heavy Metal is a surprisingly up-close look at the toll of the war on young people, and how they still have dreams and still want to jam, party and get down.
Mines the comic possibilities of the classic setup of introducing the fiancé to the family, with results that are playful, charming and surprisingly thoughtful.
An uneven effort overall that when it is working has a strange, engaging energy that is often overturned by an uncertain staidness.
Mournful and engrossing.
movie_title: The Short Life of Jose Antonio Gutierrez (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A mixture of archival footage, recent interviews and reenactments, the film gives a solid, if rather dry, overview of events.
At once desperately grim and unnervingly gripping, providing an exacting sense of the detail and procedure that went into death by hanging.

The way in which [director] Anspichler lingers on those who are only moments from death, especially milking a little boy's suffering in the film's finale, is truly sickening and exploitative in the lowest sense of the word.
Ruscio would rather add forced narrative complications than get to the actual core of what he's tossing out there, the sacrifices made in the name of relationships, dreams dashed or discarded.
Things tend to sputter about, feeling disconnected and episodic.
Lacks the emotional anchor of other Mexican cinema.
The workmanlike craftsmanship of Cain's filmmaking almost (but never quite) smooths over the ham-fisted way he conceives the story.
Moreau and Palud play on the way our minds fill in the gaps of the unknown and the very primal fear of things going bump in the night.
Though "Berkeley" may be based on Bobby Roth's own experiences, he filters it through a narrative framework that feels distant and impersonal...
Once the film gets mired in specifics, it begins to seem like any other Holocaust documentary and loses the sense of relevance and engagement with the now that at first makes it so intriguing.

Director Juan Antonio Bayona and screenwriter Sergio G. Sánchez ratchet up the tension to such excruciating heights that, while you're watching the film, your impulse is to scream out loud just to feel some sense of release.

Will the music of The Hip Hop Project album change your life? Likely, no. Did the process of making it change the lives of those involved in its creation? Undoubtedly. And that, perhaps, is inspiration enough.

The action is rendered with such disconcertingly low light levels -- and of course there is heavy rain for the climatic sequences -- that it can be a strain to simply see what is occurring on-screen. Then again, maybe that's for the best.

The very act of writing critically about Superhero inspires something of an existential crisis -- no one likely to turn out for it is reading this review, and anybody reading this review is probably not inclined to see it under any circumstances.
Not even a fixer-upper, The Ruins should be considered a complete tear-down.
It is easy to see the film as two movies crammed together, neither of them being very good.
Never [coalesces] into a greater portrait and tending to cancel each other out. Sometimes a story does need a star.
Deception would be laughably bad if it weren't so rotely inert.
Reynolds doesn't convey any of the lightning bolt insouciance that made him arguably the greatest movie star of the '70s and '80s (really) but rather just stands there.
Gleefully brimming with body parts and bad behavior, Pathology is a fun piece of flamboyant tastelessness.

Combining contemporary interviews with Factory survivors and an astounding treasure trove of archival footage shot by Williams himself, the film is an enigmatic, atmospheric portrait of a guy apparently too nice for the notorious Warhol crowd.
movie_title: A Walk Into the Sea: Danny Williams and the Warhol Factory (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film remains engaging in no small part because of the beguiling and enigmatic performance of [Katherine] Waterston, daughter of Law & Order star Sam Waterston.
A pleasant sorbet to wash away the aftertaste of the pre-summer clunkers.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For a film that wants to present itself as extravagantly dazzling, there is something thuddingly familiar and bland in its vision.
A surprisingly delicate, quietly emotional documentary look at the experiences of one Indian family that immigrated to England in the 1960s.
An adaptation of one of his stage plays, Meet the Browns gives off the distinct feeling that Perry is treading water or at the very least is content to satisfy his audience with the minimum.
Because [director] Emory doesn't grapple fully with the issues that loom over the film, there is something soppy and soft-headed about Inlaws & Outlaws.
The film itself seems lost in a time warp -- even its attitude toward the '80s is out of date considering the ongoing revival in music and fashion from that era.
Beach's storytelling tactics, much like the film as a whole, would simply be annoying if they weren't also borderline insulting.
Intermittently fun and occasionally witty, with just the right touch of self-awareness.

A veteran director of music videos, [Marc] Klasfeld has for his feature film debut churned out a lifeless series of sketch-comedy ideas that presumably would make even the Wayans brothers blanch at their broadness.
For all its visual surprises and visceral shocks, Lunacy is still the kind of film that is easier to admire than it is to actually like.
Not having a way to capture images of the machines at work means that too much of Butler's film ... is disappointingly made up of computer simulations.
What should be a sustained mood piece instead flops around uncertainly, trading in understated strength for noisy diversion.
A lugubrious and airless affair.
LaBute's remake is an interesting idea that never transforms into a particularly satisfying movie.
Seen on an Imax screen, the now-familiar imagery of the devastation in New Orleans and other areas takes on a new resonance as the sheer size of the affected areas is felt more fully.

It's a little rough around the edges, to be sure, but with such strong lead performances there is something irresistible in the film's audaciously straight-faced portrayal of such an unlikely relationship.
Essentially the filmmaking equivalent of an enraged blog on the Web -- pointed and provocative, but not exactly a comprehensive source for the issues it addresses.
This may be a just-for-fun comedy, but that shouldn't mean that it must entirely disconnect from the world.
Its sexual provocations aside, the film works best as an idealized portrait of a specific time and place, a hipster bohemia where everyone struggles to find meaning in the everyday acts of living.
Arguably the most vital and eye-opening documentary yet made regarding the United States' current military entanglement.
The film is forever trying to balance between being for younger teenagers and keeping their parents occupied as well, and never quite gets it right.
It's not a good film by any practical standard, but The Marine is bad in just the right way, a mindless throwaway that's at least smart enough not to take itself too seriously.
Rather than the escalating gross-out spectacular it could have been, Sleeping Dogs Lie is an unexpectedly thoughtful look at what it takes to make relationships work.
While it would like to be nimble, light-footed satire, too often Death and Texas stumbles on its own earnestness, wearing cement shoes when it should be tap-dancing.
The film mixes rousing kid-friendly adventure with surprisingly savvy grown-up wit and charm.

Scotsman not only lacks vision, a true sense of how to mesh Obree's sporting triumphs and personal setbacks, but it also lacks passion. What it needs, as strange and tacky as it may sound, is a bit more madness.
Strangely self-serious, and without covering the prerequisites of top-shelf nastiness that contemporary horror requires, this giant crocodile movie turns out to be neither fish nor fowl.
That [original] film was intellectually engaging as well as tangibly creepy, while the new remake is just plain bad, and boring to boot.
It is exciting to think that someone in Perry's position is indeed challenging himself, as he could presumably coast along on tried-and-true formulas for quite some time.
The film's values are fairly well encoded into the story, such that it feels less like a sermon and more like a film with a good, if somewhat sappy, heart.
Now and then there is something strangely right about films this defiantly wrongheaded, but What Love Is never rises above the leaden, overbearing qualities of Callahan's dialogue and staging.
Did you know that sometimes men and women see things differently when it comes to relationships? Such is the essential premise to Dating Games People Play, an entirely unnecessary romantic comedy.
Operation Homecoming never quite captures anything so poignant or precise, rather falling into seemingly endless variations of 'war is hell.'
movie_title: America At A Crossroads: Operation Homecoming: Writing The Wartime Experience (2007)

movie_review_blurb: ... a chillingly pitch-black comedy of errors ...
movie_title: The Prisoner Or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is flatly acted and extremely ill-paced, lacking any sense of urgency, momentum or fun.
Raucous and vibrant.
A disaster film with just the right touch of reality to ground the outre genre flourishes.
Many of the film's storytelling beats seems drawn perhaps a little too closely from "The Long Goodbye," Raymond Chandler's elegiac detective novel adapted into a classic by Robert Altman.
Words such as offbeat, charming or, Lord help us, quirky are wildly overused and yet this is exactly the kind of film to which they best apply.
Harden is a wonderful actress but struggles to find the complexity in so strained a situation.
Made up of four or five story ideas all crammed together, the film maintains a stop-start momentum at best that keeps it from ever hitting a solid stride.
With good intentions and a warm heart but undone by uneven performances and shaky storytelling, "Bob's New Suit" never quite finds the right fit.
What keeps the film afloat is the buoyant young cast, with Rulin especially watchable as the tightly wound lead and Joey King as her younger sister, who's an aspiring actress.
Dupieux's absurdism is simply muddled, masking the fact he doesn't really have much to say.
Something of an intriguing, if not entirely successful, exoticism.
Perry's ongoing disinterest in improving as a filmmaker is now seemingly part of his unshakable belief in himself, his insistence on doing his thing his way.
What this "Evil Dead" gets most right is its tone, paying homage yet staking its own territory; it's scary without being downbeat, fun without being too jokey.
"My Brother the Devil" is a promising debut that marks El Hosaini as a filmmaker to watch, but one still very much in the developmental stages.

"The Story of Luke" is not a saga of epic proportions, but with a huge assist from Pucci's layered performance, takes a premise that could easily be movie-of-the-week sappy and finds a humanizing lightness.
"The Lords of Salem" will make you feel bad. But it's supposed to.
Pineda's ebullience is infectious, and "Don't Stop Believin': Everyman's Journey" is a pleasant story of dreams coming true.
The whole affair curdles into a feeling of unearned, defensive superiority.
A sprawling, ambitious, major work -- a gripping exploration of power, personality, technology and the crushing weight that can come to bear on those who find themselves in its combined path.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Even if you may not be putting a Pussy Riot song on your next playlist, there is something so of-the-moment and exciting about the group that "Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer" feels important, if not fully complete.
"Copperhead" crams far too much of its action into its last 30 minutes after a rambling, drawn-out set up.
The movie feels like a flakey, off-the-cuff blog post that somehow transmogrified itself into a feature-length documentary.
"100 Bloody Acres" somehow manages to be both retro and up to date with its giddy, delightful gross-out horror-comedy mash-up storytelling.
Grown Ups 2 looks like it was a lot of fun to make. And the last laugh is on us.
Solidly done if somewhat unremarkable, there is nothing particularly wrong with "Broken," nothing that needs fixing exactly, and yet it never fully comes together.
The film is a visual mess, with cheap-looking effects hampered even further by crummy and unconvincing 3-D.
Drumming is able to swing from lighter comedic moments to dramatic insights while making it seem effortless.

Right down to the brute functionality of its title, "The Smurfs 2" may be the platonic ideal of a major studio sequel - no markedly better or worse than the first and with just enough difference to lay claim to being something new.
Anyone who longs for the old, weird films of John Waters or the psychotronic freak-outs of New York's Cinema of Transgression school should be able to get their fix from "Pig Death Machine."
"Blood" feels perfunctory, needing something besides fussy plotting to jolt it to life.
An infectious, warm comedy of family and communication and a promising debut as writer-director for Chism. These "Peeples" are people one should be happy to meet.
"Jobs" feels curiously out of touch with its subject, both as a man and regarding his impact.
The Last Exorcism Part II is an effectively unnerving, slow-burn supernatural horror tale.
A cynical college-age "Hangover" redo with far, far fewer fully developed characters or inventive adventures. (And that's saying something.)
It's difficult to say if Kellstein's approach to these difficult cultural dilemmas is meant to leave the audience to decide for themselves or if he can't figure it out either.
A self-published philosophical tract transposed into a movie that defies most all conventional notions of good or bad. It's something more akin to hypnotically terrible.
Rice does a fine job of juggling so many characters and moving smoothly among flashbacks without losing sight of the main story.
A movie first and foremost about other movies, a derivative of derivatives, "Guns, Girls and Gambling" is like a losing hand at cards: It could have been a winner, but just isn't.
One of the few points of interest in the film is trying to decide which car scenes were done with a towing rig and which were green-screen process shots.
"Worlds Away" functions solely as some sort of bargain sampler platter appetizer, never proving it has a real reason of its own to exist.
Harmless if not particularly noteworthy, with a warm heart and can't-argue-with-that message of environmental and local awareness ...
movie_title: Le Noël De Walter Et Tandoori 3D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Deeply, willfully out of touch ...
An intermittently compelling but ultimately disappointing drama that loses track of its own point of view in favor of more generic storytelling.
The original "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" leaves audiences feeling hollowed out, dispirited and dissolute. "Texas Chainsaw 3D" is simply a bummer for being a big nothing.
When it's all over, audiences are sent reeling out of the theater with heads spinning and guts churning.
If only "Struck by Lightning" had a sharper, stronger perspective, it might have made more of its conceit.
A modest thriller propelled by a strong cast and straightforward storytelling.
A one-sided attack piece like "FrackNation" doesn't add much to the conversation.
"The Last Stand" may not herald a full-scale reemergence for Arnold the Action Star, but it's clearly a step in that direction.
Really just an overstuffed story that comes off not as layered but rather as an unfocused jumble.
Quote not available.
In "Girls Against Boys" both sides lose.
The filmmakers trot out slavery as a general sins-of-the-past signifier and then have no idea what to really do with such a painful real-world issue.
movie_title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Ávila can't quite thread the needle between telling his personal story and connecting it to larger social currents.
By our quote-unquote standards of contemporary comedy, it plays as uneven at best and often just flattens out for long jokeless stretches.
There is something sharp, exciting and more original tucked within "The Berlin File" - and it is in moments a sleek, crackling film - but it all feels somehow misshapen.

The film feels like an animated Wikipedia page, just sort of running through the greatest hits of Lincoln's life in office - the Emancipation Proclamation! Gettysburg! The Theater! - without any real insight.
Whether one is an animal lover or not, the chance to in essence sit with these animals as if up close and in their pens is remarkable and engaging.

Mesmerizing and haunting, "The Jeffrey Dahmer Files" is an inside-out serial killer movie, lacking in gore or cheap psychology and made in part for those who think they never want to see another serial killer movie.

Really the biggest problem with Dark Skies is that Stewart can never quite decide just what story he is telling or whether to focus on this character or that, instead struggling to string together scares regardless of how they fit together overall.
There are vague hints that the story is "really" about the difficulties and anxiety of commitment, but then one of many variations on a fart joke distracts from any actual idea.
"Kick-Ass 2" is a lesser version of what it appears to be, an uncertain jumble rather than a true exploration of outrage, violence and identity.
The fact that there is already at least one sequel planned feels more like a threat than a treat.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)
