movie_review_blurb: Even for its flaws, it is hard to ask for more from a late summer movie than "The World's End."
It all winds up feeling hollow and even slightly oppressive, an enforced sense of fun jabbed within quotation marks. It aims for a silky lightness of touch but lands like a dropped slab of concrete.
The movie never quite decides if it wants to be a sensitive drama of self-actualization or a playful party movie and ultimately misses the mark on both counts.
One can't help but imagine what previously attached directors Barry Levinson or Richard Linklater might have done with this material, with their affinity for scenes of drifting talk and hanging out.
Directed by Denis Villeneuve from a script by Taylor Sheridan, the film manages to somehow be sleek and sprawling, focused and cagey at the same time, often in the same scene.
A better, funnier and more considered movie than much of what passes for nonfranchise studio filmmaking, even as it shows a world almost exclusively white, straight and upmarket.
Combining Hou's patient, observant style with a historical martial arts tale, the film is a fascinating hybrid of craft, genre and story.
It is not hard to wonder if "Truth" the screenplay might have rang its bell a bit more clearly in the hands of another director, another set of eyes and hands to distill the material.
The movie isn't some kind of disservice to the legacy of Charles Schulz, but it also feels unnecessary.
A tremendous effort by Hardy is let down by unfocused storytelling.
"#Horror" is a bit like someone who is genuinely scared of something but tries to laugh it off.
The movie settles for being a party comedy and little else.
"Daddy's Home" is a movie just smart enough about being dumb.

Some movies are so interminable that it seems they might never end, while others are assembled with such indifference that you are essentially left waiting for them to start. "Pixels" somehow manages both.
It is designed to be fun, efficient and accessible and delivers precisely and exactly on that and nothing more.
It is hard to think of a movie squandering the opportunity of a perfectly timed cultural moment quite like "The Boss."
"The Next Cut" manages to be entertaining and thoughtful, harmless fun but just serious enough not to seem frivolous.
It's heavy stuff, served with a light touch.

movie_review_blurb: Most of the action setups are incoherent.
Die Another Day is best processed as an over-the-top symphony of the most absurd elements these movies have to offer.
The eleventh hour plot twists are both fitting and unexpected.
[It uses] 50s pop-ideology as an excuse to point at big issues from safe distances.
An earnest Scrooge story with a heart covered in excrement.

Good science fiction never announces its subtext this narcissistically.
The studio may be taking a monetary risk by straying from its musical formula, but it can rest assured that in doing so it's delivered a pleasing entertainment.
With the help of Hayek and Molina's multifaceted performances, Frida is as much about the nature of art as it is about the condition of the artist.

8 Mile stands as a deeply flawed excursion harbouring a couple of deep satisfactions.
Stripping film art down to its most purely visual roots, Brian De Palma's almost silent thriller is a stylish exploration of movies (and dreams) as our efforts to fabricate reality.
A feel-weird movie that ends up feeling pretty good.
The cast seems so intent on delivering the goods that you can't help wondering what this might have amounted to if it didn't have such an aversion to actual substance.
This experiment works essentially as a remake criticizing the trend of remaking films in the first place.
Amelie is both brave and wise enough to consider happiness an emotion worthy of artistic taste.

Letters From Iwo Jima is less interesting as the counter-perspective to last year's Flags of Our Fathers than it is as Clint Eastwood's effort to stake his own Japanese movie epic.

Perry's habit of reducing drama to verbal sermons is the main thing keeping his movies within the realm of daytime TV.

The collision of ideals is also where Black Snake Moan shines as a statement on the value of the cultural melting pot.

There's nothing to fear.

The performers bring enough spirit that the idiocy oversteps malice and manages to be funny about half the time.

It has crossover as more than kids' fare because it's smart about childhood.
Plenty of high profile movies are about the tormented lives of artists. Perfume: The Story of a Murderer takes it up a notch: It's a legitimate artwork.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

It's an achievement so hermetic it hardly bothers to be a movie.
Scorsese's treatise on honour and trust has a sprawl that's at once epic and cohesive.
The third entry in the Fast and the Furious franchise burrows culture shock in dishonesty.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An early flashback scene indicates how The Illusionist might have played like The Princess Bride for the tea and scone set. Instead it's just a nobly acted stage mystery.
Boring youth movies are the result of boring youth characters.
It's 9/11 ingeniously structured as the basis of a Beckett play.
Its trash pic spirit locates funny nuances of human behaviour.
It works better than most movies with a quirky Sundance pedigree, because the filmmakers aren't quick to paint any of their characters as morally wrong.

Though keeping worthwhile targets - like professors who want to see their most creative students fail - director Steve Pink lets his punk inspiration slide into standard school rivalries and unrelated slapstick.
Billed as Canada's first bilingual feature, director Erik Canuel imitates US buddy film formula.

The Broken Lizard crew amuse each other with enough banal antics (can anything else account for this film running nearly two hours?) that the sober viewer suffers enormous gaps of boredom between good jokes.

1930s black America becomes just a stage for OutKast's vanity project.

Mostly, the movie's offbeat charm comes from its appropriation of the outrageous antics of US comedies with lowkey Canadiana.

Some crazed jewel thieves get trigger-happy in a gas station, and kidnap John Cena's wife. This is useful, as it adds the dangerous excitement of having an angry pro-wrestler chase them through South Carolina forests.
Pale-faced, staring, mute Japanese kids strike back.
Eschewing personality, it mistakes pandering for insight.
The focus in Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning isn't on the confrontation of demons, moral reckoning, or terror. It's an unimaginative exercise in suffering.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone repelled by the dating quota enforcement of movies like Failure to Launch should at least recognize virtue in Employee of the Month's dismissal of ranked social leagues.

It's so charming that it threatens to reduce Beatrix Potter to a series of fairy tale virtues. But it's this focus that distinguishes the movie from tortured artist cliché.

Life's too short.

An entirely internalized portrait of a character without a clear interior.
The progress Harold makes in this unconventional romance is the peak of Stranger than Fiction.
The drama suffers: The Dixie Chicks don't provide a rebellious force to rise against the inanity they faced.

movie_review_blurb: The look of Night of the Living Dead 3D can be replicated by holding translucent red and blue Jolly Ranchers in front of your eyes while running in a park at night.

Cohen stages his gags with a fearlessness where viewer-discomfort is part of the thrill.

movie_review_blurb: By colliding eras, Coppola asserts that rich youth of long ago aren't much different than those alive today.

At once a sly dig at celebrity movie biographies and American slobbery.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's delivered with an assured pacing and discovery where the story is still revealing itself after the first act.
The promising beginning goes unrealized.
A speculative "what if?" take on human nature taunts Children of Men with the pretense of great science fiction.

Happily N'Ever After is a cutting edge contraction for Happily Not Ever After. It's a shame other films weren't blessed with this hip foresight, otherwise we'd have N'Another Teen Movie and The World is N'Enough.
Mess that it is, it carries a distinctive tone and visual effort.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The marital problems played out by Naomi Watts and Edward Norton are of trivial concern when set within a cholera epidemic in China.

Stallone is so well-meaning with this project, he keeps an average movie extremely likable.

Barely a good movie, in its visionary fury it becomes a great one.
Fast food merchandising of the heart.
Blood Diamond lives unsteadily as an action-fueled real-world expose.
Movies about real life serial killers are released frequently. It's when they're missing grief that they become an insult to the memory of the dead.

Sadie (Mandy Moore) and Ben (John Krasinski) are getting married (because they met at the start of the movie.)

Its best and worst attribute is how nice it is.

movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's standard mystery potboiler, separated only because it over-pronounces the genre's issues of reality and identity.

movie_review_blurb: Rob McKittrick's debut is most successful at its simplest - unflinching in the way a lot of 20somethings talk and act in the company of friends.

movie_review_blurb: Year of the Fish does feature more than enough clever moments and ideas to compensate for forcing audiences to sit through yet another tale of a woman who needs a man to rescue her from a life of drudgery.

movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Having the straight Tom Cavanagh and Ben Shenkman play the unwilling gay dads in Breakfast with Scot may seem like a disappointment, but this quirky, surprisingly refreshing comedy has a few tricks up its sleeve.

By undermining the subtle feminism of his movie, [director] Ross ends up undermining the whole thing, culminating in a terrifying parking-lot scene that doesn't quite make sense.

Ultimately Blind Sun is a watchable and somewhat absorbing (and familiar) stylistic exercise.

movie_review_blurb: Creating a melancholic portrait of generational confusion, Hernández Cordón gives us doomed love among the present-day los olvidados.
movie_title: I Promise You Anarchy (Te prometo anarquía) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Besides what are perfunctory nods to current malaises in Japanese society, there's nothing particularly special about Kabukicho Love Hotel, which feels like it's been done hundreds of times before, and much better.

movie_title: When Evening Falls on Bucharest or Metabolism (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Inside Llewyn Davis proves the Coens to be the most Kubrickian of contemporary filmmakers-that is, if you consider Kubrick to be funny.

movie_title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Le journal d'une femme de chambre) (1965)

movie_review_blurb: Breakfast on Pluto's novelistic feel can seem disjointed, but ultimately the structure frees the film to flit from one interesting encounter to another with a minimum of connecting material.
This remake is heavy on the special effects...but the biggest difference is how the film becomes another commentary on the lamentable state of today's parents.

movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: She's the Man is cleverer than the average teen movie, but it gets so wrapped up in plot mechanics that it loses the characters

This conventional cross of Dangerous Minds and Mad Hot Ballroom can be beholden to the inspiring teacher movie formula, but Banderas' quiet grace keeps the film from pushing the motivational message too insistently.
Bolstered by outrageous humor, Thank You for Smoking grazes the main players and bystanders discussing national welfare from their own self-interest.

Match Point is not a declaration of the value of firm belief--it denounces theodicy, after all--but a caution against the outright rejection of it.

As a nightmarish vision of hell on earth, Silent Hill is a triumph of production and art design. As a coherent story, it's little more than a string of video game scenarios.

RV travels the comic highways similar to those driven by National Lampoon's Vacation's Griswolds, but the insufferable Munros leave us wishing they'd befall a fate more like that of the stranded family in The Hills Have Eyes.

Big Momma's House 2 lacks comedic momentum to sustain the ridiculousness of Lawrence as Big Momma, but it's a welcome break from the star's tough cop act and his abominable family film turn in Rebound.

Paltrow's inward performance is of a piece with her stunning work as Sylvia Plath in the biopic Sylvia.
