Domino looks like what an Avid might vomit up after partially digesting the digitized footage. It's flashy as hell, but the amphetamine-fueled method is compensating for a distinct lack of substance.
Good Night, and Good Luck. is a riveting newsroom entertainment that beckons [Murrow's] successors to follow his lead.
With Elizabethtown [Crowe] has made another heartfelt movie shot through with his sensibility. He's also made a gigantic mess, the first directorial misfire in his six-film oeuvre.
The wishy-washy self-empowerment tale hinges on the lack of communication between Chicken Little and his single father Buck Cluck, something best reserved for an episode of Oprah...
It's an unpleasant film with grotesque imagery, but Nine Inch Nails' "Closer" video is more unsettling than this mostly predictable bloodbath.
A solid romantic comedy that benefits from its ambition to look at the importance of age and religious differences, even if it could have gone deeper.
Jarhead gives voice to the humor and horror of military service during wartime, the things that those who served will not and cannot convey to civilians.
The vintage sci-fi design of the outer space setting and creatures is aesthetically pleasing, not to mention tangible in ways that CGI effects often aren't.
With the Triwizard Tournament as the centerpiece, director Mike Newell fashions an action film for children that may be without any reasonable challengers.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Kiss Kiss Bang Bang is full of knowing cinema references...but above all else it is a hilarious movie that reinvigorates the modern crime picture.
Pride & Prejudice is a lovely production, with spectacular estates and soft, golden hues, but it's far from a musty affair.
Just Friends is sweet and mostly pleasant to pass the time with...but there's little justification to enter into a serious engagement with it.
The play may have felt fresh nearly ten years ago, but the film version is about as edgy as Pat Boone covering Nirvana.
A suburban nightmare of screaming, scheming children, Yours, Mine and Ours can make the stoutest adults abandon thoughts of becoming parents.
A deeply personal and unsparing film, The Squid and the Whale finds humor in the heartache and harpoons the notion that divorce has no casualties.
Director Andrew Adamson's adaptation, the first in what is sure to be a series of films, brings it alive with a childlike sense of awe and wonder.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Thing About My Folks contains more sap than a Vermont maple.
Syriana demands patience to see how the pieces come together in a fascinating mosaic of politics, capitalism, and corruption.
Shot and edited as though it were made forty years ago, The Producers is a creaky relic of the musical's heyday.
Those willing to subject themselves to it are in for [Ellen Page's] noteworthy performance and one of the most terrifying films to come down the pike in awhile.
Alternating between lowbrow comedy and pointed political commentary is a bold strategy, but the combination results in a film neither dumb enough nor smart enough to work.
Wolf Creek is a well-made film, but its technical merits are overwhelmed by the disgust registered as it wallows in some of the nastiest human behavior imaginable.
Considering all of the jackass things [Knoxville's] done on his way to fame, his presence in The Ringer helps the film challenge the idea of what is normal and what is intellectually disabled.
Grandma's Boy is what would result if Adam Sandler and his high profile co-stars bailed on a movie and the understudies took over.
This is a vile exploitation film, and a shoddily-made one, that's half softcore porn and half horror porn.
Set in a luxurious locale and awash in generosity for its characters, even the mean ones, Last Holiday delivers the glamour and sentimentality associated with classic movies.
Underworld: Evolution is what an Uwe Boll movie would look like if Sony's money were behind it rather than German financiers and if it lacked any unintended laughs.
Assuming there are no other credit cookies, the final image in See No Evil is a dog urinating in an eye socket. There couldn't be a better way to describe the experience of watching this film.
The third time around for The Fast and the Furious finds the franchise spinning its tires.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Poseidon, [Petersen's] remake of the 1972 disaster flick The Poseidon Adventure, is lean and mean yet waterlogged by the bland characters scurrying for their lives.
The Pursuit of Happyness is a feel-good film with plot conveniences that stack needless burdens on the main character, but it takes great care to show how difficult it can be to pull oneself up.
The Holiday works its magic because Meyers invests time in the characters instead of the scenarios.
Charlotte's Web is a beautiful tale of friendship that spoons out the virtues of kindness and generosity without a medicinal taste.
Night at the Museum is more amusement park ride than a walk through the halls of history, but sometimes a slap fight with a monkey is preferable to a lesson on Sacajawea.
In an achievement befitting the boxer, Stallone delivers a sucker punch in finding a way to make this underdog comeback story succeed.
It's too bad that the film loses its way because The History Boys asks some interesting questions about what to learn and how to use it.
This dire comedy deserves to be dropped in a vat of solvent to remove its stink.
It would be easy to write off Freedom Writers as another inspirational teacher movie, not to mention one in which the white character saves the minorities, but to do so would be unfair.

Alpha Dog's characters adopt poses that they've seen on television and in the movies, and the same goes for the young cast hamming it up as if they watched their Scarface DVDs too many times in preparation.
Invigorating in its ideas and style, Children of Men conceives a dystopian future, but its questions are just as relevant to our modern lives.
Too silly and stupid to be scary, The Hitcher speeds along with no regard for logic.
Sweet Land values interconnectedness -- in a couple, among a community, with the land, and with ancestors -- and powerfully illustrates it within the story's emotional and visual content.
Catch and Release draws its title from the fishing philosophy of Gray's fiancé and buddies. The humane thing to do is throw this film back too.
The rat-a-tat-tat dialogue and 70s trappings of Smokin' Aces is pure Tarantino, although like the countless imitators, it isn't as clever as its inspiration.

Blood and Chocolate raises questions about the individual versus the group and tradition versus progress but...is more interested in flaunting the film's lame special effects than mining its thematic potential.
The film's problems boil down to story. The Messengers has none, or nothing beyond the sketch of an idea: family with troubled past moves into spooky new home.
If Norbit doesn't kill cinema, nothing will.
Some of the nonsense could be overlooked as part of rom com conventions, but Because I Said So's shrillness makes for an exhausting experience.
Watching a single athlete for the duration of a game is an interesting concept, but Zidane is better in theory than in execution.
movie_title: Zidane, un Portrait du 21e Siècle (Zidane: A 21st Century Portrait) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Ghost Rider is a comic fan's celluloid nightmare. Jokey to a fault and weighty as newsprint, it lives down to the negative attributes attached to the comic book film tag.
Carrey has difficulty playing inner torment without making it look funny, an issue magnified by...director Joel Schumacher's concessions to utilizing the actor's skills to get laughs.
Reno 911!: Miami is too safe and unremarkable to be a crime against comedy a la Norbit, but anyone in search of a laugh feels robbed all the same.
With The Astronaut Farmer writer-director Michael Polish and his co-writer brother Mark continue a foray into American mythmaking that began with Northfork.
While it's admirable that Bridge to Terabithia isn't sugar-coated, more often than not it plays as miserabilism for kids.
Like a catchy pop song you can't stop humming, the sublime romantic melody of Music and Lyrics puts a smile on your face and love in your heart.
The actors possess enough charisma and good spirit to charm even if there's the sneaking suspicion that their skills are in service of something mediocre.
The story is built beam by beam, but Fincher tweaks the final design of what we expect in the architecture of a serial killer movie.
As a Cold War thriller, The Lives of Others is gripping stuff replete with the nuts and bolts of all-encompassing surveillance.
Premonition's way of dressing its marital crisis material in Twilight Zone garb grabs attention but looks flimsy upon further inspection.
Home of the Brave is so ham-fisted in its attempts to wring pathos from the vets' problems that it plays like an overwrought parody of an award bait movie.
Earnestly acted and directed, Eragon has neither the visual dazzle nor narrative momentum to compensate for its cut-rate fantasy mimicry.
Idlewild overflows with inventiveness and random weirdness that sort of make it a must-see even if it isn't a particularly good film.
For Your Consideration is a funny movie, albeit a minor one alongside Guest's other comedies.
This moderately amusing computer-animated comedy is torn between its zany, go-for-broke nature and the strictures of trying to be everything for everyone.
The Notorious Bettie Page may be the sweetest movie ever made about pornography.
Johnson's sources of inspiration for Brick put forth tough dicks and dames in a cold, uncaring universe. Glum teens are a clever and natural evolution for the genre.
Water simmers at the injustice heaped upon these women because of religious tradition.
Simply put, this movie about sweeper salesmen is a comedic vacuum.
It's an impeccable production on a visual level and undeniably a well-made film, but the narrative often lacks the spark to bring it to life.
While consistently funny, The Break-Up deals in bitterness and revenge, sometimes in ways that cut closer to the bone than most fluffy romantic comedies.
Streep plays Miranda subtly, not needing theatrics for the razorblade spitting she does to nick all of the unquestionably incompetent people around the character.
Unfortunately for You, Me and Dupree, it's easier to invest patience in people stumbling to find focus and purpose than films searching for the same things.

Snakes on a Plane may not be a good movie by conventional standards, but with the proper amount of love via audience participation, this genre picture is exactly the sort of silly fun that mega-priced, B-grade tentpole films often fail to be.
Crank works overtime to be a disreputable bit of pulp fiction, and for the first half or so it's like inhaling the cinematic equivalent of the film's title.
Confetti is the latest mockumentary to encounter the problem of reality, or reality TV, being more outrageous than the filmmaker's send-up.
Flyboys rises above [its] flat characterizations to provide an often fascinating glimpse of the lives of early airmen.
The philosophy espoused in Gridiron Gang places the team above the individual, but the film is carried on the broad shoulders of the charismatic Johnson.
With Mission: Impossible III [Abrams] has essentially designed the most expensive episode of Alias ever made.
Cook is the stand-up comic of the moment, although there's little in Employee of the Month to explain why he's currently one of the hottest names in comedy.
For all intents and purposes, The Grudge 2 is a parody of itself and the most recent wave of Japanese horror.
The fashion-conscious Marie Antoinette looks great. Imagine what this attractive but empty shell of a movie might have been with something inside it.
Saw III is essentially a grim schoolyard game of 'would you rather...?' rendered in nasty vignettes.
[The director] has expertly interwoven real and simulated footage to make a film that looks convincing, but it amounts to little more than a clever editing exercise.
The Santa Clause films may speak to the need for family connections, but this third movie represents another part of the season: the need to move product.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Director Asif Kapadia and screenwriter Adam Sussman reach into the grab bag of horror movie clichés and pull out fistfuls for The Return.
If more action propelled this water-treading plot, Ayer might have produced the mean streets classic that Harsh Times aspires to be.
As crazy and subversive as Let's Go to Prison's makers might believe it to be, it's too undisciplined and predictable to amount to anything
Akin to a socially conscious ensemble film by John Sayles, Fast Food Nation takes aim at corporate America moreso than the McDonald's and Burger Kings of the world.
There's nothing saying that entertainment for kids can't be substantive, but the film's hard sell against belief in the supernatural and for ecological care are simple-minded and preachy.

Ultimately it's about fully embracing life rather than staying locked in our habits and comfort zones, hardly a new moral to the story in the history of cinema, but Stranger Than Fiction brings vitality to the shopworn message.
A few laughs are sprinkled in this equivalent of a lame sitcom holiday episode, but the broad comedy and treacly ending are unlikely to put anyone in the Christmas spirit.
While it includes excerpts of some RFK speeches, Bobby provides no insight into the man and his politics, choosing instead to flit among the insipid soap opera storylines.
An unforeseen mix of action, sci-fi, and even a hint of romance, Deja Vu's pleasures are in delivering what we don't see coming.
The Protector's plot is as sturdy as a piece of balsa wood, which wouldn't have mattered so much if the film had showcased Jaa's talents better.
A funny, generous film with strong performances, In Her Shoes redeems the often derogatory 'chick flick' label.
Red Eye is a wind-up machine of elegant simplicity, an increasingly uncommon breed among today's bloated genre films.
What's abundantly clear is that Adams steals the film as the irrepressible Ashley.
This is a thrilling picture that merges [Scorsese's] gritty style and his adoration of old-fashioned Hollywood. The production design alone makes the film a must-see.
Kinsey's interest in sex combines the psychological and mechanical, and the film strikes a balance that is neither erotic nor clinical.
The 1930 film has some major weaknesses -- most of the expository scenes, especially a creaky beginning -- but there's enough stunning stuff in it to make it worth seeing.
Without a doubt Kraa! The Sea Monster is grade A crud.
Brooks struggles to define Spanglish, garbling the storylines in an unfocused film that only skims the surface in its two hours plus running time.
Flight of the Phoenix ignores the human drama to focus on cockamamie setbacks that are harder to swallow than the plane's motor oil.
Mildly amusing...but joke repetition and a greater emphasis on outrageousness and vulgarity release a strong scent of the writers' desperation.
This visually flat, dramatically incoherent film puts a stake through the heart of the series.
The dialogue is often lacerating, as lovers wield words like lashes, striking out to get what they desire.
Daniel Craig gives a solid performance in the tradition of Hitchcock's wrong men.
While much of Being Julia's appeal stems from no one being as fabulous as [Julia] is, the lack of a worthy sparring partner diminishes the fun.
What better way is there to get into a festive spirit than having it crammed down your throat?
An over the top, ham-fisted replay of the original.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Payne and Taylor excel at getting underneath these tough exteriors and portray these people for what they are, warts and all.
SpongeBob's resilient, Pollyana-like nature is hard to resist.
The dialogue mimics the terseness [of Elmore Leonard's work] without the snap or humor. Almost every word sounds recycled from another movie.
Birth channels the style and tone of [Buñuel classics] exceptionally well, but ultimately the dramatic resolution is unsatisfying.
[Law's] timeless good looks and effortless charisma make him the kind of leading man that Hollywood would produce from genetic experiments if they could.
I ♥ Huckabees might be too smart for its own good, but that also seems to be the point. Russell extols liberal activism while deflating its self-importance...
Eschewing plot and a linear timeline for a stylish exercise in mood, Shimizu sets the scenes with long silences and chilling images.
[Parker and Stone's] merciless mockery of Hollywood action clichés, particularly those found in Jerry Bruckheimer's productions, couldn't be more accurate.
Oozes sentimentality for the plight of these mildly eccentric characters... The problem isn't the film's gooey center but the flavorless, formulaic substance surrounding it.
Sayles traces how rumor, conjecture, and outright lies seep into the [political] discussion and drive it.
Duff's sunny disposition makes her a likable movie presence, but I've yet to see anything from her...beyond a 'let's put on a show' high school drama club enthusiasm.
Ladder 49 wants to honor firefighters for their courage and selflessness...yet at every turn [the film] undercuts itself.
Nine years after Toy Story, the novelty of computer animation has worn off. Story and character need to capture our imagination.
Treating the [controversial] incidents with kid gloves allows Jim Brown: All-American to fit into the encomium template, but a more forthright approach is demanded.
Writer-director Edgar Wright and co-writer and star Simon Pegg have terrific fun riffing on zombie lore.
Bettany and Dunst make a cute couple that is as fiercely competitive in their love lives as they are on the court.
...equal parts whimsy and war horrors, a potentially combustible combination that succeeds largely due to Jeunet's ability to turn absurd melodrama into something magical.
[Leconte is] among the best today at turning out films in the classic French mode.
The film's storyline plays out as a comic riff on Moby-Dick, which is hilarious if you're on Anderson's wavelength but will probably bore to tears those who aren't.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Racing Stripes follows a story arc similar to Babe, but it possesses none of the warmth, humor, or originality of that film.
Although muddled and inconsistent, especially toward the end, Reign Over Me succeeds with its portrayal of friendship in hard times.
Attempts to reflect the times, loaded as it is with southern aphorisms and slang, but the results are forced and clunky.
Adorable beyond belief, [Audrey Tatou] wins our hearts with a performance that could comfortably exist in silent cinema.
Mulligan uses a delicate touch in revealing the confusion in growing up and the loss in discovering that the world isn't as simple or perfect as children believe it to be.
Its kinetic energy and embrace of film noir tropes provide a surge of adrenaline and testosterone for the fanboy universe.
Boyle demonstrates that a family film with a moral message mustn't necessarily be a musty affair.
The film feels like a summary work, as if [Allen] is reevaluating his career twenty-five years after exploring similar territory in Stardust Memories.
While Guess Who gets some mileage out of its black and white issues, it's more focused on being the interracial romantic comedy answer to Meet the Parents.
Although this embedded view is revealing, watching the unformed footage becomes tedious.
It's formulaic stuff, but the film treats the conflicts seriously and possesses a sweet demeanor.
For the sequel Bullock's as likeable as ever, but she can only do so much when working from a mundane script that relies heavily on repeating gags from its predecessor.
There's much to like about Bride & Prejudice...but the end result looks and feels like a cut-rate version of the Bollywood and Hollywood sensibilities.
Born Into Brothels simmers with righteous anger, but it never boils over.
...attempts to look effortless in seeming hip, but the wink-wink, nudge-nudge jokes about sequels, Hollywood, and the music world come off as familiar and self-congratulatory.
Diesel has fun puncturing his movie persona in The Pacifier. If only this film weren't so dopey.
Man of the House is an amiable trifle that might be a guilty pleasure if it were better.
The documentary works best when exploring how Deep Throat came to be and what led it to become a financial success and cultural lightning rod.
The untidy answers and selfless actions in Because of Winn-Dixie stand out from the family films populated with bratty kids and clueless adults.
There's no story to speak of, just a string of scenarios usually resulting in everything in sight getting smashed.
Vera Drake succeeds because Leigh is not interested in sloganeering but in looking at the human and moral cost.
As a first-time experimental filmmaker, Caouette displays remarkable directing and editing skills.
The Wedding Date reveals no trace of recognizable human behavior in it.
Oddly enough, about the first half of Pooh's Heffalump Movie could be thought of as the children's version of The Village.
Million Dollar Baby is an exceptional boxing movie, but Paul Haggis' screenplay...amounts to something greater than the familiar underdog sports tale.
Hide and Seek goes off the rails when the secret is brought into the light because it feels like a cheap gimmick, and not an original one at that...
Boll's vague X-Files rip-off isn't scary or exciting, but inadvertently he's made a movie funnier than a lot of the purported comedies Hollywood cranks out.
Rudely funny and gleefully violent, the film is a wound-up genre exercise that doesn't dip even a toe into reality but is a good time if you can get past that.
Elektra's muddled story and formal unsightliness aren't filmmaking tragedies of Greek proportions, just Hollywood's latest casualty of concept over character.
[Zhang] adopts a stylized but more naturalistic look for the visually sumptuous wuxia spectacle House of Flying Daggers.
Evergreen is composed of standard teleplay material that fails to surprise and engage at almost every turn.
Kerry Conran imagines an adventure cobbled together from serials, comic books, and radio dramas of the 30s and 40s, making something derivative yet unique.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A Dirty Shame is outrageous for the sake of being outrageous, but unlike some of Waters' other films, it's neither shocking nor funny.
Becky's adept maneuvering through upper society's pitfalls is sometimes muddled from too many characters and too little explanation, but Witherspoon remains fun to watch...
Hirokazu dwells on the resiliency of children, a theme that also resonated in Small Change and which gives the film a lightness not inherent in the subject matter.
Michel Legrand's music is the film's heartbeat, and it soars and dips according to the melodrama.
movie_title: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (Les Parapluies de Cherbourg) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: That Obscure Object of Desire is an intoxicating descent into one man's experience of the emotional terrorism intended to shake him from his ways.
Truffaut is so precise with his observations and unintrusive with the camera that we feel as if we are seeing a documentary instead of contrived movie scenarios.
movie_title: L' Argent de Poche (Pocket Money) (Small Change) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: [Hirokazu's] also one of the most empathetic filmmakers, softly guiding viewers through his meditations on life and death.
Wedding Crashers is a brash, frequently hilarious film that may be overly long but satisfies our desires for a lot of comedy and a little bit of romance.
Attempts to provide Wonka's backstory can slow down the film's momentum, but overall Burton puts an enjoyable twist on a beloved story while justifying the remake's existence.
[Connelly] does superior work creating a woman struggling to be a good mother while feeling like she's falling to pieces.
The Aristocrats is an unrepentantly filthy movie...and a very funny one.
Although Bad News Bears is not a shot-for-shot remake of the original, it is strikingly similar to the point where its existence is hard to defend.
For better and worse, the pieces comprising Must Love Dogs are borrowed from every other romantic comedy.
If Todd Solondz were a humanist, he might make something like performance artist Miranda July's winning debut feature film.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Like DJay, Brewer exhibits talent for what he does, but too much of it is in service of hogwash.
A rousing action picture with generous dashes of humor, The Rock remains the much-maligned director's best film
The Bridges at Toko-Ri effectively depicts the sacrifices and courage of those who went to war.
The Rocketeer is a throwback to when movie heroes weren't burdened by irony or existential angst.
John Woo's poetically violent action sequences are his trademark, and Hard-Boiled features three stunning examples.
The Skeleton Key conjures a spooky atmosphere steeped in the mystique of folk magic and medicine and suspicion of the deep South.
John Dahl's solemn staging of the rescue mission will likely earn him points from military aficionados, but The Great Raid is terminally dull.
Deuce Bigalow: European Gigolo recycles its lowest common denominator dirty joke even though it wasn't very good the first time.
While it's an effective sports film...the players and their enormous spirits take precedence over the outcome of the games.
It's all noise and motion that blurs the action to the point of incomprehensibility.
The Brothers Grimm is fascinating but only in the way that watching a good director misfire this badly can be.
The Man is a stale mismatched buddy comedy in which not a single interesting thing happens.
(The film's) noble intentions are unquestionable, but the scattershot reporting keeps it from amounting to little more than a string of too-similar witness testimonies.
movie_title: Answering the Call: Ground Zero's Volunteers (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Transporter 2 bursts with outrageous driving stunts, sublimely absurd fight scenes, and a sense of humor that ties it together.
A brisk, galvanizing journey through the political thicket in Africa, (it) positions Meirelles as a leading director of electrically charged dramas with social consciences.
Witherspoon and Ruffalo underplay the broad comedy and their characters' attraction, which is why their chemistry ultimately proves to be so satisfying.
Corpse Bride continues a perfect marriage between Burton's creativity and a technique rarely used for feature films.
Coupled with...picturesque cinematography, Press and Blunt's natural performances communicate a palpable sense of the summer's heat and the hazy days of adolescence and ardor.
Romero finds creative ways to stage zombies feasting on flesh while tackling...gated communities, war profiteering, and entertainment as a weapon of mass distraction.
It's a laugh-free exercise in moviemaking by numbers.
The visual power of Miyazaki's animation is as strong as ever, but it's all for naught when you can't make heads or tails of the story on screen.
Wicker Park frustrates to no end when a smidgen of common sense on anyone's behalf would clear up everything.
Maria Full of Grace provides an authentic and compelling view of a drug mule's experience.
Cellular utilizes remarkable efficiency and ingenious construction to realize an exciting and funny story that seems plausible enough under the circumstances.
A sloppy, lowest common denominator comedy
Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter...and Spring provides an oasis from contemporary rhythms.
The title and the music suggest a Sergio Leone spaghetti western, but the setting and characters would be more at home in a Mike Leigh film.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The film discards serious discussion for Mexican standoffs and action scenes, trading the possibility of complex rewards for simple pleasures.
Part live action cartoon, part love letter to the cinema, Kung Fu Hustle is one of a kind.
Rather than making The Interpreter about the twists and turns, its focus is the people who don't know how to read the situation in which they have found themselves.
Like the films of Jim Jarmusch and Aki Kaurismäki, Schultze Gets the Blues uses dry humor to extract laughs out of mundane situations.
The Tennessee middle school's story is worth hearing, but rather than a feature-length documentary, it's best suited as a short TV newsmagazine package.
The somber Kingdom may not provide an epic's anticipated escapism, but it serves as a salient reminder that hundreds of years later these battles are still being waged.
While strides have been made in this country's race relations, Crash brings to the forefront the prejudices and stereotypes that often remain unspoken.
House of Wax's violence is abrupt and gory, giving it an ick factor that surprises and repulses in a good way.
Gamers would be better off playing Doom or sitting in front of a blank screen than wasting time with this incredibly dull Aliens rip-off.
XXX: State of the Union falls flat because Lee Tamahori directs the action scenes with the grace of a bull in a china shop.
Told predominantly through handheld close-ups, Danish director Susanne Bier's intimate drama Brothers examines the cost of war on the domestic front.
The kids are cute and the intentions are good, but ultimately [the film] plays like a teacher's presentation to the school board about the importance of arts education.
Clones is far from perfect, but when it clicks, it revives the old spirit that made a generation become so obsessed with all things Star Wars in the first place.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The well-choreographed action has a video game's fluidity and brute force.
True to its weepy telefilm resemblance, Dear Frankie delivers several eye-dabbing moments, but the tears...are earned through solid storytelling and subdued acting.
The nastier comedy that Monster-in-Law demands is a bad fit for [Luketic].
Ferrell's a gamer who does what he can, but he has little support.
The cartoonish way in which the characters are played drains the film of any grittiness the setting is supposed to provide.
Purely as a study in speed and movement, Lords of Dogtown is a gnarly ride.
The Animation Show serves as a corrective to the limited views of what animation is and provides an avenue for worthy short subjects to be seen on a wider scale.
The pleasant actresses compensate for the originality and surprises that Sisterhood lacks.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Miike reins in his anything goes impulses...but still smuggles in his sense of humor and flair for the grotesque, often at the same time.
More attention is lavished on the fight and chase scenes than the relatively superficial message, but you don't go to a big budget summer movie in search of Ingmar Bergman.
The juvenile inspiration gives the film its creative spark, making it the coolest home movie project imaginable for a father and son.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: [Off the Map] takes time to breathe, to savor the present and not get bogged down in all the little things that often dominate our attention.
Pride rises with its feel-good message, soul classics of the 70s on the soundtrack, and Bernie Mac's comic relief. The film isn't a champion, but it makes you feel like one.
Ray is a flawed film, but Foxx's captivating acting and a bustling soundtrack smooth the rough spots.
The Last Mimzy's flight of fantasy sputters as the story's potential fails to reach any magical points.
The Company Men could stand to express a little righteous fury.
Strongman's unvarnished approach complements its salt of the earth subject.
Session 9 is heavy on mood and light on narrative substance, but the pervasive sense of dread that it sustains trumps the slightness of plot.
Still Walking is so uncommonly and beautifully perceptive about how families interact that it feels as natural as putting one foot in front of the next.
As a testament to the power of books, the often gloomy The Neverending Story comes off as a Reading Rainbow episode covering existentialism.
As a Cold War message movie and cinematic descendent of Fail-Safe, WarGames examines the inherent danger in favoring technology's cool logic and situational calculations.
The light tone, classical style, and Shue as Sandra Dee stand-in are more indicative of a cinematic mindset from approximately 25 years earlier.
In the era of the tortured superhero in movies, it's refreshing to come across one with enthusiasm and a pure spirit.
Rather than catering to the kids...the makers try in vain to produce something hip to appeal to all ages, or at least the parents who grew up with the cartoon.
Through its magnetic stars, funny crudity, and observation of people's foibles in relationships, Friends with Benefits consummates the deal that viewers enter with romantic comedies.
If a thousand monkeys at a thousand typewriters can produce Shakespeare, then Zookeeper must have been banged out by one primate pecking away at a keyboard between sessions playing on a tire swing.
These fourth wall breaking techniques never feel like meta intrusions on the material but like a child's interaction with a parent reading the tales.
Malick has come to be known and revered as a cinematic poet and philosopher, as a filmmaker who explores big ideas, but in Badlands in particular he also shows a knack for off-kilter humor.
Zapped! fancies itself to be the bad boy and flirts with that image, but this low-rent production is far too wholesome and blandly unfunny for that affectation to be convincing.
Career Opportunities plays like a hodgepodge of Hughes' greatest hits.
With a story that proves to be heartwarming and predictable, Undefeated mostly plays according to the script familiar in its fiction and nonfiction counterparts.
The Dardennes' style resists cheap sentimentality, yet in The Kid with a Bike it yields a deeply moving examination of love as a shield.
The terrifically timed, well-executed silliness is embraced without irony or any greater sense of purpose. It delivers what it promises: scene after scene of low comedy done with relish.
Astute at observing the behaviors and mindset of the fan who sees no distinction between himself and the team.
Writer-director Asghar Farhadi performs some kind of miracle with the tension and complexity he produces from such a simple set-up.
Take Shelter writer-director Jeff Nichols takes great care in detailing Curtis's journey and surrounding him with concerned loved ones.

To refer to a film's olfactory properties is ordinarily associated with expressing one's displeasure, but to do so in regard to Damsels in Distress is to praise this cinematic aromatherapy's mood-lifting qualities.
Naranjo numbs sensation to make his points about the drug war's damage to Mexico, turning Miss Bala into a thriller from the dissociative first person perspective.
Like life, The Five-Year Engagement can be messy and irrational. The shame is that the film doesn't need to be those things quite to the degrees that they are.
As far as unnecessary sequels are concerned, Men in Black 3 is a serviceable addition to the series.
With facts that are stranger than fiction and a story surrounding a murder that is often played as dark comedy, Bernie exists somewhere between an Errol Morris documentary and Fargo.
Dark Shadows gets stuck in neutral because of the uncertainty as to what kind of a film it wants to be.
The danger for Baron Cohen is having made his name as a confrontational comedian but delivering something that, while occasionally provocative, feels too conventional.
Laden with dread and executed with a musician's sense of timing, The House of the Devil is better than a substantial number of the films it resembles.
Just Go With It is an extraordinarily bad match of star and material.
Although not up to the high standard of writer-director Ti West's previous film The House of the Devil, The Innkeepers is another often chilling exercise in building mood and atmosphere.
The Roommate has the seed of a promising thriller in its premise yet never taps into the anxiety of discovering that the person designated to share your space makes you uncomfortable.
Knowing where the relationship is headed lends bittersweet notes to the scenes from the past, but the conclusions Blue Valentine draws ultimately feel pat.
Through its slack editing and direction, Hot Tub Time Machine gives the impression of a halfhearted effort, as if the film's name and story were wacky enough that any old gag would do.
The film might be intended as a cautionary tale, but that tends to get lost amid the lurid thrills and tacked-on happy ending.
Date Night takes two funny people, puts them in unfunny situations, and has them do and say unfunny things.
The film becomes a caricature of arthouse miserabilism, which asserts that the only truths are the ugly ones.
Baumbach's writing and direction of these characters display more of a novelistic touch...but the approach produces a deeply felt view of flawed individuals.
The Last Airbender is swollen with portentous mumbo jumbo and realized in the most simplistic and mundane ways imaginable.
This breezy movie is more fun when it doesn't worry about saying anything important and lets the zany antics unwind.
Whether intentional or not, The Sorcerer's Apprentice plays like Disney's stalled attempt to launch a stripped down Harry Potter-like franchise.
Salt doesn't spring many surprises, but settling for smartly staged setpieces over twists and turns in an action movie sounds like a square deal.
Going the Distance is concocted from a familiar formula. It just happens to be a really good example of what can be done with it.
The lack of subtlety and discipline is what can make Machete a disreputable pleasure and less than a full success.
Easy A passes due to Stone's star turn and a knowing screenplay that needed a little more bravery to elevate it to a top achievement.
The repetition fatigue that plagued 300 also weakens Legend of the Guardians, but otherwise it's an entertaining, action-packed fable
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a good film, but for one with the reputation of being the studio's worst animated feature, it shows that interesting work is done in it.
The core idea of the film is as off-putting as the way in which the premise is depicted.
Director Mark Romanek and cinematographer Adam Kimmel employ a nostalgic and otherworldly visual sensibility to evoke the golden years of innocence and ignorance.
Whether reading Audition as a portrait of coming to terms with grief, a feminist revenge tale, or a graphic exploration of romantic attachment and idealism, it remains a terrifying film.
The scares in Paranormal Activity 2 aren't as frequent or always as well built as the original film's, but those that exist are still pretty effective.
Conviction is unashamedly straightforward in showing how a lot of hard work and sheer willpower was able to correct an injustice.
Megamind is dramatically and comedically inert.
Unstoppable takes a simple premise and spins it into an entertaining film surging with pure energy.
The bulk of The Next Three Days consists of the build-up to the escape plan, which is probably just as well since this is a thriller surprisingly light on thrills.
If Faster were made 35 years ago or by the French or Japanese, it would be one of those grimy, long forgotten films you expect Quentin Tarantino to be touting.
Strange how for a movie about a Viagra salesman, we don't see the growth of the characters.
Aronofsky is completely serious about the fever dream that is Black Swan, which is how he's able to pull off material that is inherently unserious.
Four Lions is merciless in its mission to find humor where few would dare seek it.
With so many storylines battling for supremacy, Country Strong never conveys who these people are and is often inconsistent in portraying them.
The Dilemma requires a director willing to indulge the dark comedy to its fullest. One name that style doesn't bring to mind for the job is Ron Howard.
Marwencol provides a deeply empathetic view of loneliness and powerful evidence of art as an outlet.
Although the film throbs with dissatisfaction and longing for purpose, Somewhere plays as a dryly funny meditation on being adrift in Hollywood.
As a lousy mystery and lousier romantic comedy, The Bounty Hunter is two bad films in one.
Ultimately Rampart is Harrelson's showcase, and he takes full advantage of fleshing out a complex role.

The raunchy camp comedy Gorp, the last film released by American International Pictures, features almost all of the ingredients in Samuel Z. Arkoff's formula but is empty in cinematic nutritional value.
The movies that many of these guys made in the 1980s and '90s were hardly bulletproof, but this is a cynical exercise in settling for what is expected to be passable.
Hit & Run isn't always a smooth ride, but the quirks and misfires make it as distinctive as the actor behind many of the film's creative choices.
Combining Shakespeare and zombies creates the expectation that the text will be treated with some irreverence, but to a baffling degree Warm Bodies is played mostly straight.
Compliance functions as a fascinating and mortifying glimpse at how readily and illogically people will submit to authority, whether it's law enforcement or a boss.

What to Expect When You're Expecting provides a snapshot of contemporary anxieties about imminent parenthood, but it may be more worthwhile as a document for future pop culture scholars to use to understand what was trendy in 2012.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Taken 2 is content to play out as a familiar and lesser version of its predecessor.

Seven Psychopaths doesn't knuckle down and decide how to answer everything tossed out for consideration, but even when it feels like little more than intellectual, postmodern spitballing, it satisfies as an exercise in storytelling.

It owes more than a debt of gratitude to The Shining and The Ring, among others, but Derrickson processes the chilling influences into an eerie experience mindful of the significance of projected images watched alone in the dark.
The Tall Man comes as close as anything in recent years at matching the better monster-of-the-week episodes of The X-Files.
Cloud Atlas is prone to sappiness and threatens to disappear up its own tail like The Matrix trilogy, but it builds to an irresistible final act celebrating the human spirit.
As a hangout movie for kids, My Neighbor Totoro pleases with its easygoing pace, curiosity about the natural world, and sweet spirit.
The film struggles with the contradiction of knowing the serious risks while enjoying the games as participant and spectator.
Skyfall proves that a long-standing series can deliver the expected fundamentals while keeping the new films fresh and unpredictable.

Anna Karenina plays like the ultimate CliffsNotes, which is both testament to Stoppard's exceptional adaptation and abridgement of Tolstoy's novel and acknowledgment of the film's somewhat superficial center.
On the surface Silver Linings Playbook is a raucous romantic comedy, but its real interests are superstition and delusion.
Ultimately Hitchcock comes off as a glib film about a great film.
The Perks of Being a Wallflower flutters with the excitement and terror that comes in being young and trying to find your way.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Bigelow's great achievement is stripping down the action from the exaggerated theatrics in movies and television shows so the missions feel no less exciting and immediate.
This is 40 works better as light drama than comedy, with humor defusing the bombs being lobbed in the marriage.
The character is a victim of her own decisions, but Weisz's bruised performance in The Deep Blue Sea yields empathy for being battered by doomed romanticism.
The makers of Promised Land clearly object to fracking but attempt, not always successfully, to explore the issue without stacking the deck in favor of its viewpoint.
The Impossible doesn't turn a blind eye to the physical and emotional devastation, but the comparatively uncomplicated path it follows to arrive at a reassuring conclusion minimizes the impact.
Underneath It's Such a Beautiful Day's simple surface and droll humor is a philosophical core as dense as any film's.
This bloody, hilarious, shocking, and righteously angry film is the kind of great art and great trash [Tarantino] aspires to make.
The Last Stand doesn't find [Schwarzenegger] in peak form, but it'll suffice as a sturdy exhibition of his talents.
Within the context of a modern Brothers Grimm fairy tale Mama considers the range of maternal instincts from dutiful indifference to selfish sheltering.
McConaughey is funny and fearsome in the title role, the devil holding the family accountable for their choices.
Frances Ha provides a sharp, fleet, and very funny look at female friendship and the acceptance of adult responsibilities.
Decked out in its fondness for old Hollywood films and American songbook standards, Gray Matters borrows the wallpaper from a Nancy Meyers movie to decorate its empty room.
Holy Motors is gloriously alive with experimentation and the centrality of human involvement regardless of what form the end product of their efforts takes.
The nerds perpetuate a nasty streak of behavior toward women that violates the film's general live-and-let-live attitude, and it stains what is otherwise intended as raunchy but lighthearted fun.
According to 360 the world is united in broken dreams and wounded hearts. It's too bad that playing R.E.M.'s "Everybody Hurts" on a two-hour loop could have expressed the sentiment more effectively.

Although director Lauren Greenfield documents several instances in which it's apparent that the Siegels' lifestyle is so alien from the vast majority that they might as well call Mars home, she hasn't set out to eat the rich.
Rock of Ages is so unpretentious about its aims and the performers are so game for what they surely knew would be this ridiculous that it's hard to resist entirely.
Jack and Jill's lack of energy disguises contempt, but here [Sandler's] working through his issues in a more compelling way than usual.

Hoover's magnetism derives from his intellect, certainty, power, and sense for myth-making, and DiCaprio bears that out with a performance of a man who himself may be constantly performing as though he has nothing to hide.
While existence hangs in the balance in Melancholia, von Trier's fatalistic embrace of impending doom is starkly beautiful and strangely reassuring.
Chances are That's My Boy isn't a contemptuous stunt to see what Sandler can get away with and what audiences will accept; it just seems like one.
Liberally peppered with profanities and comedic hockey-related violence, Goon finds plenty to laugh at in the coarse words and antics of athletes.
A hollow simulation of what fun for the whole family looks and sounds like.
Take This Waltz is an achingly beautiful film in the longing its characters express and the sun-dappled Toronto cinematographer Luc Montpellier captures.
The Dark Knight Rises remains a fascinating film, albeit one that suffers from an excess of ambition and deficiency in unifying its objectives with clarity.
If Extraterrestrial is to explore what might be called Third Wheel Syndrome, Vigalondo needed to bring greater tension to the romantic triangle than what exists.
While the fluid hand-drawn animation provides a pleasant stylistic alternative to the predominance of 3D computer animation in the marketplace, the story leaves a lot to be desired.

The overwhelming number of superhero films of late and the seemingly limitless ability of CGI have taken some of the wonder out of displays of dazzling feats beyond ordinary human potential. Chronicle restores that thrill.
The Vow presents some fascinating challenges for Leo and Paige, yet without fail the screenplay comes up short in allowing them to overcome the obstacles in their paths.
Big Miracle is invested with solid craftsmanship and a nuanced view of how idealism, pragmatism, and politics intersect.
Love is a battlefield in This Means War, and the three likable leads are the casualties.
Wanderlust has a freewheeling, improvisational aesthetic that doles out enough solid jokes, even if it does so erratically.
A Better Life's sense of place and eye for detail are strong, but the too-smooth style and rushed dramatics are at odds with the hardscrabble existence on display.
Once John Carter gets past laying out the specifics of the various Martian cultures and tensions, it settles into a pleasant groove that recalls the old Saturday afternoon serials.

Trollhunter adopts the form of a found footage documentary, which translates as lots of banal conversations, abundant shots of the Scandinavian countryside, and competent but shaky handheld camerawork.
After awhile Casa de mi Padre begins to play as a conceptual exercise rather than a legitimately funny movie in its own right.
21 Jump Street is a smartly stupid buddy comedy that plays with the ridiculousness of its set-up.
Even if it isn't saying much, Wrath of the Titans stands as a minor improvement to its predecessor.
The ill fit between Mirror Mirror's screenplay and its director's sensibilities dooms the comedic fairy tale from the outset.

While made with great technical proficiency, War Horse is determinedly old-fashioned in how Spielberg tells the story, which is a fitting creative strategy considering that the film studies the convergence of the old and the modern.
The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo can't quite transcend its junk foundation or...the familiar beats of the other adaptation.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Alfredson's marvelous precision in showing how an agent might do difficult espionage work is as thrilling as any overblown James Bond setpiece.

With everything, including the most pivotal moments, rendered in shorthand, The Iron Lady diminishes the accomplishments of the person whose story it tells and the actress working so hard to offer a well-rounded embodiment of her.
I Wish excels at evoking a child-like state of mind in all of its wonders and concerns because of Kore-eda's astuteness in following how kids make sense of the world and change their perspectives.
A solidly entertaining blast of summer movie spectacle.
Under African Skies takes what could have been a puff piece glossing over the protestations related to Graceland and teaches the controversy.
For all of it's mirroring of real life circumstances, The Ghost Writer's shrouded revelations are ever transitory.

It's a far cry from what Van Damme and Lundgren were doing twenty years ago, but in the end this film comes off like a band that claims all of the 'right' influences in interviews but can't synthesize good taste into work of merit.
Director Antoine Fuqua gives the well-trod material more room to roam than necessary but fails to shade it in anything but the drabbest law enforcement blue.

Broken into storybook-like chapters...the film implies that it possesses literary roots; however, Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium comes across as a quickie knockoff attempting to capitalize on a more popular title's success.
Enchanted bubbles over with good cheer, due in large part to Adams for the wide-eyed optimism and innocence she brings to her irony-free performance.
Todd Haynes' masterful portrait of Bob Dylan scrutinizes the musician-poet-actor-artist-husband-father-outlaw and leaves him at once as mysterious as ever and yet somehow knowable.
While it may be clichéd to proclaim the original foreign film to be superior, the fact remains that the Japanese pic contains more scares and intended laughs than this slapdash American remake.
For all of the care and creativity put into Walk Hard's original songs, the rest of the film feels less inspired and maybe a little lazy.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Practically a duplicate of the breezy (and bloated) original, National Treasure: Book of Secrets is not without charm, but it lacks the thrill seeker's joy of discovery.
After choking on laughs for a period, the question becomes whether Baumbach has anything to deliver beyond his misanthropic floggings.
Atonement is an exquisitely crafted film bursting with the possibilities that cinema has to offer.
Although The Bucket List shouldn't sit well on the stomach, it goes down as easily as meals through an IV.
There Will Be Blood is a spectacular achievement that, at this early date, seems worthy to be mentioned alongside cinema's avowed masterpieces.
Bridesmaid dresses are notorious for being unflattering, single occasion garments. Although formulaic, 27 Dresses wears well on its star.
Qualms about Rambo's contextual appropriateness aside, this guns-ablazing movie works on a primal level, but stiff performances and a musty script has it firing its share of blanks too.
At the risk of praising with faint damning, Meet the Spartans isn't the worst film I've ever seen; however, I'm not suggesting that this feature-length parody of 300 is good in any way.
Boring, hypocritical, and didactic, Untraceable is an exercise in tut-tutting the audience for being curious about the very stuff the film traffics in.
If it were considered unseemly to speak ill of dead films, then the only thing to recommend about Over Her Dead Body would be the lead actor's palpable indifference.
Instantly forgettable and proudly lazy, Strange Wilderness feels like it's being made up on the spot.
The Eye remake rolls off Hollywood's Asian horror assembly line like expired goods that have been repackaged.
The Diving Bell and the Butterfly transcends the uplifting movie-of-the-week story through Schnabel's artful direction and deep empathy.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Dedication's problem isn't its idealized conception of love but the thoroughly unconvincing way in which it is realized.
Like its namesake mineral, Fool's Gold looks like one thing (a romantic comedy), turns out to be something else (an action-adventure), and has zero value.

Definitely, Maybe stumbles along the way to its destination just like its protagonist does, but the humor and heart compensate for the lack of sure footing that extends all the way to the uncertainty in the title.
Cassandra's Dream is not a top-notch Woody Allen film, but this dark drama is a worthy addition to the director's career-long search for meaning in a world where randomness and cruelty often reign.
While Charlie Bartlett's spitting in the face of authority may thrill disenchanted teens, its obnoxiousness and phoniness is enough to make me feel like an old man yelling at kids to get off my lawn.

Shot in widescreen, all the better to appreciate the swanky art deco sets, Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day can feel static...but the wonderful lead actresses provide the momentum that the composition and editing fail to provide.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: College Road Trip plays like an instructional video shown at orientation to ease sheltering parents afraid to let their children leave the nest.
Executed with machine-like precision, The Bank Job is a ripping good caper with plenty of interesting twists.
With a dreadfully dull story and performances as petrified as 12,000-year-old wooden artifacts, 10,000 BC shambles along as if on a march to its own extinction.
Snow Angels can painfully burrow into one's heart, but such is the cost of empathy, or any human connection for that matter.
The jokes land softly, but Run Fatboy Run moves at a sitcom-like clip that keeps it watchable even when it isn't especially funny.
As good as the action scenes are, the humanity in [Will] Smith's performance is most responsible for I Am Legend's success.
Produced by Judd Apatow and co-written by Seth Rogen, Drillbit Taylor has a been there, done that quality reminiscent of Superbad if it were much tamer and less funnier.
As a showcase for Washington and Crowe, American Gangster does not disappoint.
Damaged individuals healing one another is a serviceable idea for a film, but Things We Lost in the Fire is missing an essential component: plausibility.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Told with compassion and delicacy, The Namesake provides a stirring view of cultural assimilation and personal discovery.
As a politically-charged action film, it accomplishes the mission.

No one will mistake Ice Cube's comic timing for Cary Grant's, but this remake of the 1948 RKO comedy Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House is a moderately amusing family film, if not a terribly inspired one.
Blades of Glory has the sport's absurd elements down cold and skates by on Ferrell's comic bluster. Even the French judge would agree.

The mantra in Meet the Robinsons is 'keep moving forward', but it's in going back to traditional narrative and filmmaking values that helps set this animated romp apart from many of its contemporaries.
Like a southern fried X-Files, The Reaping explores peculiar incidents with a mix of belief and skepticism, at least for a time, but it loses its potency as paranormal answers become verified.
In terms of the five stages of grief, Jimmy spends most of the film in denial and anger--understandably so--but it grinds First Snow into dramatic inertia.
Perfect Stranger is a perfectly mediocre thriller until the spectacularly stupid ending arrives.
With the burden of inevitable comparisons to Hitchcock's masterpiece upon it, Disturbia carves out its own modest spot as a decent thriller until caving in to the demand for a big finish.
...as satisfying as a weeks-long case being dismissed on a technicality. It makes all that time feel like a monumental waste.
Canines hear sounds inaudible to human ears. Maybe the same is true of the humor in Year of the Dog.
Blessed with an airtight script, a sterling cast of comedic actors, and a director in peak form, Hot Fuzz is an arresting farce sure to keep audiences locked up with laughter.
Writer-director Jon Kasdan's attempt at character-based dramedy manages some good scenes, but as a whole In the Land of Women feels incomplete and inauthentic.
From the nifty Saul Bass-inspired opening credits until the end, Vacancy is persistent in streamlining its thriller tropes.
This very funny film should get audiences strumming along on their own air guitars and flashing devil horns in support of these masters of mock rock.
Next plays like the most boring episode ever of 24, with a little extrasensory flavor tossed in for good measure.
Kickin' It Old Skool equates making incalculable 80s pop culture references with joke telling.
With undue emphasis placed on the cards instead of the characters, Lucky You is holding a losing hand by the time it reaches the river.
The subject matter in Georgia Rule--sexual abuse and alcoholism, for starters--lends itself to drama, but Garry Marshall's tone deaf direction and Mark Andrus' sloppy script play it as comedy.
A tense and terrifying trip through urban chaos, 28 Weeks Later is Juan Carlos Fresnadillo's respectable follow-up to Danny's Boyle's original.
After the Wedding's anguished portrait of family, charity, and mortality peels back layers in the characters that defy their easy categorization.
Where the character cannot maintain well-adjusted behavior over sociopathic indulgences, the film fails to strike a balance between the serious and outlandish.
Bug straddles the lines of genre seediness and high art pretension, but it's not enough of a cheap thrill or mindbender to succeed at either.
With equal measures of raunch and sentimentality, Knocked Up explores the minefield of imminent parenthood for two people who don't know each other very well.
Making the team and playing in the big game grab the headlines, but the repaired relationship at the heart of Gracie shows that there are bigger prizes than kicking a ball around a field.
If junior high school boys wrote a cheesecake syndicated TV show and spun it off into a movie, the result would be DOA: Dead or Alive.
Ocean's Thirteen shows that summer movies and their attendant presumption of needing to turn one's brain off can still be executed with style and wit.
It's just the same old same old repackaged as the new worst offender.
This well-meaning talkathon about the war on terror, contemporary politics, journalistic integrity, and civic engagement has enlightenment more than entertainment as its goal.
Lars and the Real Girl could have felt overly precious, like a cheap stunt or joke, but the emotional depth and warmth make this quirky regional character study anything but plastic.
The lack of explanations in The Ruins may prove unsatisfying to some, but the unknown is often more terrifying than the tangible. Such are the wages of fear.
TMNT amounts to no more than an extended episode of a television cartoon, but this new adventure gets in enough laughs and action to make it worth fans coming out with their shells on to see it.

Unsurprisingly Zombie Strippers is poorly acted, written, directed, edited, and lit, but it is so tedious to watch that this might be the first movie that would be improved if Uwe Boll were calling the shots.
An Education showcases several fine performances in this story about the dangers of youthful cleverness.
The old dogs of the title may refer to the not quite senior citizen leads, but it's a more apt description of the shopworn and laughless jokes occupying this woofer of a comedy.
Armored should crackle with nervous energy; however, the bland characters don't get much of interest to do and are virtually interchangeable.
Purely as a visual and visceral experience, puckish writer-diretor Lars von Trier produces an enormously powerful phantasmagoria that deals with and reproduces the effects of fear and depression.
The film serves as a reminder that no matter how dire the circumstances, truly remarkable change is possible.
The mediocre material gets a boost from a hardworking Grant, who uses his trademark bumbling formality to deliver dry commentary and wring out the most laughs possible.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Road is a haunting portrait of what it means to be a parent.
Nine doesn't remake Federico Fellini's 8 1/2 so much as it pillages the classic film for the purposes of Broadway vamping.
Streep, Baldwin, and Martin are having so much fun in this romantic comedy-drama that it's impossible not to get swept up in the good time they're having as well.
The film has been lauded for being very of the moment in its treatment of massive corporate layoffs, but where it truly shines...is how it details the importance of a personal touch.
Leap Year is not constructed from the finest materials, but its two appealing lead actors make the most with what they're given to provide a sweet, breezy escape.
As a testament to the importance of the written word in its lowercase and uppercase meanings, THE BOOK OF ELI makes for an odd but compelling action film in defense of literacy and Christian faith.
The Messenger's clipped insight that war is hell is just the sort of line straight from the manual that the film strenuously cautions against.
G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra is like a term paper that fulfills the word count requirement and drops in key phrases to demonstrate some familiarity with the material but is largely filler.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Soderbergh and Burns deftly present the puzzling information in a clear and highly entertaining manner, but for all of their hard, workmanlike efforts, the film is Damon's through and through.
Kusama and Cody don't fully succeed in making Jennifer's Body as clever as intended, but...they unleash some potent ideas and subvert the genre
Even if many of the jokes in Cop Out aren't all that funny, Smith's facility with crude wordplay is what he salvages from this huge mess of a film.

Surrogates establishes an intriguing premise for exploring a world in which virtual life trumps physical reality, but the thematic potential is squandered in favor of a by-the-numbers police procedural.
The feminist coming of age sports dramedy has a sweet and sunny disposition bolstered by a proud independent streak.
Gervais has helped craft a funny but inconsistent film, yet I'd be lying if I didn't mention that I appreciate the ambition and humor put into what could have been a one-note premise.
Paranormal Activity isn't an actor's film per se, but it wouldn't be as eerily effective without Featherston and Sloat's believable, lived in performances.
Percy Jackson & the Olympians is a dutifully made kids' fantasy film that Columbus handles with the basic approach that he wielded on his faithful but vanilla Harry Potter adaptations.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like a carnival barker, The Human Centipede entices the adventurous with the promise of a repulsive display that begs to be seen but fails in its delivery of gory one-upmanship.
No Strings Attached entices with its libertine premise about the joys of relationship-free sex, but the come-on is really just a lusty tease for a standard romantic comedy.
As incredible as it may sound regarding an amnesia thriller, Unknown's plot isn't silly enough to merit where it ends up taking the main character.
Shine a Light doesn't break any new ground for Scorsese or the Stones, but it's an enjoyable showcase for the prodigious skills the director and band have.
Hall Pass plays like a third or fourth sequel to The Hangover filtered through cheap pop psychology.
The Illusionist is the next best thing to a new Tati movie.
Beastly plays as an apologia for bad boys and the saintly girls who find them irresistible.
Daniels employs a throw everything at the wall to see what sticks directorial style that makes Precious compelling viewing, but predictably, his shotgun approach lacks focus.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Emmerich would be better off losing the pretense of respectability and embracing the B-movie showmanship that is clearly his strength.
Astro Boy may have many of the same parts as the source material, but as Dr. Tenma learns, trying to replicate something doesn't mean you end up with the same original.
The diverting garbage that is Law Abiding Citizen would be more deplorable if it were possible to take this wholly implausible film seriously.
A slapdash but amiable crossbreed of The Karate Kid and The Wizard of Oz, The Forbidden Kingdom functions as a martial arts cinema primer for American youth.
...too much of the film is filled with material better served for the behind-the-scenes section on the electronic press kit.
The Clone Wars elicits some pangs of nostalgia with its grand battles, alien landscapes, and beloved characters but yields little more than fuzzy thoughts of what used to be.
The deft touch with which it addresses spouses' and parents' professional and personal trade-offs proves this to be a more substantial and poignant picture than expected.
The obvious but effective tactic of contrasting words and visuals scrapes off the veneer of domestic bliss that people put on for the world and which gets pasted in scrapbooks and hung on walls.
Except for the presence of Hong Kong star Chow Yun-Fat, this shoddy live-action film is no different or bigger than the sort of junk kids plop down to watch on TV after school.
...an ungainly and incomprehensible assault on the senses.
This uninspired Torah-lampooning sketch comedy is as arid and empty as the landscapes which the protagonists wander across.
Biel's performance lacks the zing needed to jolt this comedy of manners.
An affectionate portrait rather than a sad, derisive takedown, Anvil! The Story of Anvil finds inspiration in the passion and tenacity these aging metalheads display.
Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian can be too cluttered and hyperactive to appreciate its broad pleasures.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Terminator Salvation boasts impressive setpieces that provide eye-popping visual scale, but the story so badly lacks scope that the film feels small and, ultimately, inconsequential.
It raises big, intriguing questions that rarely, if ever, come up in the hubbub about steroid use in professional athletics, particularly Major League Baseball.
The first Friday the 13th is not a masterwork by any stretch of the imagination, but it has one crucial thing the 2009 edition lacks completely: the element of surprise.
What's missing in this Wolfman is something timeless: the human cost that gives tragic meaning to the metamorphosis and potential cure.
Without any palpable sense of terror or political subtext, the film is analogous to its not-exactly-zombie townsfolk who stagger about purposefully but blankly.

Canny and well-crafted.

Better than it has to be.
Plenty thought-provoking, but it's not much of a movie and ultimately inspires curiosity rather than passion.
At its best this is grade-A pulp from the land of Elmore Leonard.

Worth a look for its bravura, which should endear the movie most of all to prospective filmmakers with maxed-out credit cards and heads full of dreams.
Well-considered, beautifully made, and often gripping in its narrative, the film epitomizes the best the documentary format can offer.

Cinematically, it's like watching your lawn grow.
... surprisingly fresh and charming overall.

... American Dreamz is kind of all over the place from the beginning.

Garçon Stupide is interesting enough to merit an audience broader than its intended niche, though it isn't perfect.
With more attention to the fundamentals of narrative, Over the Hedge wouldn't be so over the top.
It's a checklist of summer-movie elements arranged with enough care to suggest that it should add up to more than a pleasant diversion.
The movie isn't perfect -- Spielberg-slick, its power is sometimes dampened by melodrama that overstates its message -- but it is compelling and thought-provoking and topical as hell.
Akeelah has lofty goals, and though it doesn't always achieve them, it is a rewarding tale for public educators, parents, and kids with big dreams.
This smarty-pants campus yarn is on fire with satire.

Mixes environmental awareness and spiritual mindfulness with its chase scenes through grand scenery.

An observant and effective study in character and setting, suitably grave and distinctively realized.
Bickford is an assured first feature for former Beacon Pictures exec Lew, with a winning cast and an infectious spirit.
It's the snobs vs. the slobs! And this holiday's no picnic!
Devotes itself to youthful inertia.

Pleasantly diverting.

Poetry is dead - but maybe a five-year-old boy can save it, with the help of his kindergarten teacher.

The film is powerful; a skillful study in landscape as well as character.

Fun for a bit, things soon turns silly ...

Documentary about the phenomenal tennis stars Venus and Serena Williams sees them as women as well as phenomenon.

If nothing else, the movie's themes are announced: domesticity, ogling, excrement.

movie_review_blurb: ...a cynical extension, not even an earnest spin-off.
History of Chinese Communism drowns in data.
movie_title: The Beginning of a Great Revival (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In this slick, professionally assembled football documentary, Muslim-American director Rashid Ghazi focuses on Arabs living in Dearborn, Michigan in a post-9/11 world.

Action star Sam Worthington plays a disgraced cop threatening suicide from atop a hotel ledge, but we rapidly lose interest.

A lovely fable about nature and motherhood in the North Pole. The problem is, it may scare the pants off you. The other problem is, it's all true.

What to Expect is like what they say about childbirth--You'll scarcely remember a thing when it's over, but you won't need that epidural either.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A witty, visual demonstration of the wild muscularity of contemporary dance--and why we no longer giggle at "men in tights."

The feminist documentary takes up the battered-wife syndrome, low pay for female workers, forced separation of mothers and children and-finally-a woman-owned business. Gloria Steinem must be happy, though the film centers on 69-year-old twin hookers.

But for a walk on the wild side with a dangerous rake, look elsewhere. As one of the characters in the film says, the world (at least the movie world) doesn't need a hero, it needs a monster. Got that right.
This animated feature is tricky to get into, but soon enough becomes a colorful pinata spreading goodies hither and yon.

Using these sequences, letting things be unresolved yet still relatable to anyone of any age, sex or career stage, was a great creative decision. Brandy becomes us.

movie_title: On Any Sunday, The Next Chapter (2014)

movie_review_blurb: All else rings true: creativity versus personal commitment, sacrifices for your art which might not pan out, the scintillating but sometimes scuzzy New York scene.

movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Taking no sides and every side, Stones in the Sun is a powerful tripartite narrative from Haitian filmmaker Patricia Benoit, using her own family history.

movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This Sundance Award-winning comedy-drama handles two incredibly difficult topics-cancer and male/female friendship (sans sex)-with charm, insight and humor.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

Even at its overlong over two hours, Steak only gets occasionally repetitive ...
Passionate, polemical, and not just a little bit pedantic.
movie_title: Tango Negro: The African Roots of Tango (2015)

movie_review_blurb: He Named Me Malala is much more effective than any essay or political speech on the destructive nature of what the Taliban is attempting to do.

A messed up mélange which manages to mislay a few themes along the way.

Spirituality plus good deeds continue a tradition of East Indian introspection in Gurukulam.

Without the epic sweep of a Doctor Zhivago, it's an intellectual and emotional landscape Vera traverses: grief to survival and, finally, pacifism.

"Cutie and the Boxer," like all truly noteworthy films, takes you by surprise with its unexpected twists and revelations.
"Standing Up" is mildly entertaining. Basso picks up steam as the movie moves ahead, but for the first third or so she seems to display only whininess.
"A Teacher" will leave you feeling drained, even exhausted. That's about right for a movie about obsession, one with no resolution except waiting for the other thud to drop.
It's not a pretty picture, but it's a compelling one.
We Are What We Are has elevated the horror genre into first-class moviemaking.
In the debut documentary of Greg "Freddy" Camalier, it's a toss-up as to which is more magical -- the physical place of Muscle Shoals, Alabama, or the music it produced.
It falls to Irish actress Saoirse Ronan to carry the burden of family reclamation in a post-nuclear age...For the most part, she manages.

Live at the Foxes Den is like a sketch of an idea of what life might be like if you could keep doing re-dos.
It is not the most subtly layered documentary I've ever seen, but these days it's no longer verboten to take a stance in docs. And there is so much to be admired about Hanna.
The tale of a modern-day Icarus. His wings didn't melt, but his brain cracked. He lived, but he learned to question the trip.
Easy to like, if hard to believe (though you still want to)
The message gets muddled with plot strands going every which way, though the real culprit is some awkward animation.
...Endless Love is silly and trumped up, though it may do something for tween girls dreaming over Pettyfer.
Many fine talents are thrown into this witch's cauldron of chopped-off bits from other horror films, but it doesn't cohere.
Defiant doppelgangers limn the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but didacticism destroys the tension.
Much of this is in the "who knew" mode, and it's lovely to get extended shots of the art. But the human angle is not skirted either.
More of a meandering, misguided path than a road to hell, Naomi Foner's directing debut, starring Dakota Fanning and Elizabeth Olsen as 18-year-old BFFs, is similarly filled with good intentions.

With a lot of travelogue-type footage and some introspection, director Maria Sole Tognazzi's A Five Star Life finds a new angle to the women's issues we thought we already settled, or at least had enough of for now.

Writer-director Paul Haggis' new film will most likely screen soon on long airline flights: perfect for a movie where you sometimes don't know where you are, and with so many plot ellipses you needn't worry if you missed something while in the loo.
Facing its issues with such wit and attitude keeps the film from ever being lugubrious. That and Shailene Woodley.
Earth to Echo is a shame-free replication (or homage) to E.T. and Chronicle, but mainly hits home with its universal worry: What happens when best teen buds are forced to separate?
James Gray's film sticks in your head both for the images it creates, and for those triggered in myth memory, of the immigrant experience in America.
