Toss in some scenes cleverly reminiscent of the spritzy routines of Diner (but with older folks) and the boiler-room sales tactics of Glengarry Glen Ross, and you've got the best highlights of Small Time...
...Authors Anonymous manages to be sweet-tempered mainly thanks to lead Kaley Cuoco.
The more things change, the more they remain the same -- Arnold.
Shirin in Love, like its protagonist, looks ditzy at first but quickly becomes a thinking woman's romantic comedy, making a lie of recent media claims that the genre is defunct.
So add We Are the Best! to the growing canon of excellent girl-band movies...And in this film, being in a band is a way to find yourself.
Edge of Darkness isn't a great film but it's crisply efficient one that's almost always engrossing...Gibson has fire in his eye and gravel in his Bahston accent.
Absolutely worth the time required to see the whole story. Don't let the demand of cumulative running time scare you away from what is a deeply satisfying movie experience.
But the writing consistently misfires...It's as if Rhodes has a blueprint for a certain kind of comedy but not the tools or materials to construct it.
Finds the sweet spot in that realm of disturbing, unpredictable drama tinged with the blackest possible comedy...a deliciously dark and offbeat surprise.
The action barely pauses %u2013 and when it does, the talk is hardly memorable. But talk is cheap; fireballs coming out of exploding SUVs are not.
Your time is better spent tracking down a DVD of the original, which was a highlight of a rapidly deteriorating genre.
It stalls out after an hour, then stumbles along for another 50 minutes of the usual Sparksian palate of life lessons and regrets and sadness.
Green ably creates the tension of expected and inevitable consequences...forcing the audience to imagine how difficult it would be to survive.
Ajami isn't a downbeat film, though it is a relentless one. It is alive with energy, if only the energy devoted to survival.
The Good Guy builds its power as it goes, taking you places you don't expect. It's the rare movie that can surprise you in that way %u2013 but this one does.
The finale is like watching Mexican pro wrestling, except instead of wearing colorful masks, they're covered with fur...it doesn't suck, but it doesn't have much bite, either.
It's not awful. It's just not particularly inspired. Something tells me this movie won't be inspiring a sequel anytime soon.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like a lunatic's trip to Wonderland, it builds suspense with only brief respites, reaching a climax that is truly shattering. Hang on tight.
When it all becomes clear, all the jagged edges go away and the film comes into focus as the well-honed thriller it has been all along.
It works more often than it doesn't, but it never quite goes where you expect. And that's rare enough to be noteworthy.
This alleged action-comedy is flatter than a tortilla in a panini press...C'mon, Kevin Smith, quit smoking weed and write a new movie of your own.
Built for one purpose only: to scare the crap out of you. Which it does, regularly and effectively. Don't go expecting anything deeper -- or anything less.
Exactly what the magic of movies is about, giving you a risk-free front-row seat that still manages to make you feel like you're caught up in the action.
Toe to Toe features two exceptionally layered performances at its center, as well as ideas that don't sort themselves out in neat and easily summarized fashion.
Light your money on fire and watch it burn. It will have an equivalent entertainment value and you'll save on gas, parking and snacks.
Feels like two different films cobbled together, without much to connect one to the other...the disconnect between the two is huge.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There are more sophisticated animated films out there, but none with the sheer joie de vivre that this Belgian stop-motion-animation entry packs into 75 rollicking minutes.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's room for both drama and fun in director Michael Hoffman's staid script, but he doesn't find much of either. And the key problem seems to be: not enough Tolstoy.
A feast of ideas, sensations and images that pull you into a world you never could (and never would want to) visit or inhabit..expansive, encompassing and yet deeply personal.
The problem is clearly the screenplay. Unfortunately for the cast and director Hines, the script was obviously sacrosanct. And that sinks the movie.
One of the year's most moving performances %u2013 by Colin Firth %u2013 set against what appears to be one long perfume commercial from the early 1990s.
Freeman, a thinking man's actor, lets us into Mandela's head without having to explain what he's got on his mind.
A hard subject beautifully handled, with an artistry that makes The Lovely Bones a memorably intelligent and emotional experience.
There are visionary filmmakers - and then there's James Cameron, who pushes the envelope of what is possible on the screen every time he makes a film. He doesn't do it nearly often enough.
A compact, economical treat: full of flavor and feeling, wrapped in an unprepossessing package that contains far more than you'd ever imagine.
Nine offers mostly lackluster music ... Yet, without the music, Nine would be that absolutely unnecessary object: a remake of 8 1/2.
The damp of England lends this whole film a certain sogginess. Indeed, in the whole of The Young Victoria, there's barely a crackle or crunch to be had.
A masterpiece of missed opportunities...a Lifetime movie about a depressed dad instead of a bereft mom. Would you pay to see that?
Meyers' script is as bloated as her work on her past films ... But she has a cast of consummate professionals to dress this up and make it seem like more than it is.
Yet another case of a film with not enough story for the amount of movie there is...more interesting for what it wasn't allowed to be than for what it is.
A pointless, bloodless cinematic construct obsessed with man's capacity for cruelty...the equivalent of watching someone pull the wings off flies.
It's a business-horror story of greed and market share...You don't have to look far (corporate global-warming deniers, anyone?) to find a corollary in contemporary reality.
Has a strong Dickensian flavor, blending slapstick with social satire...You'll laugh at Cera's off-rhythm delivery and casual sharpness wrapped in the softest possible tones.
The kind of movie of which I wish I could say, "You couldn't pay me to watch that crap." Obviously, however, you can - but not nearly enough.
The script feels slim, as though Goldin, lacking inspiration for actual witty lines, hoped that Broderick might bring some comedic spin to the wan dialogue.
It works because of the immediacy of Andrea Arnold's filmmaking and the jittery vitality of the central performance by a young actress named Katie Jarvis.
Denzel Washington is an actor who makes his own gravitas. Even the great Denzel must surrender to his his inability to make spiritualist silliness seem serious.
A kid's film that's distressingly short on both wit and action. Obviously, Jackie Chan isn't immune to making one for the paycheck and phoning in his performance.
Belongs on a shelf next to the Will Smith Wild Wild West: a remake that seems more excreted than created... too long, too generic and not nearly as clever as it seems to think.
Tough and sorrowful...A dirty little beauty, a cop tale in which nobody wins and the best one can hope for is a draw. Except for the audience, that is.
Many gun battles and fiery explosions ensue, all of them free of excitement or suspense...Saldana and Morgan have the chemistry of two strangers who just met at a tax audit.
None of the actors make much of an impression in Stolen. But then, neither does the film itself.
Quiet, deliberate and understated in its humor and romance...a subtle, polished story...There is, one hopes, still room for a film as charming and layered as this one.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Juicy and exciting...Seeing it will make you understand why its more classical approach to story-telling won over the Oscar voters.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Sharp-edged...a smart comedy with an agenda that, for the most part, knows what it's about and gets about it. It's not perfect but it's full of surprises.
Outrageous and funny, cheaply shot but knowingly edited...Is it art? Who cares? It's definitely fascinating and engrossingly watchable.
While it jumps the rails at a couple of different points dramatically, Handsome Harry keeps winning you back because of Jamey Sheridan's performance.
Essentially confirmed what I suspected, based on the commercials: that everything that was meticulously etched in the original would be scrawled in crayon in this version.
Feels contrived,rather than organic. It's like a cynical attempt to make movie version of a downbeat Bruce Springsteen song.
An overstuffed Lifetime movie, if that network for women ever made movies about nice guys who happen to be sex-addicted murder suspects with a sleep disorder.
Caan's touchingly clueless longing makes Mercy stand out as an adult romantic drama that earns its hankies
If only Kick-Ass were as nervy and entertaining as its brazen title. Unfortunately, the weakest part of Kick-Ass is, well, Kick-Ass himself.
Comes from a raw, tougher place than the Guy Ritchie gangster hijinx. These characters don't banter or practice gymnastics; they act brutally and are brutalized in return.
Like an old-school nature film, one that allows its images and characters to tell the story for it.
Like a math equation whose inevitability doesn't diminish its crisp clarity of truth...It unwraps its surprises in ways that pay off as the movie goes on.
If you listen and read closely, the positive reviews will be cloaking their praise of Iron Man 2 in rationalizations, rather than letting it flow unfettered.
It should be required viewing for anyone who wants to vote in the 2010 election and has teabags stapled to their person.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of those could-have-been-worse movies. But it also could have been much, much better.
It's as if what Scott really wanted to do was make a movie about the signing of the Magna Carta, then got cold feet.
Easily the most provocative film I've seen in ages, one that pushed me way out of my comfort zone and yet kept me spellbound throughout.
A date movie for the undiscriminating...Anyone who might accidentally think about what they're seeing should probably stay away.
They aren't making a movie about the comic misadventures of a lovable scalawag. Just the opposite...a daring, downbeat message...Douglas does some of his best work in years.
Holofcener's deliciously understated film takes a miniaturist's pleasure in getting the details right.
Lord of the Rings and every woman-warrior myth you've ever heard of, with a Lewis Carroll overlay...His worst since Planet of the Apes or Batman Returns.
Zaks finds the life in every scene, even the more clichéd ones...it feels like a celebration of a seminal musical moment, for all its flaws.
It's not terrible, and I mean that as the mildest of praise...it's better than expected, if not outstanding or noteworthy in any other way.
A sleeper, a film of deceptive power that sneaks up on you...builds to a climax that is both shattering and filled with deliciously acrid irony.
A compelling action movie built on a false premise: that honest soldiers telling the truth helped the press raise public awareness and turn the tide of opinion against the war.
Laughs? Sorry, they didn't RSVP for this affair. Neither should you.
Limp and witless. A romantic drama with all the body of chicken noodle soup.
You have to hang with it, squeezing pleasure and the occasional chuckle out of its bitter beauty where you can. It's not for everyone but it rewards those who are open to it.
Deceptively funny, a blithe mix of smarts and feeling that never panders to the audience.
A great soundtrack: If only the movie showed that much range or energy...mundane and formulaic.
No one seems to have a clue about how to inject life into lifeless material...a cinematic meal of soft, bland fare only.
It doesn't really have anything on its mind at all, except finding creative ways to photograph arterial blood spraying from someone's neck.
Tough and entertaining, a film that coils itself around you like a constrictor and squeezes. You won't want it to let you go.
Builds to a climax you may or may not buy. But go along for the ride; it's one that's alternately hot and chilling.
Dragon is a solid comedy-adventure, though a few more laughs would have been helpful. It will delight kids and amuse their parents.
Fantasy vs. fiscal considerations -- the eternal struggle between art and commerce. In the end, art triumphed and business (and the personal conflicts) won out.
Suddenly abandons all comedic promises and turns into a sadistic action film...a textbook example of a promising movie that takes a wrong turn from which it never recovers.
A squirmy-funny exercise in oddness that happily takes its time getting to the truth...Church hasn't had many roles as juicy as the title character of Don McKay.
Aside from further output from Lady Gaga, I can't think of much that's more unnecessary than a remake of Clash of the Titans, at least until they remake Godzilla.
A smart, finely wrought tale that will have you choked up and nodding your head at the same time...It's about much more than simply triggering the audience's tear ducts.
Drags and lollygags, suffering from a sense of seriousness and self-importance that saps it of energy and tension.
If you were a fan of the Doors, you won't miss When You're Strange. And if you weren't a fan, well, you will be by the end of this compelling and involving documentary.
Either you'll go with After.Life's conceit or you won't. Even if you do, you're left with more questions about its plausibility than you'll be comfortable with.
While it does include two or three scream-worthy moments, they neither define nor dominate what is, in the end, a lovely tale of grief, love and moving on.
One of the few Robert De Niro roles in recent memory that doesn't equate acting with histrionics...one of the quietest performances of his career, yet one of the most moving.
Provocative and funny at the same time...a window into a world most white people (or most people in general) know nothing about, one that is not quite what it seems to be.
A headlong story to go with its brilliantly imaginative and fanciful visuals and bright, upbeat score by Randy Newman, who covers a lot of ground.
A childlike wonder wedded to dazzlingly imaginative visuals, in a story of surprising simplicity and equally surprising emotional depth.
Fortunately, only a third of the film is devoted to Jack White. It's not enough to spoil the pleasures of this rocking little treasure of a movie.
That it's also shamelessly tear-jerking in that warm, enveloping way that Hollywood can do so well from time to time is a plus, not a minus.
Spread may not amount to much but Kutcher will change perceptions of who he is as an actor for anyone who sees it.
Tarantino understands that the key ingredient in a thriller is the suspense...it's the tension that thrills you, that makes you squirm and feel totally alive to the moment.
It's like seeing a Broadway show from a seat you could never buy. It may be a Spike Lee Joint, but he never forces his stamp on it. He lets it flow in all its joyous wonder.
As imaginative as Shorts is, it's never very funny. Rodriguez apparently was too busy to be bothered with honing the script so the jokes actually generate laughs.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Watching The Baader-Meinhof Complex is like a trip to a recent past that is too easily forgotten.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film's flaws and charms just about balance each other out.
The "wow" factor in Neill Blomkamp's District 9 is huge, so much so that it would be easy to overlook what a soulful, tragically heroic story it is.
Overturns clichés of hypocritical sanctimony with surprising laughs. Bobcat Goldthwait may be the most unique filmmaking sensibility since Albert Brooks.
Oswalt's performance is at once hilarious and touching, shifting from sunny to cloudy to stormy with a smoothness that's inspiring.
Wintour, apparently, is queen of the universe %u2013 or the fashion universe. Which has as much to do with the real universe as Spongebob does to the plight of the dolphin.
Judge, unfortunately, is not judgmental enough to bail on the jokes that don't bear fruit %u2013 and not driven enough to really exploit the ones that do.
It's impossible to watch this film and not come away with a personal vow never to patronize the Chevron corporation again.
A computer-animated wonder, an apocalyptic action-thriller that's a little like The Terminator meets WALL-E.
Can a great surprise at the end make up for all of the earlier flaws? Only if you've got ADD.
The Other Man feels like a movie that focuses on the hole, instead of the doughnut.
If you're on Soderbergh's wavelength, you'll laugh yourself silly at the chutzpah of The Informant!, a bold comic take on a serious story.
An emotionally naked performance by Theron, an actress who knows how to reveal herself without making a big deal of it. It's a showcase role, but not a showy one.
As unlikely and enjoyable a memento of that long-gone moment in the age of Aquarius as we're likely to find in this 40th anniversary year of the epochal rock festival.
Two problems: Cody's script is barely funny %u2013 and what humor there is gets crushed by the heavy-handed direction of Karyn Kusama and the marginal acting skills of Megan Fox.
In his dreams, Stephen Sommers is Michael Bay.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In this comic tug of war, Yi and Cera both pull in the same direction -- and barely pull, at that. It's the acting equivalent of its boneless music. No friction = no laughs.
A film that will amaze the under-10 crowd and keep their parents distracted (and, surprisingly often, entertained) as well.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The chemistry between each pairing of the three principals is surprisingly potent and that's what makes this film work.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: With its easy-going pacing and consistently funny give-and-take, Humpday is more than just a one-joke movie. It's a perceptive comedy about masculinity.
The performances that Soul Power captures are so captivating, so exciting, that it holds its own...I defy anyone to sit still through this infectiously funky doc.
A window into a bygone world that seems so much simpler ... when the medium minted its first superstars, including Liberace, Bishop Fulton Sheen %u2013 and Gertrude Berg.
A movie that will make you laugh so hard you'll gasp for breath...The formula is familiar, but Baron Cohen still finds ways to shock you into guffaws, over and over.
This Chris Columbus film is as painfully unfunny as any movie this summer %u2013 or in recent memory. A chimp could have written this script...goes from grad to worse.
Bittersweet, a movie whose many laughs are balanced by the moments of heartbreak...I'd call it a date movie -- except it's likely to cause more arguments than agreements.
Thrilling storytelling, a sumptuous, engrossing tale...not the first film this summer to clock in at two-and-a-half hours %u2013 but the first to make that time seem to fly by.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ephron wanted to compare and contrast the two women...But the bottom line is that one of those lives is truly interesting, while the other is truly not
A fascinating mess: sprawling, passionate, conflicted, confused...It may not be a film with a lot of clarity to its vision, but it definitely has vision, which is rare.
It may be the smartest, funniest political comedy since Wag the Dog.
It's rare that a movie manages to be both graceful and biting at the same time, let alone smart, funny and sweet. But The Answer Man fills the bill.
It's tempting to make a joke based on the title of The Ugly Truth. But that would require investing this review with more actual wit than the entire film contains.
One of the most important and heroic pieces of work I've ever seen...the year's most exciting film -- as well as a documentary that can't help but leave you upset and outraged.
A film that is full of heart and wit. Give it a chance and you'll find yourself drawn into this character's life in ways that will both touch and amuse you.
Dori Berinstein's charming film goes beyond the "cute old people" pigeonhole...becomes an underdog tale of unlikely heroes fighting the odds and overcoming expectations.
An overweight, out-of-shape comedy with serious aspirations and not nearly enough discipline to see them through...it runs out of laughs after about an hour.
Though not completely successful, it's still a bold, wildly juicy film that goes for the throat and never relents.
Straightforward, brutal and exciting, a gripping tale of men ready for death in the face of unknowable treachery and a vicious enemy.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A bizarre mash-up of Fatal Attraction and Stephen King's Misery, with so many risible premises that it's hard to know where to begin.
With this deft, witty, smart and soulful film, Reitman establishes himself as a modern purveyor of the same cinematic tradition as Frank Capra and Preston Sturges.
Bright Star seems to be a lot about very little, a miniature projected to Imax size. So much goes unspoken that what remains seems almost trite.
A well-written and insightful drama built around two beautifully modulated performances by Tucci (who directed) and the always-marvelous Patricia Clarkson.
A powerful and compelling drama based on a true story that still resonates.
Not that it ever gets beneath the surface - but that surface was so multi-faceted and exciting, at least in this context, that it makes this film impossible to ignore.
A delicious and funny trip through the powers of the mind ... You couldn't ask for a better cast of actors for this offbeat and frequently hilarious tale.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Complex and fulfilling...a beautifully etched slice of a life that's always compelling.
Thankfully, this Christmas Carol is Scrooge-centric...and, thanks to an unusually layered performance by Jim Carrey, that mostly saves the day for this film.
Precious is a powerful social drama telling a gripping personal story. It will put you through the wringer and take your breath away.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A movie whose reach far exceeds its maker's grasp of where this story is going or what it's really about. The longer it goes on, the less sense (or suspense) it has to offer.
It's a fascinating experiment that also happens to be an interesting and highly watchable movie.
As powerful and restrained a drama as you could wish for...a film of both great sadness and great redemption.
This is a world of freaks, who exist to be laughed at - except there's nothing funny about them but their looks.
Is Fantastic Mr. Fox a film for kids or adults? Well, yes %u2013 and each will come away with something different.
The most jeopardy these women confronted was the day they said yes to Women in Trouble.
Mazzio feels the beating heart of the striver and, as a result, Ten9Eight: Shoot for the Moon never drags, even as it offers an important message to audiences.
Blazes across the screen with a sweep that most movies can only dream of. It's nice to see a master like Woo at the height of his powers, after slipping Hollywood's shackle.
Ultimately, race has nothing to do with the truth of the emotions this film elicits from an audience. It's a solid movie, whether you're color blind or not.
Like a well-crafted novel, Broken Embraces takes its time revealing its true intentions...an emotional time bomb, packed with passion, color, romance and tragedy.
Cage acts, at times, as though his head is about to explode. And not the character's head; it's Cage himself who seems in danger of self-immolation.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie that proves that Zac Efron is a real actor, not just a teen star...The real find here is McKay, who has the music of Welles' voice tuned perfectly.
A film that takes a bleak, harrowing story and makes it tender and compelling...deserves to be in the Oscar hunt for the shattering performance by its star, Viggo Mortensen.
This story of unpredictable second and third acts is a treat, a smart drama with flashes of comedy that keep you guessing...Wright's comic timing is adept.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Enjoyable in a lazy way, it feels a bit trifling. Given his apparent passion for the period and the subject, it's disappointing that all Curtis can come up with is this film.
Engaging without really being memorable. It ends almost where it starts, and so feels like it doesn't go much of anywhere at all.
That's the problem with this sort of homage: Unless you've got a startling new take, you wind up with a movie that's been done hundreds of times before, to much better effect.
While it doesn't say "To be continued" at the end, it might as well, except the probable audience's response may turn out to be, "Why bother?"
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A scathing indictment of modern America's "me first" approach to the social contract...an urgently important piece of work.
Scott Hicks' film never confuses sentimentality for genuine feeling. Owen brings a range to this role that that he hasn't previously had much opportunity to reveal.
A Serious Man is the Coens at their best: wonderfully odd, darkly comic and just plain weird,
Page is ill-served by Barrymore, whose only directions apparently were shrieks of "Cuter! No, even cuter!"...turgid, predictable and not particularly funny.
Teamwork, not victory: That's the message of More Than a Game and it's a worthy one that makes for exciting filmmaking.
A fascinating examination of parental love and the blind faith that sometimes is required in what otherwise seems like a cold and cruel world.
The problem of The Invention of Lying isn't the single joke %u2013 it's the lack of others to flesh it out...Consider this one a swing and a miss.
I came away wanting more comedy and less gratuitous splatter. Still, you can't dismiss a movie with as many big laughs as this one packs.
Michelle Monaghan gives a wonderfully rounded performance, reminiscent in its depth and heart of the one Melissa Leo gave in Frozen River.
A movie so generic that it could have been about anyone...like sitting through an endless series of story conferences, in which the life is slowly sifted out of the material.
Sheen, so wonderfully restrained as Tony Blair and deliciously self-aware as David Frost, finds a kind of mania that sends sparks shooting from Clough's eyes.
Touching and insightful, a film that understands what that first whoosh of emotion in a relationship feels like %u2013 and how quickly love can change and vanish.
Funnier and more exciting - and more emotionally connected - than most of the summer's blockbusters so far.
Its utter simplicity masks layers of complexity. Some will see it as a movie about nothing, when in fact it is a movie about everything.
Should be required viewing for anyone who's ever managed an unhappy employee, and will ring loud bells for anyone who's ever been one. Which is most of us, right?
Some films accumulate power as they go on. A film like New York, I Love You stops and starts without accruing much of anything.
A laugh-out-loud satire with a dry-martini wit ... consistently surprising and funny without pandering for laughs.
Somehow, a shovel seems a more appropriate implement for dealing with Lars von Trier's Antichrist than any sort of writing utensil.
Motherhood is a deceptive film that seems to be one thing when it starts %u2013 and then turns a corner and becomes something else, something deeper and more perceptive.
No, Ong Bak 2 isn't a great movie ... But if you love the pure kinetics of a well-shot martial-arts film, Tony Jaa is the most exciting figure to come along in years.
Mulligan gives a performance of dazzling nuance, full of feeling without being splashy or overly emotional. She mixes toughness, fragility, intelligence and naiveté.
Ulrich Tukur is an actor of great restraint and yet great expressiveness... John Rabe offers a unique perspective on the rape of Nanking.
Reminiscent of The Messenger in its ability to capture unexpressed sorrow, its strong acting and story-telling make it a film that will haunt you.
Like sitting in someone else's living room watching him play a videogame...with nary a moment of actual tension or excitement in the whole, prefabricated affair.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Barney's Version puts Paul Giamatti where he belongs: front and center in a film of great romantic, dramatic and comedic sweep.
Upbeat but harrowing, a story of family cohesion threatened by implosion. It's a fine boxing story, but it's an even more compelling story of relationships worth fighting for.
Strong and believable, though its subject may not be one that most moviegoers want to confront at this particular moment in history.
A documentary look at Gray's life told by, who else, Spalding Gray. It's only fitting that that his life is told in his own words
von Donnersmarck has gone Hollywood - and I can't wait for him to go back to Germany.
Its subject is so personable, with both an infectious personality and a razor-sharp mind, that it's hard not to get caught up in his story.
movie_title: Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing will protect the audience from this dreadful film except to stay far away from the few theaters unwise enough to show it.
Slow and grinding, Taymor's version of The Tempest would be dwarfed by any teapot she might decide to set it in.
Mitchell shows a firm but gentle touch with this material. He's keenly attuned to the shades of sorrow, but also to the possibility of humor, forgiveness and resolution.
Aronofsky thrills you with the tension he creates. But when it comes to the big reveals, you're either giggling at what he shows you or already way ahead of him.
Brooks' script is more hit than miss, but it is hit-and-miss nonetheless. Probably too studied in its approach to grab a mass audience.
Great fun and strong filmmaking, encapsulating the hubris and self-aggrandizement that marked the career of uber-lobbyist Jack Abramoff.
There's a found-art quality to Somewhere, a sense that Coppola has snuck up on the best moments in the film and captured them with a camera.
A terrific western..One of the best movies of the year and one that shows other filmmakers just how a western should be made.
The law of diminishing returns is a law for a reason...as lazy a comedy as Adam Sandler's Grown Ups.
A miracle of virtuoso acting and understated filmmaking..This is slice-of-life drama that is cosmic in its microcosmic depth. The whole world exists in these scenes.
There's nothing feel-good about Blue Valentine that the feel-bad parts can't undermine. Which doesn't sound like praise but it is.
Somewhere along the line, we've lost the ability to appreciate a film as deeply felt and intuitive as Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's Biutiful.
It stumbles from scene to scene, theme to theme and trope to trope. If you want it to make sense, however, you're out of luck.
If you're new to Phil Ochs, it will reveal a voice silenced too early and, just maybe, send you scurrying to iTunes for a sampling of his work.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Carries the legacy of the original - it's deadly dull, self-important and besotted with its own computer graphics..Flashier effects but no dramatic sense or sense of drama.
P.T. Barnum and H.L. Mencken remain inarguably correct in their assessment of the public's gullibility and appetite.
A believably creepy tale that forces the audience to draw its own conclusions about what did and didn't happen.
Faster is empty-calorie action trying to disguise itself as gourmet genre dining. Not that those empty calories can't be tasty - they're just so damned forgettable.
Off-balance - a state in which Chabrol liked to keep his audiences. He's successful one last time ... a film that never quite reveals itself in the way an audience would like.
Both a compelling and an infuriating film..this is Watts' and Penn's movie and the two of them make a strong and watchable team.
Boyle's film is dynamic and alive, a celebration of life instead of a contemplation of death...It's absolutely one of the year's best.
Downey and Galifianakis work it hard - but there's just not much for them to work with...a script that runs out of laughs before they're halfway across the country.
Gibney possesses the clarity of vision and intelligence to take complicated stories and make his material both comprehensive and interesting.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Saying that For Colored Girls is the most disciplined, least clownish film that Tyler Perry has made is faint praise indeed. And that's how it's meant.
Like a mix of the Three Stooges and Abbott and Costello...This ultra-dark British comedy is a blend of slapstick and smart bad-taste humor. This ultra-dark British comedy
An Australian thriller that's never quite as clever or original as it seems to think...as a movie, it's decidedly unthrilling.
Complain loudly about the 3D tide - but see and enjoy Megamind for its own considerable charms.
A movie that earns its stripes as being wildly inappropriate and quite funny...a sleeper for the end of a year that's been short on laugh-out-loud comedies.
Shot in shadowy black-and-white, its first 20 minutes feature Balibar singing a song on stage portentously called Torture which was what it was like to listen to her.

There's no repressed emotion in John Gray's heart-on-the-sleeve drama...it's an old-fashioned kitchen sink drama that feels like something from the 1970s.
Not a lot happens in Octubre - and yet lives change. Worlds change...has a Jim Jarmusch quality of deadpan wit and cinematic restraint.
A sensibility that blends comic books and video games - then invests it with an operatic grandeur and a seriousness that gives it surprising emotional weight.
You either already know all this about Jobs - because you were a true believer in him as The One True Tech God - or you don't because you don't care.
Nobody talks without needing to in this film, And what they have to say is nearly always either interesting, revealing or both.
The most chilling film of the year, more frightening than any horror film because it seems so real..generates an electrifying level of tension and just plain fear.
A misfire from start to finish. Track down Love Crimes to see what all the fuss is about.
A far too neutral retelling of a subject on which there are seemingly no neutral opinions
Given the right opportunity, Kathryn Hahn could give Melissa McCarthy and Kristen Wiig a run for their money as the funniest woman working in movies.
Like watching a friend play a race-car videogame. Over and over and over again for 90 minutes. Without ever offering you a turn.
A strong dramatic vision and the intelligence to carry it out with minimal resources..the kind of movie we need more of: thought-provoking, unshowy but deeply affecting.
A workmanlike doc-bio of a toweringly mysterious figure who rejected exactly the kind of cult of personality that this film continues to exploit.
The word that came to mind as I walked out of Kick-Ass 2 was "vomitous." The best thing that can be said about it is that it's not in 3D. That's not nearly enough
Shelton's secret: she finds terrific actors to invest her characters with a depth, humanity (and wit) that makes their lives interesting, even when nothing big is going on.
Gandolfini reveals a smile that is easy and warm; it makes his premature death this summer that much sadder, when you consider the range he had but rarely got to show.
A deceptive film: a drama disguised as a comedy, with laughs that are undercut but sad truths.
The script is misshapen and out of balance..Bello disappears for vast chunks of time..The rest of the cast all seem like bystanders to the Hugh and Jake show.
Exactly as middlebrow and mainstream as most of Howard's oeuvre..Chatter about it as an Oscar contender is simply laughable.
Not just good for a film directed by an actor or a first-timer - it's a solid, entertaining film. Period.
One of the year's most entertaining and enriching nonfiction films...Moving and joyful.
Watch this film - and then show it to someone who refuses to educate themselves about what the financial situation is all about.
A breakout role for Weigert...deserves to be seen by a wide audience.. because it's just an exceptional and pleasurable film
A harrowing, white-knuckle tale from start to finish...Life or death: How much more of a story do you need?
Forces the viewer to consider those complex emotions from a distance, rather than dramatizing them in anything more than the most oblique or glancing way.
A small but thoroughly engaging dramatic comedy...Paul Giamatti is one of our great screen actors, a poet of frustration and regret with a wide range.
Schmaltzy, even corny - but it also gives a face to issues that continue to haunt us..pulls you into its drama and gives you a new angle on a history you thought you knew.
Seyfried's eager-to-please Linda Lovelace seems like a hostage in her own life, reminiscent of another famously pilloried female of the period, Patty Hearst.
Pixar has the kind of layered, lovingly crafted humor that the best TV sit-coms have; there's an ease to the cleverness, an unpretentious, highly skilled approach to comedy.
The law of diminishing returns kicks in early...The film is not a bust, but its ending will leave you saying "if only..."
Even more symptomatic of how badly dumbed-down big-budget action has become...Emmerich is a bombastic hack, not as cynical, perhaps, as Michael Bay, but just as soulless.
The best thing I can say is it's not in 3D. But it's barely one-dimensional...Depp proves that it's possible to overact without ever changing your expression.
Calling this film a cat-and-mouse game would insult felines and rodents, both of which are much smarter than this movie.
There's not a drop of irony in del Toro's film, nothing cynical..I find it all kind of refreshing, in a time where sarcasm and meta are the ruling attitudes.
Captures the fear that seems to drive too much of race relations in this country, that blend of unease and false assumption that kills communication and leads to tragedy.
A witty riff on the ugly American...Further proof that Cera has a lot more range (and daring) than haters give him credit for.
Will shake you up and upset you. At a minimum, it might make some people rethink where they're going on their next vacation.
The tyranny of fatherhood doesn't have a more intimidating embodiment than Niels Arestrup.
It calls to mind films that understood that the less you saw, the spooker it got..It's as scary a film as I've seen in a long time.
The kind of movie where all the best jokes are in the trailer...as thoroughly unnecessary as anything out there, with the possible exception of The Lone Ranger.
Not just one of the best films of the summer; it's one of the best of the year, a drama with enough laughs to underscore just how tragic its portrait really is.
Plaza is a minimalist who knows how to do a lot with a little..a girl-power comedy about one young woman seizing the reins of her own sexuality.
An extremely entertaining comic-book movie - though a comic-book movie nonetheless...not great but, hey, it's good enough.
Doesn't find new ground but finds new ways to make this story feel personal and involving.
A film with wit, tension and sheer headlong pace to grab and hold your attention for a brisk 106 minutes..fast and funny, definitely the smartest action movie of the summer.
Announces the arrival of a new triple-threat talent: Lake Bell..a delight at Sundance, it arrives in the dog days of summer like a cool breeze.
I laughed a lot during this brisk, consistently funny movie...counts on comedy shocks for laughs - but it makes them outlandishly weird and surprising.
Neill Blomkamp is the real thing: a visionary filmmaker with a headful of dystopia and the story-telling ability to give it some punch.
Wrong-headed, self-indulgent and pretentious...Gosling gives virtually the same performance as in Drive, which reveals its seams and shortcomings.
A film that makes you feel a lot without resenting it. You wish it were better, but it's good enough not to make you begrudge its shortcomings.
Powerful and saddening..it will hit you like a fast-moving bus.
Puts you right in the middle of the action and never lets you go..gritty, gripping fare, a movie that will leave you shaken.
Straightforward action, with less hand-to-hand than you'd like and too much gunplay to be interesting..Efficient, diverting and utterly forgettable.
Obviously not for everyone, in the same way that Park's films aren't. But if you've got a taste for this kind of brutal, in-your-face story-telling, Lee delivers.
A wonderfully measured film, packing each frame with information that resonates with something else in the film. If it doesn't make a star of Isaac, there is no justice.
This film has actual heart and soul. That's because Russell looks at the whys of these people's lives in ways that make this movie jump to life at unexpected moments.
Will leave you wet-eyed and appreciative for it. It's a personal story that proves to be more than a little universal.
A daring piece of work...turns what could have been a one-joke movie into something much deeper and more emotionally thoughtful.
Only Adam Sandler makes movies that are less entertaining.
Like a more expensive Land Before Time: bad writing, corny jokes and a weak (and familiar) plot.
As bitter and brutal - and witty and entertaining - as anything since Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf.
Works - as a musical and as a drama. It's a story that hits a universal chord: that forgiveness is the antidote to anger and the beginning of renewed connection.
He's not really a wolf - he's more like a hyena, a scavenger, a bottom-feeder. Why would you want to know his story?
A gripping tale of men pushed to the extreme and rising to the occasion, right up to the moment they no longer can.
The script for this film is never sharp or savvy enough to counteract both the ick factor and the simple lackluster quality of it all.
You want to root for this little movie because it works so hard. But, finally, to not nearly enough effect.
A bittersweet tale of self-discovery for all involved.
movie_title: Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: You watch her sailing and you get caught up in the relaxing, infinite quality of the pursuit: the sounds, the colors, the feeling - you are and must be totally in the moment.
Hart's flailing and Cube's slow-burn scowl are supposed to be the funny part. That, unfortunately, is an inaccurate assumption. Even the cheap laughs are expensive here.
This film is too nuanced and understated for any Hollywood studio to get right. See this version before someone makes an inferior copy that gets more attention.
Given the figures on the relationship between teen motherhood and poverty, this movie seems woefully short on references to sex education, birth-control and family planning.
If you let it, Visitors casts a spell, unlike any film you've seen in a long time.
The film runs out of steam in its second half. It keeps chugging along, but it feels like Stiller and crew are going through the motions.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Unchallenging but exciting and enjoyable, an underdog story with a relatively happy ending.
At a little under two and a half hours, "Mandela" feels long at times - and yet, at the same time, not long enough..Elba is a commanding actor of great subtlety and grace.
A solid replica of the original, a new film with pleasures of its own that draw upon the appeal of the first film...not a great film but a decidedly enjoyable one.
I'm not exactly a Machete cultist - but I'm cultish enough to admit I had a lot of fun watching Machete Kills.
May be the year's most subversive film: a horrifying satire of the manufactured fun we've come to associate with the Disney assembly line.
A bravura performance in a gripping film that joins Gravity in the competition to be the year's most harrowing.
The year's most powerful film, an arthouse masterpiece which demands to be seen..important, engrossing, upsetting...It's hard to imagine one that will hit you harder.
An engaging portrait of an artist that blends performance and verite footage...should whet your appetite for his music.
By-the-numbers biopic...Assange, the dramatic character, isn't nearly as interesting as the real Assange.
McCarthy's self-importance combined with Scott's make an uncomfortable fit.
A powerful lesson in the timeless nature of history that will shake viewers with its building emotional power.
I didn't laugh as often as I did at the earlier Jackass films, but it did make me laugh just as hard.
It's never very funny, nor is the music particularly memorable. Two big strikes right there.
Having squandered most of this century's first decade being a movie star, Matthew McConaughey has approached its second stanza as an actor. The results have been salutary.
Not a terribly good film, but it features some of the best martial-arts action I've seen on film in a while.
A leaden-footed mess, bulky and uninvolving...computerized movie-making, built with algorithms and tropes and very little actual humanity..Thor-mageddon ain't much fun..
Strong stuff, a film that scalds its subject - who still doesn't seem to understand what he's done that's pissed so many people off.
Ah yes, an animated TB plague - now you're talking.
A surprisingly funny tone poem on roots and separation and disappointment...Dern barely speaks and holds the camera's focus just with his fascinatingly oblique presence.
This isn't a movie about victims - it's a movie about surviving and coming back.
Engaging and diverting, a movie that never quite goes where you expect it to - even when it shows you the ending right at the start.
A beauty: a detective story with heart and humor that can't help but provoke outrage - as well as admiration for the capacity for empathy by a woman who was deeply wronged.
Downplaying the violence itself strips the story of some of its power. You get little sense of the toll that surviving a competition such as this takes on the victor.
That rare intelligent romantic comedy that's also about something deeper. Succumb to its charms.
Reitman never winks at the melodrama of the romance. Nor does he overdo it...not without its flaws, but if you let yourself get caught up in it, you won't be sorry you did.
We are left at the end with imponderables and questions, things that will ricochet around your brain long after this compelling and unsettling movie ends.
Burrows deep into a social strata that seems to float just below the surface of everyday consciousness...You can't help but engage. At least I couldn't.
A film that should make you furious. It raises serious issues about our commitment to helping the least fortunate of our citizens.
Audaciously, in-your-face creepy and exhilarating in a way few films have been since David Lynch's Blue Velvet.
A roiling visual extrusion rendered from CG imagery..I'm afraid it will be a while before researchers find the algorithm to make an audience care about a movie this inert.
This underwater drama sinks itself with its overly formal dialogue, limited imagination and overheated dramatic leaps.
This is Winstone's show and it's a perfect showcase for his bluff, easygoing machismo. He was born to play this lovable scoundrel, with an emphasis on his rogue elements.
There's no place like home, indeed.
You don't have to be a Journey fan because I'm not. Really..Less a rockumentary than the story of one man discovering just how much real work goes into living the dream.
Chilling stuff, the kind of thriller - like The Vanishing, let's say - that leaves you stunned and gulping.
Never dawdles but rarely digs deep...set against the backdrop of impending war, when everything seems more vital and in-the-moment. Except for this sometimes plodding film.
Since they were fictionalizing it anyway, why not give it a little life?
Why would Roth give himself over to filmmakers who'd make a movie as dull and superficial as this one?..Makes you long for the doc that could be made by a real filmmaker
With a cast this well-stocked with comedy talent, you'd think just a few more laughs wouldn't feel like such a reach..a movie for 8-year-olds who haven't seen a lot of movies.
Who is it that keeps casting Jim Sturgess in movies? His range is limited to goofy smiles and pained looks of unrequited love - all that's required for this film.
An aggressively entertaining movie..that can be serious when it wants, without ever taking itself too seriously.
Funny, surprising and full of heart...meatier than you'd expect, with lots of unexpected humor.
You can count on one hand the number of good romantic comedies in any given year. Which is why Admission is such a treat.
A reminder of a horrifying period in history and a primer on the resilience and determination of which human beings are capable.
Butler winds up as the last good guy standing in a building full of terrorists. So, of course, he's able to kill them off one at a time because, well, Die Hard.
The wave of hype about this movie has already started. To which I'd offer this thought: Bull****.
There is an inevitability to the story, which builds tension like a snowball propelled by an avalanche. Cianfrance invests it with a sense of tragedy that's Shakespearean.
Populated with characters who seem to have no interior life..In his own oblique way, Korine offers commentary about just how empty that world is.
A new-agey sci-fi tale that spends a lot of time talking while making little actually happen..wants to be about ideas, rather than story. Except there aren't any ideas.
Feels like a not-very-skillful attempt at making a certain kind of movie...repeatedly trips over its own shoelaces, calling attention to distinct story-telling shortcomings.
With Hitchcockian self-assurance, Karpovsky is able to inject an element of surprise and uncertainty even into the film's final moments.
A curiosity that is neither funny nor striking enough. The most striking thing about it is the ballooning gut of Gerard Depardieu, whose barge-like girth is truly astonishing.
The music is never as impressive as the filmmakers want you to think but the filmmaking itself is often very good - good enough to keep you watching and plugged in
I certainly agree with its politics. So why did it feel like a preaching-to-the-converted letdown?
A mild blend of comedy and sentiment, heavy on the sentiment and, unfortunately, far too light on the comedy.
Making an homage to 40s gangster films isn't the same as making a derivative and slight piece of entertainment, which is what this bloody, only occasionally exciting film is.
A movie that some moviegoers can justify as a guilty pleasure. I'll certainly admit to being embarrassed at just how entertained I was.
A film that should beguile anyone with even the slightest tendency toward being a seeker - and any fan of the book who wants a figurative translation to the here and now.
For a certain demographic looking to lose itself in a couple of hours of diverting (but not completely mindless) action, you could do worse.
..isn't awful, just kind of pale and predictable..It's got a big wind-up - but not much on the ball.
Karpovsky is an engaging screen presence, doing comic artistic neurosis in "Red Flag"..an explosion of work from an intriguing filmmaker.
You keep waiting for this stuff to start paying off, but it's like plugging quarters into a broken slot machine.
The waste of talent is criminal..the movie equivalent of shooting a man in Reno, just to watch him die..a long journey into night that will leave you dazed.
It would be too easy to dismiss it as a simplistic horror-thriller..a movie that seems full of sharp edges and unexpected turns, one that you probably haven't seen before.
Tight, lean and linear, with little wasted motion, but also little complexity..holds your attention without insulting your intelligence - too badly.
Hoult has a blend of sweetness and vulnerability that gives R more depth than the average zombie...with much of his performance in his limpid, expressive eyes.
A movie that's like a nesting doll - with each new revelation hiding as much as it reveals.
A weak-tea reworking of Midnight Run, itself a long-overvalued action-comedy that was never as good its proponents would have you think.
A dark coming-of-age journey about a girl who may or may not be able to summon the character to survive in a way she can live with afterward.
If you can turn your brain off - or tap into the adolescent girl within - you should have fun.
Eliminates the need for McClane to do anything except shoot guns, look pissed and spout reductive one-liners.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Another clichéd story of a cynic who gets in touch with his inner idealist..Movies like this give political satire a bad name.
Has something that both "Dark Knight" films lacked: excitement. It grabs you viscerally, delivers emotionally. It may be the best big movie of the summer.
A better movie than the first one...which is a little like saying that someone with a terminal illness is better off than a person who's brain-dead.
If you happened upon "The Brass Teapot" on TV and it broke for a commercial, you'd probably change the channel.
Even more entertaining than Abrams' first one...the first real blockbuster hit of the summer.
With its dazzlingly cynical story and intensely squalid setting, it's a trip to the dark side - indeed, the darkest side.
It feels amateurish, as though it was made up as they went along. The violence - because that's what most of the action consists of - feels phony.
Moore shows physical-comedy chops that are both admirable and quite funny..a small but very funny treat with a cast to die for.
Watch it - and then try to get worked up about any of the phony scandals that currently preoccupy the media.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: How about a give-back program in which the studios donate one car to charity for each car they smash up in movies like this?
Never less than compelling, generally entertaining and sometimes piercing. The acting matches the script: incisive, unshowy, yet fiercely honest.
The people who want to see it will see it, no matter how bad it is...You have much better ways to waste your time, I'm sure.
Take it on its own terms, as a compelling emotional drama about an impossible situation.
Baumbach's acerbic wit seems to have been diluted by the watery Gerwig, who seems to have no flavor whatsoever...like viewing the outtakes from a movie you don't want to see.
Thought-provoking even as it entertains. It moves with a nimble, sure-footed speed as it pulls you into its shadowy world.
Imagine a script by Quentin Tarantino, directed by Wes Anderson - and you have an idea of just how surprising this film can be.
Acker might as well be pitted against a body pillow, so shapeless and soft is Denisoff's presence.
Has one good idea and little notion of what to do with it. Unfortunately, that's enough for most audiences.
A tightly constructed little suspense machine, as neatly plotted as an advanced calculus problem...builds to a literal cliff-hanger.
This limp outing plays like an extended improv session, in which all of the best jokes wound up in the trailer.
If you invest in Kevin Sheppard's story, it will pay off.
A film that rewards patience and attention. The filmmaking will draw you in and the acting and story will keep you rooted to your seat.
It's hard to imagine another documentary this year that will be as uplifting, entertaining and moving...It is the musical cure for whatever ails you.
Witty and raunchy - alternately juvenile and sophisticated, drawing laughs from all parts of the comedy spectrum.
A coming-of-age tale that touches a lot of bases and explores a variety of tones in ways that most films are too timid to do.
Gripping and unsettling..There is a fly-on-the-wall quality to the scenes that's almost voyeuristic. It creates a sense of floating dread that builds as the film goes on.
You can only listen to so much screaming and crying before it stops having the desired effect (ratcheting up the viewer's stress level) and simply becomes grating.
Like the slow-cooking version of a road comedy, yielding tasty results thanks to the craft and patience of the filmmakers.
As he skewers the tabloid mentality that has replaced actual journalism, Redford points to the lassitude of the masses (and media) that led us into an immoral war in Iraq.
I'm jaded enough that I came out of it feeling exhilarated if exhausted..this film has a sense of humor, as well as a relentless approach to its tale of demonic possession.
Like any good illusionist, Boyle understands that misdirection is a big part of the gag..feels like a Boyle escapade from start to finish.
Upsetting, exhilarating and frightening in equal measures. It's got the ability to pierce your complacency with its cautionary tale.
Maybe what Malick is working toward is a film in which he can leave out the actors altogether. He's getting pretty close.
Deals with big emotions and allows you to feel them without stacking the deck or pushing obvious buttons. Instead, it lets the story of Jackie Robinson pack the punch.
Seems like such an obvious topic for a film that it's surprising no one else has made it before..Raises issues that never get old. Nor should we stop talking about them.
A portrait of a tough American musical spirit, fighting through until the end and taking energy and solace from the music he created.
movie_title: Ain't In It For My Health: A Film About Levon Helm (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Not that the film doesn't want to make your pulse race. It's just that it seldom does. You have far too much time in this bloated and underwhelming film to consider that fact.
One of the year's best films: funny, moving, thought-provoking - and so personal that it strikes universal chords.
It's a mind-tickler of exquisite precision that saves some of its surprises for the finale.
Bahrani dishes up obvious melodrama about fathers and sons, down-home values versus shifting business ethics.
The film seemed to sputter along without truly lifting off.
Both dreamy and dramatic, a fascinating view of Indian history seen through the prism of a personal story.
The film lives and breathes with Aprile's performance. She has a wonderful watchfulness..She sees all; how much she understands is probably shocking.
A powerful blend of grit and finesse..a gripping crime story..a psychopathic killer played with unlikely restraint by the most surprising actor around, Michael Shannon.
There are laughs and a warm romantic feeling to be had, but there's more going on here than simple feel-good story-telling.
Black chooses to pump up the action to a size that makes it hard to focus the film's actual excitement.
It's like a vanity project for - well, who, exactly? I could barely sit through the whole film; I can't imagine wandering the aisles of this puffed-up emporium.
Luhrmann does find the beating heart at the center of this overstuffed enterprise. It rests firmly in the person of Leonardo DiCaprio's Jay Gatsby,
A spare, well-told story that shows teen characters learning necessary lessons in ways that manage to be both universal and dramatic.
Grim and compelling but, ultimately, inspiring - and never less than thrilling.
A worthy film and an important document..It's a narrative we need to understand and learn from.
movie_title: Hank: Five Years From the Brink (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like a cinematic magic trick, one that unveils itself over the course of roughly 90 minutes.
A slight but affecting film built around a stirring central performance by Patrick Stewart, who lifts this small indie to another level altogether.
The script is a mix of talky exposition and gun battles, the lowest form of cinematic action..a cyber-thriller that's distinctly short on thrills, not to mention credibility.
The kind of movie that makes you hold your breath when things get tense. How long can you hold yours?
This dreadful film mistakes gross violence for thrills and formula setups for action sequences. J-Lo, usually a controlled screen presence, mostly looks hapless here.
The good news is that Jupiter Ascending is actually not bad. But that's not the same as being great - or even good.
Comedy is a very subjective thing and I can imagine people who won't find What We Do in the Shadows funny. But I can't imagine that they have happy lives.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Vaughn finds new ways to deconstruct and reconstruct the spy-thriller... blends Hong Kong action with state-of-the-art digital effects to create breathless set pieces.
A well-made and unabashed feel-good film that has the advantage of being true. How often do you find that?
Film-making at its most friskily entertaining and surprising. Even if it doesn't win the Oscar on Sunday, it's a film to be prized for its audacious energy.
Cotillard does a stirring job portraying the repeated triumph of will over fear...A film that places value on the simple human attributes of empathy and sacrifice.
Works hard and does manage to generate entertainment. But the strain shows.
a fascinating character: quick-witted, still relatively spry for his age, with an air of mystery, even when he's simply telling the truth.
Sequel-itis: Let's take this delightful little surprise hit and try to duplicate its success without doing anything original.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There are not a lot of actual incidents in the film: no chases or shootouts. Yet Gullette creates real tension, through silences, quiet encounters with the drug lord and the extremely expressive face of Ben Acha.
The writing is wooden and Penn obviously knows it... If Penn is helpless against exposition-heavy dialogue, what chance do the other actors stand?
Get Hard isn't terrible. It's funny often enough to stave off impatience. That's something, I guess.
Funny and smart, finding humor in cultural pretension without taking cheap shots. That's a lot harder than it sounds.
A great movie? Probably not - but a compelling and involving one, dealing with an important moment in recent history? Woman in Gold is absolutely that.
The limitations of its script and of Jonah Hill's performance in the central role keep it from transcending its shortcomings.
Pleasant and occasionally touching, without ever being really compelling.
There's a difference between tart and vinegary and Maps to the Stars is consistently on the wrong side of it.
The plotting gets a little sludgy...it runs out of ideas long before it plods to the final credits
Busy without being involving, energetic without having much excitement... And the lesson is this: Everyone dies, sooner or later.
Eastwood displays the futility of the Iraq war, but, given more than 10 years of films with the same ideas and images, it's not a startling or even moving message.
Overstuffed and sometimes undercooked, it still manages to envelop you in worlds and situations you've never seen before.. with human feelings that can't help but move you.
A wildly imaginative action-comedy...its computer animation is both whimsical and eye-popping, creating a fantastic world with startling photorealism.
Well-crafted but formulaic, a glossier version of the kind of movie the Lifetime network shows every month.
Haunting, surprising in its humor and beautifully served by the twin performances of Servillo.
Martin Sheen is particularly good as late Union Carbide chairman Warren Anderson.
Light but with a real heart...See this film, if only to live vicariously through her job.
Romantic, at times melodramatic, "Beyond the Lights" is entertaining and emotionally involving.
Thought-provoking and studied in its pace..Have patience, however, and you'll be rewarded by a moving, thoughtful experience.
On a regular basis, I see many worse movies out there than Stewart's sometimes affecting, sometimes overly earnest film.
Readers will be sorely disappointed by how shrunken Zamperini's experiences seem...feels more like a Hollywood formula than a hero's true story.
It's one of the year's most provocative films, precisely because it undercuts every expectation the viewer might have going into it.
Shot with a sense of how to make the intellectual seem dynamic...fulfilling and compelling..Intelligence is rarely this exciting.
Settles for sitcom setups and punchlines.... feels both slight and generic.
An exceptional visual version of what could have been largely an interior journey...manages to tell a tale as large and daunting as the great outdoors.
Treats plot like a rental car: something to be abused and abandoned, squandering a strong start in an orgy of wheel-spinning.
Leigh and Pope simply let Turner exist in the landscapes he's trying to capture, creating the cinematic equivalent of Turner's panoramic washes.
Jackson brings it home with a bang with this final film...exciting and emotional..flies by in a roiling series of climaxes, each carrying a new level of tension and thrill.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A film about courage and strength that should be required viewing in this, a nation whose sense of history extends barely as far as last week.
It's a mess, pure and simple, and remaking it turns out to be a sucker's bet.
A solidly entertaining film, one that finds the humor in an unfamiliar tale of human art and artifice.
I'd be lying if I said that it could stand on its own. That, of course, is the difference between a good sequel and a good movie.
A rousing and visionary piece of work...a kinetic joyride that surfs a giddy wave of dark wit and intelligence..deserves to be mentioned in same sentence as Network.
After tantalizing us with increasingly imaginative developments and the promise of catharsis, Garland lets it all dribble away at the end.
Maclean takes more interest in the journey than the destination. The stops along the way are alternately life-threatening, illuminating and abruptly, wildly funny.
The bubbly Wolff and laconic Rourke have a nice comic give-and-take, but Rourke's face, in the right light, looks like a bad pottery experiment.
The funniest documentary since The Aristocrats.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A serious film that is never solemn, bristling with energy while reminding us that there is no statute of limitations on one's conscience.
Despite all that computer wizardry at work, the green-screen seams show and the herky-jerky pace mitigates against the kind of creeping tension that should inform this film.
A film whose final half-hour has you soaring so high that you almost forget how lame the rest of the film is.
Personally enjoyed the hell out of it; critically, I felt, OK, this is a really good start and a step in the right direction with room for improvement.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It kept me fully engaged for its entire running time and had me thinking about it long afterward.
Simply being dirty and gross is not the same as being funny, something the makers of this film apparently didn't understand.
A melancholy charmer that will make you laugh and bring you to tears.
Barber keeps the atmospherics at full pitch, which tends to draw out the action but undermine the tension. The violence can be brutal at times, but it's seldom dramatic.
Engaging and emotionally intelligent.
So lazy a comedy that I kept looking for Adam Sandler's name in the credits...essentially a funny 3-minute short with a bloated, unfunny full-length feature grafted on to it.

Fey finds a depth in this character that her comedy roles seldom offer... I have a hunch it's a better and different movie than you probably expect.
In a more just universe, the film and Paprika Steen's performance would be part of the Oscar discussion, instead of an imported curiosity.
If it doesn't rank as top-shelf Woody Allen (a crowded shelf indeed), it's still one of his better ones.
Like so many film comedies these days, it assumed that casting funny people was the same thing as writing a funny script; it's not.

One of the summer's small treasures, in the flood of big-budget dross.
Just because you CAN remake a piece of crap like this does not mean that it's a good idea.
Like a long, entertaining shaggy dog story without a punchline...just sit back and let it wash over you in all its witty, if insubstantial goodness.

A miniaturist dealing in microcosms that reveal the world...one of the most human films I've seen in recent years, full of insight, sadness and unexpected laughs.

A sly little wonder of a film that may end up flying under the radar.
There are barely as many laughs in its slack 104 minutes as in the average 30-minute episode.
A coming-of-age tale with bite, introducing a talented new cast to the world in what may be the summer's freshest film.
You're not going to find another film this summer that keeps surprising you the way this one does.
The year's most joyous and surprising movie
The equivalent of a meal made entirely of french fries - by the end, you're stuffed, but you're hardly satisfied.
A bravura performance by Shannon, who can use calm as a weapon in the same way he uses volume.
It would be a brain-teaser, if it only had a brain.
One of the summer's most entertaining... one of only a handful of comic-book movies to transcend the limits of that increasingly cookie-cutter genre.

Builds to a stunning final confrontation that changed the lives of both men.
If you're already steeped in Brando history, then the recordings will seem like a fresh page.
One of those near-misses that feels as though a lot of discussion went into the rationale behind every wrong-headed decision.
Gerwig may be the most overrated (or at least most overemployed) actor of her generation.

A small film with big feelings, built around a pair of engaging performances. It's absolutely worth tracking down.

See it exactly because so many have so much invested in keeping this quiet.

Wildly funny, delightfully stylized and brutally violent at times. You'll never be bored.
A subtle, touching tale..It never quite goes where you expect it to, choosing nuance over broad strokes and smaller moments over splashy effects
A film that has laughs, heart, romance and several other things to recommend its unconventional charms.
Trolls in the waters of both Philip K. Dick and William S. Gibson (without ever really getting a solid bite).
Stirring film, capable of moving you even as it gives you a new perspective from the past on an issue that continues to plague us, here in the future.

Overstuffed, exhaustingly elaborate and just not that much fun...More is definitely less in this piece of Hollywood product.

A quiet, moody sci-fi tale..has an experimental feel and gives up few of its secrets without a struggle.
A valentine to the life of the theater..the kind of movie that allows you to see other people's passion at work.
movie_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that manufactures its feel-good status without really earning it. There's nothing wrong with it that an injection of tension (or story) wouldn't improve.

A fascinating and disquieting experience. If you're looking for a movie that will push you out of your comfort zone, look no further.

Gritty, witty and downbeat, an alternately thoughtful and juicy adaptation of Pete Dexter's novel.

Roils with passion, but does it with a quiet intensity that is startlingly effective.
A ramshackle affair...It's diverting, but insubstantial.

It's not great - but it is funny. That excuses a lot.

Will not only amuse kids and parents alike, but will let the adults keep laughing during the repeated viewings that inevitably will result when it reaches home video.

A stylish, nervy film, one that captures the manners and mores of its 19th-century setting while making the emotions it deals with utterly contemporary.

Like a nonfiction Chris Farley movie...it's never less than entertaining, though not as the redemption story Tom Berninger probably thinks he's created.

A witty, engaging sequel...just as fast, funny and entertaining as its predecessor.

A delightful coming-of-age tale...sweet and funny, with plenty of heart and intelligence.

Straightforward in telling Swartz' story..a solid film on an important topic,
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Berlinger may be our premier true-crime documentarian (though he has many other arrows in his quiver)...a crisp (if dense) examination of a shameful and tragic story.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmaking is spare but incisive and, together with the performances, this film should dominate any awards conversation this fall.
There's much more to it than there seems, thanks to a wonderfully layered performance by Wasikowska...one of the brightest young talents acting today.
Fascinatingly complex and endlessly entertaining documentary... a film which, by measures, both intrigues and tickles you.
A brooding, compelling performance by Neeson... He and Frank combine to give this satisfying story the gravity to be more than just entertainment.
Not a great movie, but an enjoyable one, an emotional comedy that earns its lump in the throat and most of its laughs...Because of or in spite of the director? You decide.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The laughs are on a level with the moments that bring a lump to the throat in a film that never feels less than organic and always feels surprising and alive.
A smarter, more disciplined version of Man on Fire...fast and economic .. not flashy - but it's effective.
A sweet, engaging film which, if a tad too shaggy, is a warm, funny change of pace from most summer fare.
You don't realize just how taut this little film is until it has you thoroughly in its grasp.
As rewarding as a film as it was as a book. In both cases, you walk away feeling gut-punched by a story that manages to save a couple of surprises for the end.
Reminds us we've managed to make our pointless little world even more hellish by torturing each other through the Internet. Or by making films like this.
A spare, compelling film that pulls you along with the insistence of hounds after the fox...offers an important story - and a glimpse of what our media world has since become.
Just keeps charging forward, forcing you to stay plugged in and get charged up by what this energizing film has to offer.
Murray gives his most soulful performance since Lost in Translation.. and gives the film its heart and its wicked edge.
A big piece of entertainment product, glossy and engaging in a way that few movies try to be these days. It's also too often unable to get out of its own way.
Brutal, punishing and exciting - in that order...a searing, gripping tale of the power of that bond that happens between men in war.
This tale of insecurity and reinvention in the backstage world of Broadway wring laughs from cringeworthy moments of frantic desperation.
One of the year's delights, a smart comedy that never sacrifices its depth for cheap laughs.
In examining the most basic human bonds, it closes some of the distance a privileged audience may feel when confronted with the reality of the way the rest of the world lives.
An OK comic-book movie which, like so many of these efforts, has a reach that far exceeds its grasp. It's not bad but it could have been lots better.
Excessive in an interesting way for much longer than you think it could be. Unfortunately, that's not long enough.
An emotionally rich tale with lots of tasty talk about the way men and women deal with each other, knowingly or otherwise.

The plot holes are gigantic, but the spirit is so playful and breezy that you can sit back and enjoy the ride.
Think of MacFarlane as a post-modern classicist, who loves his source material, even if he can't resist the impulse to mock its conventions..I laughed frequently and heartily.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Fast, exciting, surprisingly witty and just plain satisfying..the first really exciting movie of the summer-the most original, the most invigorating and the most entertaining.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Promises more than a few tear-soaked hankies...earns its tears with strong performances and a restraint that help you invest in characters whose departure you will feel.

I was riveted, thanks to Christensen's fearlessly etched performance and Troell's spare story-telling style.
This is Clark Gregg's film and he brings the right blend of salesmanship, anger and flop-sweat desperation to the role.

Smart and thrilling, without ever really tipping its hand about just what game it's playing.

Gordon himself comes across as what he is - a smart hustler with an eye for the main chance, a guy with great stories who isn't a great story-teller.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Competent but unremarkable, an entertainment that evaporates from the mind the minute the credits roll.

Like Bellocchio's draggy, overrated Vincere, this movie wants us to believe in its depth, while mostly just skimming the surface.

A film that manages to pay homage to films of the past even as it sends them up and then pushes past them into a territory all its own.
Goes the long way around, building to a colossal anticlimax. Still, getting there is an admittedly (if intermittently) entertaining ride.
There is an undeniable emotional power to Andrew Haigh's beautifully sketched romantic drama.

Might have been better as a parody - except that it's already a parody of itself.

As much fun as a baseball movie ought to be but rarely is.
Goes exactly where you expect it to - and yet this journey is worth the trip because the destination ultimately proves so moving.
