Worth tracking down to its digital release platforms..It will force you to deal with prejudices you may not even know you had.

A movie that parts the clouds to reveal a surprising sunniness.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

Like a comedy made out of Legos - the pieces snap together so effortlessly that the makers assumed audiences wouldn't notice just how mismatched the components really are.

The real question is: How does a movie as weak as this get made? Who read this script and said, "I have to make this movie"?..It's not funny - and that's the real crime.

A strange mix of outrageous action and surprising stillness. It's like a cross between The American and Reservoir Dogs

movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Rudd is a master at understated goofiness and brilliant at conveying optimistic vacancy. Cluelessness is one of his best comic modes.
A solid film by a self-assured director, one who didn't have an axe to grind dealing with a subject that could have been spun that way.
Gripping and gritty, a thriller that breeds genuine excitement in both of the time periods in which it is set.
A delicious puzzle: not a whodunit but, rather, a story in which you try to figure out how she's going to get away with it..smart, vicious and oh so tasty.
The whole movie has that sloppy feel, as though it were assembled from leftover parts of other, better comedies.
Wrenching stuff, the kind of unrequited love story that, unfortunately, remains all too common in the real world.
movie_title: I'm Glad My Mother Is Alive (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like Rocky squared: an underdog story with two underdogs..a blast of excitement and roaring physicality. You don't have to be a fan of the sport to get a charge out of it.
The first hour of Steven Soderbergh's Contagion is so tense that you can almost forgive the second half for getting bogged down.
Like a small firecracker that turns out to be a dud..as dead as the city it depicts..Durham ought to sue for libel.
Not that Chasing Madoff isn't a movie with an important subject. But Markopolos' central role in the film can make it a chore to watch.
It's hokey at times - but it also knows how to move you on a personal level.
A small film with nicely etched performances, assembled in a way that is consistently engaging and surprising. How many movies can you say that about?

Early on, I was ready to bolt; the question in my mind was "Why am I watching this?" Aside from the fact that I could say that it's my job, I still don't have an answer.
Slashingly funny..A darkly funny trip down a one-way street. You know where it's headed - but you can't help enjoy ride anyway.
Yet another Garry Marshall mix-and-match mash-up of movie stars, holiday bromides and a laugh-free - even laugh-retardant - script by Katherine Fugate.
Alfredson lets this story unfold with great care..This movie forces you to either pay attention or lose your way.
Can't generate any big chuckles in a movie loaded with such sure-fire laughs as groin-kicks and tots shouting obscenities.
A performance like Swinton's - so gorgeously and painfully calibrated - is something to behold.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Brisk and funny, a documentary that feels like it should be a mock-doc but has the advantage of truth.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It is not simply about the breakdown of civilized behavior. It's about the very untwining of the ties that shelter civilization from the dominance of self-interest.
A generic big-budget action film of mind-numbing pointlessness..Attention-deficit-disorder filmmaking that barely qualifies as a movie.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tough, compelling drama, a comprehensible Shakespeare adaptation that glories in the Bard's language, even as it captures one of his most intriguingly troubled heroes.
The seams are showing badly..Aside from blocks of exposition about the various code words, this movie is chopped up into a collection of action packages.
Close's performance is exquisite, carefully etched with bits of pain and ecstasy.
Spielberg and Jackson..find themselves trapped on the Road to Hell, paving furiously.
"Precious" is the word that kept bobbing to the top of my consciousness as I watched...too precious.
Jolie raises a crucial issue: What are you willing to do to survive? What can you live with? Where do your loyalties ultimately lie?
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One of what is becoming a crowded seasonal field of movies with something to appeal to each of several generations..A confident, entertaining movie.
It has Spielberg's signature moves; what it doesn't have is the sense of passion that says, "This is more than a product. I really believe in this."
It's a serious role with a dash of cheek, given the grand treatment by Streep, an actress who is incapable of giving anything but a compellingly thoughtful performance.
A movie that continually surprises you, reminding you that the best films are the ones that deal with complex emotional truth, rather than a clichéd cinematic version of it.
Examines what it felt like to be a teen in 1963..What did it feel like when the world changed - and you were one of those who wanted to help change it?
I'm not impugning Fincher's intentions; I'm just saying that, as good as his film may be, it's redundant and unnecessary.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Captures the dizzying intoxication of that first serious relationship..and the queasy, mortifying pain that a first relationship can impart. This is a smart, touching film.
Takeshi Kitano has always been a rule-breaker so it's no surprise that Outrage, his latest gangster film, should foil expectations.
The film snails along as a high-minded discourse that doesn't know when to shut up.
A 2D comedy shown with technology to make you believe you're seeing something you're not. And one of the things you're not seeing - or, rather, hearing - is witty dialogue.
Good enough to be proclaimed for what it is: a political film espousing the same arguments against income inequality that are the basis of the Occupy Wall Street movement.
A lengthy drinking binge of a movie: It's fun for a while, seems to offer more meaning than it actually does - and leaves you wishing it hadn't ended so badly.
Offers Farina the chance to demonstrate his range..a finely etched portrait of a man forced to put the best face on some hard choices - mostly to convince himself.
movie_title: The Last Rites of Joe May (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A movie about second chances that's sweet (without being sugary) and tinged with regret.
A one-trick movie, with prefab suspense but also prefab plotting to undercut said suspense.
A sleek, taut spy-thriller with echoes of Day of the Jackal...One of those dark, even nihilistic-seeming thrillers where every turn seems to be a turn for the worse.
A movie that refuses to take itself seriously and manages to find a few outrageous taboos to make fun of...uses 3D with more imagination and wit than any other film so far.
Makes cases for and against Hoover, without really making us care either way...an interesting failure, a movie that tries to do too much and ends up not doing nearly enough.
A film that features one of the year's most deeply felt performances and one of the most tortured characters in a long time.
Has the kind of edge that too few movies allow themselves...handled with skill and a blend of wit and suspense.
There's fighting, disemboweling, limb and head-severing and blood - an entire hard drive's worth of CG blood. There's not nearly as much plot, in fact, as there is blood.
A movie about a wedding that makes you wish you'd checked the "Regrets only" section of this particular invitation.
It has less plot than an hour of Sesame Street, fewer jokes than a Republican presidential debate, and astonishing computer animation, in wholly unnecessary 3D.
A movie that manages to be heart-breaking and laugh-out-loud funny at the same time.
A savage, white-hot performance by Harrelson..intense story-telling..a character you can't take your eyes off.

Williams, it seems, can do almost anything. She is a protean actor of amazing range..a shimmering presence who is both tougher and more vulnerable than you would expect.
One of the year's best films and happiest surprises - a genuine work of imagination and vitality that broadcasts its love for the very form it so expertly uses.

A few moments of startling imagination, between which are sandwiched almost two hours of dreary, opaque storytelling.
A movie so in love with atmospherics and self-examination that it completely loses track of its subject.
You don't have to be a Deadhead or a Ken Kesey-phile to find the fun and the wistfulness in Magic Trip
The cure for the common thriller - an adrenalized chase that starts with a bang and just builds from there.

A fascinating inside look at a misplaced piece of human history..You wish Herzog had been confined to the 42-minute time limit of an hour-long commercial TV presentation.
Rosenthal is just an unpleasant Yank who eventually is the Cassandra preaching doom and bad ratings. He's the last guy you want to have hanging around.
Prom seems relatively harmless; also, lifeless and pointless.
Slight and, I'm afraid, slightly forgettable..The film lives and breathes because of Hawkes, a lank actor with a craggy face, sad eyes and a winning, open smile.
For the first half, you can kid yourself that these witty sidetrips are what the film is about. But then Shelton gets "serious," and it dissolves into arty murk.
A novelty item, but an often entertaining one.
This romantic comedy is actually romantic, mildly funny and built on a set of strong performances from an ensemble cast of great breadth..not half bad.
The brilliance begins and ends with its title..feels less like a movie than a joke about a movie, to which you need to buy a ticket to see the punchline. It's not worth it.
I wish it was a little funnier - or more pointed. It's provocative; it could be more so.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Neither as funny as you'd hope nor as serious or profound as it seems to think...half a good movie, until it takes a fatal wrong turn into solemnity and mawkishness.
About what you expect, maybe a little better. I'd put it somewhere between Iron Man and the first Spiderman on the comic-book-movie spectrum.
It's nice to see an intelligent film about adult relationships and the ways that jealousy and insecurity can shred what is otherwise a solid connection between two people.
Amusing and eye-opening...makes you think, even as it has you chuckling.
Heartbreaking and uplifting..Nice to see a movie that makes education seem like an important thing, given the anti-intellectualism that seems so rampant in the country today.
Gordon-Levitt has an expressive deadpan, marvelous control of his eyebrows and an air of menace. His lean, leathery physique and flat-footed gait convey purpose.

It's always nice to see a movie that values literature and literacy - and this is one of the better ones.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Berge's seemingly serene lack of complicated emotions seems the opposite of what the title of L'amour fou means, which is an obsessive passion.
A comedy for smart people. Allen's humor prizes cultural literacy, a rarity in these times. It's magical, in all the right ways.
Occasionally chuckle-worthy and seldom awful or stupid. It's an emotionally intelligent film, if not an outstandingly amusing one.
It's about changing young lives, on giving them a taste for learning and a facility with language. In this post-literate era, how can you not cheer something like that?
Knocked me for a loop..one of the most powerful and fulfilling films I've seen in a long time.
An admirable film and, in the end, a moving one. You have to give it up to Redford for having the will to make a movie like this.
After all this set-up, there's no real release, no payoff to all the balls the creators have put in the air..a movie that has the right feel but none of the delivery.

Ultimately crashes from lack of story. Brody's tenacity in his Sisyphus-like mission isn't enough to save it.
Romantic, musical, moving -- and outstandingly funny.

Seems so obvious in its metaphors and plotting that you come away stunned at the end to realize just how engaging and involving it is.

A fast-paced action film that entertains without particularly engaging the viewer emotionally. It follows the formula perfectly and creates excitement when it's meant to.

Dustin Ingram is a Jon Heder-wannabe, which is not something that anyone should want to be.

Winkler's writing works too hard to achieve the frothy quality that he attempts.
Hunger is tough going -- and compelling cinema throughout.

A fitting tribute (or introduction) to a writer whose work still rings true in its understanding of human foibles, even as the language it is written in fades into obscurity.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Saying it's not horrible is another way of saying that this movie is consistently disappointing.
The effects are amazing, the pace and action are outstanding - what more need be said? A dazzler of a finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The performances in Life, Above All give it its power, rather than its after-school-special plotting.
